B0007TKNL0|4.0|The long-awaited film of Andrew Lloyd-Webber's musical is not perfect, but director Schumacher surprises us enough to turn out perhaps the best of several screen versions of the famous tale. <br /> <br />On the negative side, the two leads (Gerard Butler and Emmy Rossum) lack vocal strength: His singing voice is annoyingly grating at times; and she sings through her nose too much. The visual style is a tad inconsistent, with Christine and the Phantom's first descent into the underworld looking too much like a pop video, and some of the more frenetic, Moulin-Rouge-inspired camerawork lacking in life. The additions occasionally detract from the flow, especially the unnecessary flashback to the Phantom's adolescence. <br /> <br />In its favour is much, however. Lloyd-Webber's vision was always the most faithful to the original story, capturing Leroux's romance and fantasy as well as the horror. Despite the lack of vocal strength, Butler excels dramatically as a tortured anti-hero who invites compassion and understanding as well as terror; the tension between his tragic loneliness and his violent hatred against humanity is well-conveyed. Among the support, I most enjoyed Miranda Richardson's Madame Giry and Simon Callow's Andre. <br /> <br />The new orchestrations do the music justice. The choreography, like the visual style, is inconsistent, but there are nevertheless some truly splendid numbers, staged with an eye for spectacle as well as a good sense of humour (e.g. Prima Donna). For the most part, despite the very obvious influence, Schumacher avoids mimicking the chaotic pace of Moulin Rouge, and the camera work is generally subtle at the right times. <br /> <br />All the layers of the story are held nicely in balance, making The Phantom of the Opera a moving romantic fantasy, and very much the exhilarating experience that the stage show has always been.

The dragons did not speak, breath fire nor cast magic. In fact, mankind had little fear of them, finding them nuisance to animal husbandry and even bully their youngs. The dragons did not have sufficient intelligence to recognise their innate advantages. <br /> <br />Hal put together an expedition to sail to find the mysterious original homeland of the dragons. <br /> <br />SPOILERS follows! <br /> <br />After some adventures, Hal discovered the dragons were fleeing demons. The film ambits the trials and tribulations of the 1988 Odessa-Permian high school football squad in search of a state championship, but with an in-depth look into the true reality and significance of football on the lives of all that it touches in a small Texas community, \\"Friday Night Lights\\" proves to be more than just a run-of-the-mill sports drama. <br /> <br />Billy Bob Thornton appends a unique role to his impressive resume, playing head Permian coach Gary Gaines, a well-respected leader of his troops but always under intense pressure from the Odessa faithful to be the best. Bissinger (who happens to be director Peter Berg's cousin) and is adapted brilliantly by David Aaron Cohen and Berg.  \\"Friday Night Lights\\" is not the easiest film to stomach (not due to violence, but because of some abnormal jerkiness of the camera), but the film is driven by the splendid supporting performances of McGraw and Luke.  Thornton is very convincing as the demanding, hard-nosed coach who believes in perfection, but ultimately shows his depth as an actor as he exponentially augments Coach Gaines sincerity and heart as the film progresses. 0805079076|5.0|This book is a very interesting attempt to present an explanation for the origin of some of the features of today's language structures. The author does not try to go back to the very beginning of language itself, but takes his story from the point where words already existed, but most grammatical structure had not yet evolved, still before any language of which a record survives. <br /> <br />The author uses examples in present-day languages to illustrate processes in linguistic evolution that are currently taking place or have taken place recently enough to be well documented. This lends a lot of credibility to his ideas. <br /> <br />Because the author was born in Israel (presumably having modern Israeli Hebrew as his first language) and has become a specialist in Semitic historical linguistics, he presents more examples from Semitic languages than one often sees in popular linguistics books intended for the English-language reader, but it is all written in a very easily understood way, and I find the book as readable as if it had been written by a native speaker of English, though with a few signs that the English which the author learned was more British than American.  <br /> <br />There is only one negative comment I would make, and that does not sufficiently detract from the value of the book that I would deny it a 5-star rating: I wish that the author would more clearly separate his own personal speculations from the ideas which are believed by the majority of linguistics professionals. It is clear that a lot of the ideas presented in this book are the author's own, but it is not clear how many.

0743454529|2.0|Jodi Picoult once again tackles a difficult, controversial issue, and I have to admire her effort.  But the book just isn't that good.  As is often the case in Picoult's novels, the characters, although human and flawed, are remarkably unsympathetic.  As is often the case in Picoult's novels, there is an extraneous romance that offers nothing to the plot and if anything detracts from the heart of the story.  Jodi Picoult can tell a wonderful story, only occasionally getting bogged down in moralizing that pulls away from the courtroom action, and she almost succeeds in pulling off something brilliant.  However, the novel's ending is, plain and simple, a cop-out.  Whether it's to attempt to keep from offending people, or because Picoult herself couldn't figure out how to get the outcome she wanted, or didn't know what she wanted at all, but with the final pages of the novel, Picoult manages to eclipse the courage of the stark honesty of the first 400 pages with an ending that is utterly contrived and unsatisfying.  To make matters worse, the book didn't even need that much of an ending.  She didn't need to tie up these particular ends of the story.  She could have has a masterpiece.  But then, if the book was satisfying and didn't have a contrived, convoluted moment that completely negated everything that came before and, often, what comes after it, it wouldn't be a Jodi Picoult novel.

6305399212|5.0|In 1979, the most terrifying film in Science Fiction history, known as ALIEN, was considered to be one of the best films ever made. In 1986, just seven years after ALIEN, James Cameron came onto the scene to direct a sequel to Ridley Scott's masterpiece. ALIENS was the sequel for James Cameron and it still carries the most terrifying edge as the first had done.  <br /> <br />RIPLEY (again played by Sigourney Weaver) was the only survivor of the last massacre. She escaped through The Nostromo's shuttle and went into hypersleep. But that was now over 57 years ago. Floating around in space, Ripley is found and is taken to a medical health center, making sure that she is okay. Ripley finally awakes and meets CARTER BURKE (played by Paul Reiser). Ripley begins feeling chest pains, leading into an alien bursting through her chest, but Ripley wakes up in the medical center, realizing that she just had a nightmare.  <br /> <br />Ripley discusses with the government of the massacre she had terrifyingly survived, but the members of the government are in disbelief. They find a research facility and hide out there, where hours later, it is revealed that Burke is part of the Science Division, who is to take back anybody impregnated with an alien. The aliens arrive in the building, killing off Burke, Gorman, Vasquez, and Hudson. Hicks, Ripley, Newt, and Bishop are still alive. Bishop is outside, repairing their shuttle ship named, The Soloco. She finds Newt and they head out on their way, but they run into the queen alien. The queen is the egg layer. Ripley destroys all the aliens, but has no time to destroy the queen, for the building is ten minutes away from exploding. Ripley and Newt are on top of the building, ready to board The Soloco with Bishop and Hicks, but The Soloco is gone. As Bishop, Ripley, and Newt come off of The Soloco, Ripley thanks Bishop for his help. But before he can appreciate her thanks, the queen Alien rips Bishop in half. But Ripley kills the alien off by blowing it out of the airlock again. Bishop is fine, for his damages can be easily repaired. As they return to Earth, Hicks, Ripley, Bishop, and Newt wait while in hypersleep.  <br /> <br />If you enjoyed ALIEN, then you'll love its amazing sequel, ALIENS. Featuring more scares, more hi-tech weapons, ALIENS is bound to have you watching it over and over again.

0765309408|4.0|Many of the reviews have taken note of the similarities between this book and Heinlein's Starship Troopers.  The comparison is apt.  The author's style is reminiscent of Heinlein's, as well as both the tone of the book and the plot.  I like this book a lot, but it does have a few weaknesses.  For one, humanity is depicted as weaker than many of the races that we confront, yet our first impulse seems to shoot first and negotiate after, if at all.  Not a smart strategy in a Universe where we have few friends.  This idea is noted in the book but quickly glossed over.  Secondly, the bodies of people who sign up but die before induction into the military are used as clone soldiers, but only one clone per body.  What's the point?  If they want to clone people, why only dead people?  And what are the economics of this project?  Is it really cheaper to clone a body, then raise it, equip it and educate it?  I wonder.  And the ending, quite simply, is just a little too pat, assuming that everything is going to turn out just fine in a universe where the death rate from combat is 75%.  Nevertheless, the books characterization, dialogue and generally engrossing plot make this book much better than the average sci-fi potboiler.  Recommended.

B0007Y4TVU|5.0|The new System of a Down cd is all the title promises and more; it is truly mesmerizing.  Mezmerize, released on May 17th is a beautiful masterpiece with a great mix of ballads, rock n' roll and metal.  Anyone with an adventurous mind should check out this cd.  Combined with fearless political opinions and heavy rock riffs, this is a must-own 6 months into the year.  The cd starts off with an intro leading into the recently popular single \\"B.Y.O.B.\\"  This song is a combination of heavy metal verses combined with one incredible chorus.  Don't underestimate the power of Daron Malakian and Serj Tankian's singing; both have talent equal to the greats of the day.  The cd continues with their great rock and singing in the next song \\"Revenga.\\"  This song has less-heavy metal rock and more of the incredibly talented singing.  The next great song on the cd is track 5 \\"Radio/Video,\\" which happens to be a slap in the face to the money-obsessed musicians, \\"Hey man look at me rockin' out/I'm on the radio.\\"  The song quickly transitions from criticism of greedy celebrities to Tankian's \\"la, la, la's\\" which are pleasing to the ear with the abstract and melodic music that accompanies it.  The band does a good job of illustrating their views in only a 38-minute cd.  Humor and sarcasm are eminent in the next two songs, \\"This Cocaine Makes Me Feel Like I'm On This Song\\" and \\"Violent Pornography.\\"  \\"Violent Pornography\\" is a song that you can listen to and laugh with for hours.   The cd really hits it out of the park with the last four songs, which are combination of ballads and heavy rock; these are the kinds of songs people wait 30 minutes after a concert to hear in the encore.  \\"Question!\\" will surely be heard on the radio within a few days with its fast singing/talking vocals, which open the song complimented by an unexpected acoustic guitar.  It then transitions into a head-turning chorus containing fewer words and more guitar.  This is the \\"sleeper\\" track on this album for it isnot too metallic, and mixes in some of Daron Malakian's incredible guitar riffs.  The 10th and 11th Hollywood tracks really end the cd with a bang.  \\"Old School Hollywood\\" is the less impressive of the two songs, but still catchy and \\"Lost in Hollywood\\" will be a household favorite within weeks.  This is the best ballad on the cd as it really highlights Tankian's vocal ability and Malakian's musical skill.  The album does contain a two, not so catchy songs, \\"Cigaro,\\" track 4 and \\"Sad Statue,\\" track 9.  These songs are filler songs that contain bad lyrics and unnecessary rock.  Overall, these two tracks are the only two bad tracks on the album, with the other nine being of great talent.  So, if your not into the \\"I like my kind of music and nothing else\\" mentality, check this album out, download a song or two IF you need to get you in the mood, but definitely open your mind and check out the work of art that is \\"Mezmerize\\".
B000002L9J|5.0|These very words will resonate with me untill the day I die. You've heard the hype surrounding this record, frequently scoring places on \\"Greatest albums\\" lists the world over. You think that it really only got that way is because it's been said so many times, people are literally being conditioned to say so. So that is when you pick up \\"The Queen Is Dead\\", and that is the exact moment you understand exactly why it is such a highly rated piece of work. It is the album that the Smiths discovered new depth in their music. Far more colorful to listen to than the rather drab, black and white sounding debut, the Smiths work with alot of different musical textures to surprising effect. They do not sound bloated and bombastic, but at the same time, the arrangements are more layered and complex. They've pulled off perfect balance here, and they hit you with an incredibly stunning set of songs that traverse many different musical genres that flow almost perfectly together. The hardest rocking title track, The Queen Is Dead, is like a shotgun to your face the moment that bass and drum combo smashes into your speakers. Then bouncy pop of \\"Frankly Mr Shankly\\" and \\"Cemetry Gates\\", rampaging rockabilly of \\"Vicar In A Tutu\\", absolutely surreal lyrical nonsense with the brilliant \\"Some Girls Are Bigger Than Others\\", and the harder rocking \\"Bigmouth Strikes Again\\".  <br /> <br />But no fantastic album is without it's apexes. In the Queen Is Dead's case, there are two. Never before has Morrissey's vocals sounded so genuine and tortured as they do in the magnum opus that is \\"I Know It's Over\\". Geninune brooding angst in a song that will have you quivering. And finally, the godlike 'There Is A Light That Never Goes Out', you've heard about it, you've heard the pages of praise that this track generates, but now you can listen for yourself. It's brilliant, melancholic yearning.. \\"Take me out.. tonight.. where there's music and there's people who're young and alive..\\" the euphoria this track generates.. if there's a song I'd like to die in a car-crash while listening to, this one makes the grade. Wait for the melancholy flute (is it flute?) section at the very end of this song, as it climaxes toward a musical orgasm. Like Led Zeppelin's \\"Stairway to Heaven\\", this track defines an era and at the same time, paints a new standard in excellence that no other band would ever hope to achieve.  <br /> <br />I never ever want to go home. If all that was playing on the car stereo was this song, I wouldn't either.

B0001YRVN4|5.0|I think if this box set release proves anything, it's that nothing can diminish the astonishing achievement of Lucas' vision and determination in creating spellbinding adventures in other worlds.<br /><br />I first ran into Star Wars in 1977, when my dad took me on a holiday to California (we're from Australia) to Grauman's Chinese theatre to see this new \\"science fiction\\" film. I was seven years old and the experience literally changed my life. I now work as a director in television commercials and films in Australia, probably largely because of that day.<br /><br />By self description then, I am I guess, a 'classic' Star Wars fan.<br /><br />But do I believe in the originals over and above the new reworked special editions and amended DVD editions?<br />Well, frankly I'm divided... Let me tell you first, without hesitation, buy this collection - no amount of tweeking by Lucas can obscure what is, above all else a brilliantly constructed universe and epic narrative.<br /><br />I must say that even though I am highly critical of the prequel films, that fact that I had seen I, II and III added immensely to my enjoyment of watching the classic trilogy again. Knowing the background storyline somehow is a perverse thrill, as if you have power over these characters struggling to find meaning as they are thrown into peril and adventure!<br /><br />A few comments though on the experience of watching this trilogy evolve. Listening to Lucas on the commentary track (he participates on the audio commentaries for ALL of the films), Star Wars is like the most expensive, and detailed train set a Hollywood whiz kid ever conceived and he literally cannot keep his hands off it. An adjustment of colour here, an extra creature there, tweeked audio, enhanced skies. Some of the changes are very subtle, others are jarring. The general rule seems to be - if you don't notice it, it's good.<br /><br />For example, the cleaning up and enhanced shots in the battle for the Death Star in 'A New Hope' are brilliantly executed and seemless with the spirit and excitement of the original. To be honest, it's never looked so good. If all of the fixups had been this classy, I'd be ecstatic.<br /><br />The use of additional digital creatures in Mos Eisley on Tatooine is ill advised because it intrudes on the mood of the original film. Why does every new creature need to demonstrate some slapstick hijinks to make it's presence felt? Couldn't it simply form part of the backdrop as it would in reality? It's as if Lucas felt that, having spent money on the new creatures, they bloody better DO something to get noticed.<br /><br />Unfortunately, many of the enhancements belie the problems with the prequels - and most of these problems are associated with story and character deficiencies.<br /><br />Han Solo's added conversation with Jabba in 'A New Hope' adds nothing whatsoever dramatically to the film and in fact holds it up, when the rampaging pace of the original film is what made it such a revelation at the time. Likewise Luke's catching up with an old buddy before getting into his x-wing for the Death Star battle is clunky and slow - that's why it was cut in the first place! Put it in the deleted scenes section for crying out loud!<br /><br />I am one of the reviewers who definitely DOES have a problem with Han Solo's scene with the bounty hunter which Lucas altered so that Solo shoots only after the Hunter's first shot. The fact that Solo beat the Bounty Hunter to the kill told us a lot about who he was (and don't forget this is the FIRST time you see him). He's a mercenary, not a girl scout who waits to be fired on. These touches are politically reactionary. No wonder Lucas struggles to create good characters now when he's afraid to give them light and shade.<br /><br />It has become obvious following the prequels that Solo is still THE most successful and popular character in all of the 6 films. why is this? It's his humanity and cynicism that holds the sympathy and amusement of the audience.  Lucas' fantasy world is so much more powerful because of the wisecracking disdain that Han Solo has for it. HE dominates his environment as a character unlike every protagonist in the prequels, most of whom are developed little more than Playstation characters, completely dwarfed by the special effect landscape.<br /><br />The prequels sadly lack characters with Han Solo's attitude. Ewan McGregor has a crack in ROTS but he's struggling against a witless script. Whack on Episode 4 and 5 and watch Harrison to see how it's done. It's impossible to take your eyes off him. Still, even in the classic trilogy, you could see Harrison Ford starting to look accutely embarassed by having to act against Ewoks and by that stage the acting and space opera whoops-a-daisy was starting to suffer drastically from a serious case of 'the cutes'. As you can probably tell, I'm not a huge fan of 'Return of the Jedi' - Ironically, being the most recent of the classic trilogy, it's also the most dated with an unhealthy reliance of eighties pop influenced music (especially the dire 'variety entertainment' scene in Jabba's palace at the beginning of the film (mystifyingly extended in the special edition), and also by the over reliance on Ewoks (clearly small people in relatively inexpressive furry suits). Still, despite it all, at it's best, for me ROTJ still betters 95% of the prequels - possibly ROTS outdoes it occassionally due to better plotting and vastly better special effects. The main cast from the classic films (Ford, Hammil, Fisher) can still act rings around anyone in the new films, especially in TESB, where they are at their dramatic and comedic peak.<br /><br />'A New Hope' and 'Empire' are simply magnificent on every level and 'Empire' has been far the best treated by any Lucas updates on this release. It looks absolutely breathtaking and Irvin Kirschner's direction is just the kind of planet hopping adult science fiction adventure that we all feel we have been promised, and, aside from Blade Runner and Alien, have never had since.<br /><br />So, for my money, Lucas has done enough to make this one of the most satisfying experiences you'll ever have with your DVD player. For consistency and attention to character and emotions, I think he has now been outdone by Peter Jackson and the Lord of the Rings trilogy, but these films were here first, they changed the world and even made us feel that we had a new religion in a flagging spiritual era. For all of these reasons, I think Lucas has earned the right to keep playing with his train set as he sees fit. I'm still happy to watch on and enjoy.<br /><br />It's worth mentioning that the 150 min doco on the making of the films included in this set is absolutely wonderful, full of fascinating and frank details on the mountains Lucas had to move, both technological and political to make these films happen. Enjoy!f the wisecracking disdain that Han Solo has for it. HE dominates his environment as a character unlike every protagonist in the prequels, most of whom are developed little more than Playstation characters, completely dwarfed by the special effect landscape.    The prequels sadly lack characters with Han Solo's attitude. Ewan McGregor has a crack in ROTS but he's struggling against a witless script. Whack on Episode 4 and 5 and watch Harrison to see how it's done. It's impossible to take your eyes off him. Still, even in the classic trilogy, you could see Harrison Ford starting to look accutely embarassed by having to act against Ewoks and by that stage the acting and space opera whoops-a-daisy was starting to suffer drastically from a serious case of 'the cutes'. As you can probably tell, I'm not a huge fan of 'Return of the Jedi' - Ironically, being the most recent of the classic trilogy, it's also the most dated with an unhealthy reliance of eighties pop influenced music (especially the dire 'variety entertainment' scene in Jabba's palace at the beginning of the film (mystifyingly extended in the special edition), and also by the over reliance on Ewoks (clearly small people in relatively inexpressive furry suits). Still, despite it all, at it's best, for me ROTJ still betters 95% of the prequels - possibly ROTS outdoes it occassionally due to better plotting and vastly better special effects. The main cast from the classic films (Ford, Hammil, Fisher) can still act rings around anyone in the new films, especially in TESB, where they are at their dramatic and comedic peak.    'A New Hope' and 'Empire' are simply magnificent on every level and 'Empire' has been far the best treated by any Lucas updates on this release. It looks absolutely breathtaking and Irvin Kirschner's direction is just the kind of planet hopping adult science fiction adventure that we all feel we have been promised, and, aside from Blade Runner and Alien, have never had since.    So, for my money, Lucas has done enough to make this one of the most satisfying experiences you'll ever have with your DVD player. For consistency and attention to character and emotions, I think he has now been outdone by Peter Jackson and the Lord of the Rings trilogy, but these films were here first, they changed the world and even made us feel that we had a new religion in a flagging spiritual era. For all of these reasons, I think Lucas has earned the right to keep playing with his train set as he sees fit. I'm still happy to watch on and enjoy.    It's worth mentioning that the 150 min doco on the making of the films included in this set is absolutely wonderful, full of fascinating and frank details on the mountains Lucas had to move, both technological and political to make these films happen. Enjoy!

0553573411|5.0|It's books like this that make you wish there was a larger rating scale. Some fantasy books deserve 5 stars for fluid, imaginative writing and original ideas. The you reach Hobb and wish you could add an extra star in retrospect, because its the epitome of a storytelling experience.  <br /> <br />This book matches the first installment in the series very well. It doesnt lose steam like many series do by the second book, adding nonsense fillers and taking the story where it shouldn't because the author didn't have a 3-book installment planned from the beginning. Hobb doesn't have the most artistic writing style I've ever seen. It's not prone to lots of flourishes and flowery wording, but it is extremely solid and engrossing. Sometimes I can pick up her books and not be in the mood to start with her more subtle writing style; which sometimes takes recognition of her talent to see that the first few pages aren't boring, but perfectly developed, no more no less.  <br /> <br />Character development flows nicely, and none of the characters are superheros who can't get hurt and have endless powers. Everyone is human and everyone has their own process. The suspense in this story is great too, as 3/4 of the way through i was literally holding myself back from skimming to find out what was going to happen. The lines between good and bad can be sometimes blurred, with the reader never being quite sure who's helping Regal amount to his devious plotting.  <br /> <br />If you're looking for a synopsis you can find that on your own. What I offer is the assurance for a worthwhile fantasy, devoid of hackneyed genres and familiar pitfalls, that is neither overwhelming as sometimes can be, or too simplistic.  <br /> <br />

B00004ZD69|4.0|The long band name, the long album title, the long tracks. This is not pop music by any stretch of the imagination. It is an acquired taste and the 30 second song samples provided here don't do it justice. So how do you describe it to people that haven't heard it? You can call it post-rock if you have to classify it (but not all post-rock was created equally). You can call it unusual (or as I called it- \\"not pop\\") but that doesn't help. To me, it's like classical music with long suites of music comprised of several distinct movements, only with a rock edge to it. This is music you feel, not sing along with.  <br /> <br />Lift Your Skinny Fists has 4 tracks - all near 20 minutes in length - three of which are the best stuff Godspeed You Black Emperor has offered to date. Tension is the keyword here. It builds and builds on an array of stringed instruments and percussion until its release is necessary to avoid breakdown. Then, after a lull comprised of droning noise and/or eccentric vocal samples, it builds again. <br /> <br />If you found this page, you're probably already curious about the group and/or this kind of music. I'd say give it a try. This is their most accessible album. If you don't like this, you weren't made for Godspeed.

B000069HKH|5.0|`The rising' was inspired by the September 11 attacks and is a deeply personal, moving musical experience.<br /><br />There are typical Springsteen uptempo rockers like the jaunty, catchy `Further on (up the road)', `Waiting on a sunny day', `Countin' on a miracle', `Let's be friends (skin to skin)'<br /><br /> and a couple more, which are not directly linked to 911.<br /><br />`Worlds apart' stands out in its Arabic influences, telling the story of a cross cultural romance. A brilliant track.<br /><br />The title track is an anthemic rocker about regrouping, getting up again, coming back stronger. Almost a call to arms.<br /><br />Other standouts are `Nothing man', `Empty sky' (about looking into the NY skyline where the towers once stood and seeing nothing), and `My city of ruins' a moving ballad which has a gospel feel. Spiritual. Absolutely amazing!<br /><br />The highlight of the CD is also possibly the greatest song on loss ever released (You're missing) with poignant lines like `..too much room in my bed, too many phone calls... shirt's in the closet, shoes in the hall' describing the subtle signs reminding one of the reality of loss of a loved one. Beautiful! Even more meaningful to those of us who know someone missing from that fateful event.<br /><br />Carefully and masterfully written lyrics, coupled with Springsteen's passionate delivery make for one of the best CDs of 2002.
0375405380|5.0|Don Winslow's latest book (after _California Fire and Life_), _The Power of the Dog_, is an epic look at the US war on drugs from its earliest beginnings to more recent times.  The book is violent and thrilling and heart-breaking, as it follows a large cast of characters from the early 1970s through 2004, showing how the competing interests and agendas of various government agencies (the CIA, the DEA, etc.) get in the way of successfully combatting the problem, and often only served to make things much worse.<br /><br />Art Keller, the book's protagonist, is a half-Hispanic DEA agent who grew up in the San Diego barrio and saw the effects of drugs on his friends and family firsthand.  As a rookie agent, he makes the mistake of befriending Don Miguel Angel Barrera, one of the top Mexican policemen, in an effort to topple the reigning drug kingpin.  Barrera proceeds to move into the subsequent power vacuum and sets up La Federaccion, a much more well-organized and deadly organization than previously existed, and run by his two nephews, the intelligent and sensitive Adan, and the flashy and violent Raul.<br /><br />This sets in motion a 30-year vendetta on Keller's part, as he attempts to take down the Barreras and atone for his mistake, a vendetta that will lead to the deaths of numerous innocent parties along the way, and to Keller's estrangement from his own wife and children.<br /><br />The book was a very fast-moving, though extremely violent novel.  In a little over 500 pages, Winslow does an amazing job of encapsulating a lot of recent history, including the Camarena murder, the Iran-Contra scandal, and other related events, into a very readable and entertaining novel, one of the best I've read recently.  If you're not too squeamish, I'd highly recommend the book.
B0002OERI0|5.0|I loved `Basketcase' and `When I come around' from Dookie, Greenday's debut. Along the years, I heard the odd Greenday song. Then I got `American Idiot'.<br /><br />This is a CD full of energy, some rage and quite a bit of political lyrics too: the track `American idiot' is a declaration of independence from the perceived masses who blindly eat up government propaganda, all set to a furious drum beat and racing guitars, `Holiday' is a chant like rocker with an almost marching beat which features lyrics like `zieg heil to the president gasman, bombs away is your punishment, pulverize the Eiffel towers, who criticize your government'.<br /><br />That aside, what we have here is very good music. Clever lyrics, and great musicianship.<br /><br />There are some rock ballads like the absolutely beautiful `Boulevard of broken dreams' which has been a worldwide smash hit and `Give me novacaine', `Whatsername' (which talks about running into someone from way back, trying to remember her name and what could possibly be going on in her life since then) and the tender `Wake me up when September ends'.<br /><br />`She's a rebel' is an energetic punk rocker, reminiscent of their earlier sounds.<br /><br />Then there are the two very ambitious medleys: `Homecoming' which weaves through a medley of 5 songs, each great and diverse in style.<br /><br />Arguably the highlight of the disc is the other medley, `Jesus of surbubia'. Wow! Very hard to describe this song. Here again, Greenday take one through a variety of styles. Opening with the rocky `Jesus of surbubia', the downtempo `City of the damned', the pace picks up a bit with the rebellious sounding `I don't care', then drops for `Dearly beloved' which is a retro sounding number with great cooing backing vocals, then closing with `Tales of another broken home', another rousing rocker.<br /><br />A very ambitious CD which more than delivers. Not your usual boring top 40 fare.

I love this song, even if it does repeat itself a whole lot. 0553573403|5.0|This book is not the prototypical fantasy novel, but it is the best. It has in heaps and droves what many lack: verisimilitude. There are paragons of virtue, but they are not immune to the plotting of the wicked. There are villains as foul as any laid down in any fiction, but many express virtues when least expected. You see many sides to the story, and see many viewpoints. You could easily sympathize with the villains, so human are their motivations.<br /><br />In grand style and sweeping vision comes A Game of Thrones, the first book of A Song of Ice and Fire. If you have ever read fantasy, this is the book against which all others will be measured. If you have not, then this is the book which will shatter the genre barrier. The story is riveting, the characters are complex and captivating. There is so much nobility, treachery, deceit, murder, and foreboding that it threatens to overwhelm, but that is the rollercoaster ride that Martin puts you on. By the end, you are virtually guaranteed to laugh, cry, and want to reach into the pages and strangle some of the characters, both good and evil, for the foolish mistakes they make or the wicked deeds they commit.<br /><br />This book is truly a once in a lifetime master work, not to be missed. The backdrop is a medieval setting that feels more historical than fantastic. Martin leaves powerful wizards and ancient magic orders to other novelists, and in its place gives you a realistic world that is at once both incredibly broad and amazingly detailed. But it is the characters that will have you wanting for more when the last page is turned, characters at once both noble and flawed, wise and foolish, evil but principled; never has a book characterized so many fascinating characters that all seemed so tangible.<br /><br />This book is a paragon of both art and artifice. It is well-written, to be sure: vividly imagined and artfully set to the page. Martin is a master of prose, and his style effortlessly flows from description to dialogue to flashback without ever wandering or wasting pages. But truly, it is the artifice that will capture you. There are so many plots and stories swirling about in this soup that it threatens to overwhelm the reader, but Martin steers you through adeptly, showing you many points of view, until both the characters and the story have truly come to life, which makes every victory and tragedy the characters experience your own to feel.<br /><br />You are forewarned: if you read this book, you will be swept away, and you will scarcely be able to put it down, nor any of its sequels, until you have devoured every morsel of this tasty literary meal.on to dialogue to flashback without ever wandering or wasting pages. But truly, it is the artifice that will capture you. There are so many plots and stories swirling about in this soup that it threatens to overwhelm the reader, but Martin steers you through adeptly, showing you many points of view, until both the characters and the story have truly come to life, which makes every victory and tragedy the characters experience your own to feel.<br /><br />You are forewarned: if you read this book, you will be swept away, and you will scarcely be able to put it down, nor any of its sequels, until you have devoured every morsel of this tasty literary meal.

0345475674|5.0|Robert Harris has been one of my favorite authors for many years now since his groundbreaking Fatherland and the equally gripping Enigma and Archangel.  At first I was suprised to see Harris turn in the direction of First Century Roman Empire, but it turns out to be one of the best surprises of the year. <br />The novel reads very well, both informative and entertaining.  Harris does take some liberty with the events, but all in all they are true to the accounts of what actually happened.  The inclusion of Pliny the elder is truly great, since it is his accounts of what happened, that actually allow us a glimpse as to what it was really like. <br />As one would guess, the novel climaxes with the eruption of Mount Vesuvius, and like all truly great historical fictions, even though you know what is going to happen, you find yourself hoping that everyone will make it out alive.  That is the true sign of a great novel. <br />For those who want to learn a little, yet still enjoy a truly great story, this is certainly a book to pick up.
B00005K9LK|5.0|1982 was perhaps the key year for Judas Priest, as their biggest single, You've Got Another Thing Coming, was released on their ninth studio album, \\"Screaming for Vengeance\\". With this in mind, it is hard to believe that aforementioned chart-topper is actually one of the weaker songs on this classic stab of metal, which features some of the most memorable songs in all of Priest's catalog, including: <br /> <br />Screaming for Vengeance - pure speed! Halford's falsetto, and a killer solo break. <br /> <br />The Hellion/Electric Eye - the sing-a-long classic, the riffs on this song never get tired. <br /> <br />Devil's Child - the \\"AC/DC\\"-ish closer, showing that the band knows how to property execute a breakdown. <br /> <br />Fever - an underappreciated song, this ballad explodes at its climax. <br /> <br />Although the production is definitely a hindering factor in the quality of this album, there is no doubt in my mind that \\"Screaming for Vengeance\\" is within my top three favourite albums from Judas Priest. The band has never sounded tighter, with the possible exception of the ridiculously-good \\"Painkiller\\". Even the lyrical content is better than on most Priest material, speaking of government oppression (Electric Eye), retribution (Screaming for Vengeance) and of course, women (Devil's Child, Fever, (Take These) Chains). A definitely must-have from the kings of metal.

0930289455|3.0|Alan Moore's Batman: The Killing Joke is often considered one of the pinacles of Batman comics, ranking up there with Frank Miller's work on Dark Knight Returns and Year One.  While it is a fine graphic novel that gives one of Batman's most notorious villains a plausible and sympathetic backstory, I find that as a Batman story, it is sorely lacking. <br /> <br />The story revolves around the Joker, who has once again broken out of Arkham Asylum.  However, this time, instead of attempting to rob a bank or steal a priceless jem or anything like that, the Joker has a much more sinister mission in mind:  to prove that even the most sane men can be driven over the edge by causing Commissioner Gordon to go insane.  He leads the commissioner on a nightmarish journey into a world where nothing seems to make sense, including an attack on Barbara Gordon, also known as Batgirl, that will change her character forever.  All the while the Batman is working frantically to locate the Joker and bring him to justice. <br /> <br />However, the real story in the book occurs in flashbacks that tell how the Joker became a sinister, insane criminal.  He is portrayed sympathetically, and even his descent into crime seems to make a remarkable amount of sense.  It becomes apparant how the Joker was ultimately driven over the edge and became a disfigured, raving lunatic.  However, one thing to note is that this is only a possible origin of the Joker, so nothing is set in stone. <br /> <br />The artwork in the book is excellent and detailed.  It superbly sets the stage for a dark and brooding tale.  Even the flashbacks seem archaic and fitting.  All in all, it's some of the best artwork in a Batman book from the era it was written in. <br /> <br />However, what I find to be the ultimate failing of this books is the characterization, particularly that of Batman.  For years we have read stories about the grim and vengeful Dark Knight, an obsessive man dedicated to stopping evil that has a particular hatred of his mortal enemy, the Joker.  However, in this comic... we don't see that side of Batman at all.  From the very onset of the story, Batman is trying to talk to the Joker about helping to rehabilitate him, and even after the Joker performs several attrocities during the course of the story that by all means should fill Batman with a righteous fury, he sticks to this mission.  It seems incongruous with the Batman we know and love, especially when contrasted to how he reacted to the Joker's murder of Jason Todd.  Batman acts far too nice to the Joker in this story. <br /> <br />I also have to question the violence and 'mature' elements of this story.  While it makes sense that the Joker would employ appalling and uncomfortable methods for trying to drive Gordon insane, it almost seems like Moore was trying to see how far he could push things and what he could get away with.  A lot of what happens to the commissioner doesn't really add to the story, but seems to be there more for shock value. <br /> <br />And my last complaint with this story is the ending.  After this entire ordeal, with one character being seriously injured and another tortured, we get treated to one of the most out-of-character Batman moments in all of comics.  The ending just doesn't feel right at all, and the story could have ended several pages earlier and been much better. <br /> <br />In the end, the comic isn't bad at all.  It's a Joker story that adds a lot of potential depth to the character and changes some things in the Batman universe.  However, if you're looking for a good Batman story, this isn't a prime choice.  It's a good story to read once for the plot point that has an impact on the entire Batman universe, but otherwise, the comic just isn't entirely enjoyable or deep enough to pick up time and time again.

B0006L16N8|5.0|I came of age in the 80's and have always viewed Coldplay as a logical extension of that sound.  I love New Order and Kraftwerk, so the influence there is music to my ears.  I have not found a group that carries this sound as Coldplay does so close to my heart.  I have been a fan since the beginning and I expect Coldplay to follow their own pace...and I will follow them.  I can't stand the pressure to \\"do something different.\\"  It is different.  The synth sound, etc is stronger, but I would not want it to be too \\"different\\" because I love the core Coldplay sound.  I know it stings them when they are criticized by the likes of Thom Yorke and his snotty self and it shouldn't.  They are not trying to \\"be\\" any other band, and Radiohead, though immensely talented has had a hard time reproducing something as good as The Bends. Yorke's attitude has started to turn me away from Radiohead anyway. I am pleased that Coldplay are SO consistently good. I love this album.  It enriches me.  \\"Talk\\" is my favorite song so far...but I love \\"White Shadows\\" and I also love the end of \\"Fix You.\\"  I do not find this album in the least disappointing.  On the contrary I just can't find a lot of fault with it.  People try so hard to find some sound that Coldplay fits into.  I have heard people say oh they are trying to sound like U2. I have been listening to U2 since the beginning as well, and although there is a distinctive UK sound to both, U2 has a unique sound and is instantly recognized as U2 no matter what experimental turn they have taken.  Anyone confusing the two needs to get their ears checked.  I believe Coldplay has their own unique instantly recognizable sound and in the age of 40 bands who all sound like variations of Lincoln park, I am just so grateful to have Coldplay.  I am not sorry for the wait...it was worth it.
B0002KVUKW|4.0|Showing you where I stand, Frank Langella will always be Dracula to me, and Laurence Olivier will always be Abraham Van Helsing to me. Also, so you know,this is not Dracula in the most traditional sense. If this is what you are looking for, then you are better off looking in the direction of Lugosi or Langella. All of that said, this is an excellent movie well worth watching. It pays tribute to the many horrors of the past. (Frankenstein, Dracula, The Wolfman) It even starts by showing the first scene in black and white. (A nice tribute to the black and white era of horror movies.) While paying tribute to this time in the history of horror, the movie takes a closer look at the hero (Van Helsing). While Peter Cushing (Christopher Lee's enemy)  and Laurence Olivier (Frank Langella's enemy) handled the role of Van Helsing with style and charm, this movie explores the inner struggles of Van Helsing. This time, the hero is kind of an Indiana Jones type. (A basically good person who has faults and is willing to operate outside the law if he has to.) Van Helsing's allies are well placed. (The woman who carries a personality not so different from himself, and the side kick who is a little more innocent and nervous, but loyal and dedicated.) While many of us are used to the silent and frightening Frankenstein as portrayed in horror, the Frankenstein here is a little closer to the actual book. (Someone who is articulate and carries a deep sadness.) Dracula doesn't quite dominate the screen the way Frank Langella does, but again, this movie is more about Van Helsing. But Dracula does have an acceptable amount of screen time, and despite his evil, he has his charm. The scenery is not exactly up to Director Franco Zeffirelli, but it is memorable. I'm not one who really cares for special effects, but this is one rare case where the special effects flatter the events instead of distracting from them. I don't want to say too much and possibly ruin the movie for you, but they cleverly avoid the cliche happy ending. If you like this movie, I can suggest the following items as well. The book \\"Frankenstein\\" (1831) by Mary Shelley, the Lugosi version of \\"Dracula,\\" (1931), \\"Horror of Dracula,\\" (1958), and Frank Langella's \\"Dracula\\" (1979).ly avoid the cliche happy ending. B0006L16N8|5.0|Parachutes was good; A Rush of Blood was great; X & Y is not nessecarily better than A RUSH, yet it is an amazing strong follow up.  While there is no drastic progression from the songwriting formula of the previous two albums, the songs are so good that you can forgive this.  The one major change that can be noted is a greater dependence on guitar and synth effects, echoing the great bands of the early 80s such as the Cure and U2.  To produce an album just as strong as A RUSH is a testament to the band's songwriting ability.  The main standout tracks for me are WHAT IF (a great piano ballad), WHITE SHADOWS (a very energetic DAYLIGHT-style track) and A MESSAGE (a little like shiver off parachutes).  However songs such as Fix You, Low Square One are also fantastic; if you were skeptical after hearing the disappointing first single Speed of Sound, don't be.  The remainder of X and Y is as strong an album as Coldplay has ever produced.

B0007GAERG|5.0|I gotta say that ''The Emancipation of Mimi'' is Mariah Carey's best album in many years. I am glad that she has come back singing like she used to , i was dissapointed with her \\"Charmbracelet'' cd because she was practically whispering on all the tracks and everyone knows that she has an amazing voice and i for one am impressed that on ''The Emancipation of Mimi'' she showcases her vocal talent. Having said that , i am also glad that she doesnt over do it by singing in that very high pitch she is capable of doing. Anyway , onto reviewing the tracks. ''It's like that''is the first track and single of the album and is pretty much a great club song. It's beat is infectious and the song itself is lighthearted and fun , and it succeeded in getting Mariah noticed again , ensuring her a place in the top 10 here in Australia.  <br />''We belong together'' is my favourite track on this album and its a beautiful ballad where Mariah successfully conveys her feelings over lost love. Its her 16th number 1 hit in the U.S and keeps her as the most successful female vocalist ever. <br />''Shake it off'' is a mid tempo song which is catchy with a heavy r'n'b vibe , whilst ''Mine again'' is another ballad that showcases Mariah's vocals beautifully on the chorus. <br />''Say somethin'' is the much talked about collabo with Snoop and the Neptunes , and its a breezy party track with Pharrel & Chad's signature sound. ''Stay the night'' is my 2nd favourite track and another that proves how talented Mariah Carey really is and how untalented most of today's current singers are. She can hit the high notes with ease and Kanye West's beat is refreshing alongside Mariah's vocals. <br />''Get your number'' features Jermaine Dupri and i gotta admit that his ''singing''?? is kinda annoying because he sounds like Nelly. Nevertheless , i like this track alot and i actually heard it the othernight at the club , it was great! A cool party track to dance to in my opinion. <br />''One and only'' featuring Twista is a great collabo , Twista actually gets to showcase his great flow alongside Mariah's sultry vocals. <br />''Circles'' is a cool track that demonstrates the return of ''the voice''exceptionally , and ''Your Girl'' is Mariah singing to her desired love about why she should be his. Its a cute track. ''I wish you knew'' is another great ballad that has a ''live'' feel to it and '' To the floor'' sees Mariah collaborating with Nelly on another club friendly track with  a Neptunes beat. However , i wish that Nelly rapped on it instead of singing because he clearly isnt very good at it. The album draws to a close with the lush ''Joyride'' and the incredible ''Fly like a bird''. The former is a wonderful ballad whilst the latter is an amazing gospel track that shows everyone why Mariah Carey is a singer that deserves the respect and recognition that anyone who recognises talent has given her. <br />In the end , regardless of how much she resembles Beyonce on the cover or how various fans claim to like her 90's works better , the latest album from Mariah Carey is a great purchase. Strongly recommended.

B0006L16N8|5.0|I can't possibly think of a way that Coldplay could make a bad album, based on the standards that they have developed from their previous \\"Parachutes\\" and \\"A Rush of Blood to the Head\\". \\"X & Y\\" in my opinion exceeds 'Rush of Blood' with its starry, imaginable lyrics, and wonderful harmonies (that's not to say that 'Rush of Blood' doesn't have those; it's still fantastic!). However, I think 'Parachutes' is their greatest work. The first time I listened to 'X & Y', it just sounded like a blur of Coldplay, I couldn't tell any difference between one song and another (besides the single Speed of Sound), but when I listened to it a few more times, it really started to sink in and I could notice details that made that song unique. For instance, although 'What If' sounds like 'Everything's Not Lost' a bit, it picks up and goes into one of the greatest Coldplay songs ever. I still don't really understand the lyrics to 'Speed of Sound' after listening to it countless times. Something about birds flying at the speed of sound from the underground, I don't know. 'White Shadows', just beautiful. Chris Martin sings it so well. What am I saying? He sings every song well! The Hardest Part strangely is a bit reminiscent of Simon and Garfunkel's \\"Sounds of Silence\\" for some reason. Just the way it sounds.... The little riff in 'Talk' got really stuck in my head when I first started listening to it; awesome song. The worst on the album (but remember it's not bad) would have to be 'Twisted Logic'. I guess it's not that bad, but I'd rather listen to Radiohead's 'My Iron Lung'. As a bigger Radiohead fan that Coldplay, these songs are so similar, except this one doesn't have Thom Yorke's screaming. The diminished chords repeated over and over in the song really remind me of the beginning of 'My Iron Lung', as well as the middle parts sound just like it. Great ending for the album, wants to make me go listen to Radiohead.  Fine, the worst song, but also not bad, would have to be the bonus track, ' 'Til Kingdom Come'. Martin sounds like he has a stuffy nose. I'm also not a big fan of the acoustic stuff, but I like the synth. But it's still a nice song, and I'm glad it's a bonus track and not interweaved in the album.  <br /> <br />Square One - *** (out of ****) <br />What If - **** <br />White Shadows - **** <br />Fix You - ***1/2 <br />Talk - ***1/2 <br />X & Y - *** <br />Speed of Sound - **** <br />A Message - ***1/2 <br />Low - *** <br />The Hardest Part - ***1/2 <br />Swallowed by the Sea - ***1/2 <br />Twisted Logic - *** <br />'Til Kingdom Come - *** <br />Overall - ****  <br /> <br />With a lot of bands without a reputation, you can judge what their album will be like by listening to the single. B00015YVD6|5.0|Tom Hanks had done a couple of TV shows and the producers of \\"Splash\\" really wanted a bigger name actor in their movie.  Daryl Hannah had made a favorable impression in a bit part in \\"Blade Runner\\" but the big \\"name\\" in the announced cast of Splash was John Candy, who was probably paid as much as the rest of the cast combined in the role of brother Freddy.<br /><br />It would have been very easy for the movie to become a broad farce with Candy and Eugene Levy in the love story of the man and the mermaid, but writers Lowell Ganz and Babaloo Mandel found the right note between love story and comedy, and the cast pulls off both.  The comedy varies between clever and slapstick, and seeing the film again 20 years later still made me laugh at parts.  As expected, Candy and Levy do the heavy lifting in the comedy department, and they are both hilarious in their respective scenes.  The whole movie wouldn't work at all, though, if we didn't believe in the central love story - and Hanks and Hannah make it work.<br /><br />Hannah is a mermaid apparently not unlike Disney's Ariel.  She has a tail when wet, and legs when dry.  Hanks is Allen Bauer, who has inherited his father's wholesale produce business along with brother Freddy.  As a child Allen suddenly jumped into the water off Cape Cod, where the child mermaid rescues him until the adults can fetch him from the water.<br /><br />As an adult Allen has commitment issues and admits he doesn't love his girlfriend.  After a friend's wedding he returns to Cape Cod for a little nostalgia.  Another boating accident results in another mermaid rescue, but the \\"girl\\" runs away as Allen regains consciousness on shore.<br /><br />The mermaid fetches Allen's wallet from the ocean floor and follows a map to track Allen down in New York City.  She climbs onto dry land at the statue of liberty - lacking a tail and clothes - and is taken into custody by the police.  They call the guy who owns the wallet she's carrying.  (The mermaid, of course, can't speak English...)<br /><br />So Allen and the Mermaid are united again, where the attraction is powerful and mutual.  The Mermaid learns English watching television for an afternoon (this makes the rest of the movie easier!) and she decides to make her American name \\"Madison\\" while looking at a street sign for Madison Avenue.  (Many Americans subsequently chose \\"Madison\\" for their daughters after this movie.)<br /><br />Allen only knows Madison is \\"foreign\\".  Madison's time on land is limited.  (For reasons that aren't exposed in the film.) Levy portrays a renegade pseudo-scientist who has been searching for a mermaid his entire career.  When one swims past while he's diving at Cape Cod he is startled.  Then he sees a newspaper photo of a nude girl at the Statue of Liberty that looks a lot like the mermaid...<br /><br />The plot isn't difficult to guess, but the performances are full of funny and touching flourishes that make you laugh and care about these characters.  This isn't really a 5-star movie - but I couldn't choose 4 1/2.  It's a pleasant way to spend some time with your own sweetie.So Allen and the Mermaid are united again, where the attraction is powerful and mutual.  The Mermaid learns English watching television for an afternoon (this makes the rest of the movie easier!) and she decides to make her American name \\"Madison\\" while looking at a street sign for Madison Avenue.  (Many Americans subsequently chose \\"Madison\\" for their daughters after this movie.)    Allen only knows Madison is \\"foreign\\".  Madison's time on land is limited.  (For reasons that aren't exposed in the film.) Levy portrays a renegade pseudo-scientist who has been searching for a mermaid his entire career.  When one swims past while he's diving at Cape Cod he is startled.  Then he sees a newspaper photo of a nude girl at the Statue of Liberty that looks a lot like the mermaid...    The plot isn't difficult to guess, but the performances are full of funny and touching flourishes that make you laugh and care about these characters.  This isn't really a 5-star movie - but I couldn't choose 4 1/2.  It's a pleasant way to spend some time with your own sweetie.
B0006L16N8|5.0|simply put, Coldplay keeps it real... this is a band that evolves without trying to reinvent itself, and the results are captivating... also, as i try to find themes with most albums, this one evokes a sense of old U2 here and there, and i love that feeling...There is definitely a U2 quality (which I have noticed before) in \\"Square One\\".  I also notice some sounds that remind me of the album \\"Synchronicity\\" from The Police... anyway...  I really like \\"White Shadows\\" although it ends in an odd fashion for me;  also, I think \\"Fix You\\" will be on the radio at some point, perhaps even with a  modified `radio mix' to speed up the beginning, but the chorus and up tempo ending are classic Coldplay-I can't wait to play the last 1.5min of that song REALLY loud.  \\"Talk\\" is maybe my least favorite of my first few listens, and while catchy, the way the guitar melody echoes the lyrics is actually a bit annoying for me.  I've never heard any Beatles/Oasis-like stuff from them, but I did in \\"X & Y\\", and by the way, this is a fabulous love song-but I don't think it is number one radio chart material (loved the violin finish by the way).  What can I say, \\"Speed of Sound\\" is a great song.  The piano riff of \\"Clocks\\" and the wandering melody of \\"Yellow\\", I like it more with each listen.  (side note, I would really love Chris to put out a piano only album).  \\"A Message\\" is a really nice song, and perhaps the song that would most easily fit on one of the first two albums.  This song could also be the next single.  An interesting guitar riff about 2/3rds of the way through the song brings that early U2 sound back a bit too, and definitely cements this album as more flowery than A Rush of Blood... <br />\\"Low\\" now this is a great song, but again, I am struck that this should be Bono singing-but don't get me wrong, I think U2 is one of the best rock bands of any era, and I don't think Coldplay is copying them, I just think a lot of what pulls me toward each is a similar quality of guitar and vocals-and actually leaves me wanting a bit more of the piano on this album.  \\"The Hardest Part\\" gets my vote for biggest chart topper, which only means I think it is a song my mom would like.  Something about the arrangement reminds me of songs I have heard before, which isn't a bad thing with Chris at the helm, and it does have the piano I like.  \\"Swallowed by the Sea\\" is indeed a lullaby, and showcases what the world loves about Chris' voice (I think he and Dave Matthews should do a duet).  This one reminds me a bit of \\"In My Place\\"-I can't wait to learn the words to this one so I can belt it out in the shower, and I think this too would have been a solid as a their first single; it seems like a holdover from the Parachutes album.  I like this song a lot.  Finally, \\"Twisted Logic\\" is really fun, and I think this song will wear out the volume button as you can't not turn it up at the chorus, and the up and down tempo makes me want to sway.  Also, I like his voice on this song best, really shows his low and high range without seeming gimmicky, while the guitar is actually a bit more Beatles-esque again, and less The Edge.  Also, a great song and I really hope they play this in concert as I can't wait to hear it after one too many beers.  The hidden track is just that, hidden and is a nice addition to round out this album.  On the whole, this is a wonderful album, and maybe it is just me, but there is a softer edge (i used the word flowery above) that maybe is a result of band maturity, or fatherhood.  But the gorgeous layers of sound that result are delightful. <br /> <br />

B000001E18|4.0|Zooropa is a classic example of an album that doesn't grab you on first listen, but gets under your skin the more you listen to it.  There's nothing here particularly catchy or hooky, save the hideously titled \\"Stay (Faraway, So Close!),\\" which is probably the album's low point, although it's still a decent song.  The tracks on Zooropa have a great deal of variety- some would call it \\"inconsistency,\\" but it's a positive thing here.<br /><br />First we have the title track, which unfolds slowly and beautifully.  It has a dreamlike quality created by distorted guitars and airy vocals.  Musically, it's kind of a futuristic take on \\"Where the Streets Have No Name,\\" if you can imagine that.  The next highlight is \\"Numb,\\" and love it or hate it, you've gotta admit it's different.  Blender Magazine snidely referred to it as the Edge \\"rapping an alienated shopping list over a techno song.\\"  Yeah, it does sound like that, but I appreciate its uniqueness and I really like it.<br /><br />\\"Lemon\\" is my favorite song on the album, with its mellow mood and incredible vocals from both Bono and the Edge.  Other standouts include the infectious \\"Daddy's Gonna Pay For Your Crashed Car\\" and the bass heavy \\"Some Days Are Better Than Others,\\" the latter of which has an amazing distorted guitar solo.  Finally, there's \\"The Wanderer,\\" starring (not \\"featuring\\") Johnny Cash.  I love this song, but it doesn't belong on here, it belongs on a Johnny Cash album (indeed, it showed up on his \\"Essential\\" collection).  You wouldn't know U2 were performing on it unless you were told so.  Bono doesn't even sing, except for some backing vocals near the end.  Like I said, though, it's a fantastic, moody song that does suit Cash perfectly.<br /><br />The fact that Zooropa is an overall strong effort is surprising considering how fractured and uneven it is- this feels like a b-sides/outtakes collection rather than a true album.  It's a good follow-up to the brilliant Achtung Baby and builds on its experimentation.

B00009Z576|5.0|4.5 Stars  I just got Drama and I have to say that it ranks among my top 5 Yes albums (along with Close to the Edge, Yes Album, Going for the One and Relayer). Trevor Horn does a great job on vocals and sounds close enough to Jon Anderson (though sometimes straining a bit at the high notes). The backing vocals of Squire and Howe help to make the vocals sound familiar, like \\"classic\\" Yes. Geoff Downes' keyboards and synths are very textural and add a lot to the music. One thing I really noticed about this album is the energy and freshness that the Buggles seem to bring to the old Yes table, adapting Yes to the times and making them relevant, considering prog was almost dead.     Alan White is good as always. Chris Squire's bass stands out and drives the music. Steve Howe's guitar is rougher, almost metallic at times, like in the intro to Machine Messiah. Overall, Drama is more hard rock than other Yes albums, recalling the full sound of Relayer a bit though being more restrained and not as progressive. That being said, Drama is an interesting mix of progressive rock and light almost \\"new wave\\" sensibilities. While retaining the familiar Yes sound, this makes the music more relevant to the times, rather than sounding like a dated, struggling progressive band puttering out. In other words, its ability to sympathize with the musical climate of 1980 makes it better.     \\"Machine Messiah\\", \\"Does it Really Happen\\" and \\"Tempus Fugit\\" are all great Yes classics that stand up to the band's previous work.  \\"White Car\\" is a nice short keyboard track. Into the Lens is a good song, though you can't help but notice the weirdness of the lyric \\"I am a camera, camera\\". \\"Run Through the Light\\"  leans toward new wave and is perhaps the weakest song on here, but is still good. If you have an open mind about this album and the absense of Anderson and Wakeman (and can stand synths), you'll see that it is good in its own right. It sounds somewhat like \\"Going for the One\\", only a little more recent and more to the rock side like the tracks \\"Going for the One\\" and \\"Parallels\\". Simultaneously, it also sounds more like \\"Relayer\\" (which makes sense because producer Eddie Offord produced Relayer). I got this album because of good reviews and I have to say that they are right. It is an unexpectedly quality album after the lackluster Tormato and the band's split.    While the album itself is only 37 minutes long, it is packed with 10 bonus tracks that bring the total to 79 minutes. And though I would have really enjoyed hearing some live music from the Drama tour, especially \\"White Car\\" which was apparently a longer keyboard solo on tour, the interesting Howe/Squire/White tracks \\"Have We Really Got to Go  Through This\\" and \\"Song No. 4 (Satellite)\\" almost make up for it, and the aborted Paris session tracks WITH Anderson and Wakeman show just how good this incarnation of Yes is. Too bad this was their only album.

B000002J1M|4.0|On their previous album, Nursery Cryme, the band had really solidified as an outstanding progressive rock group (thanks to the addition of Phil Collins on drums and Steve Hackett on lead guitar). On this album, they took the Victorian-style hard rock (or \\"baroque and roll,\\" as a friend of mine likes to call it) of Nursery Cryme, and added another dimension to it. Ultimately, it didn't work as well as it could, but in some areas, it succeeded better than its predecessor. <br /> <br />The first area is that of a smoother flow of music within each song. Transitions are not as noticable as they were on the last album. The first track on the album, \\"Watcher of the Skies,\\" moves brilliantly from Tony Banks's mellotron intro (scored at just the right amplitude, an improvement over \\"The Fountain of Salmacis\\") into the main body of the song, with the other musicians fading up after a few minutes. The cool thing here is that even Hackett's guitar and Collins's drumming emulate the otherworldly hum of an alien starship, building upon the motif already established so well by Banks. I know I'm repeating what others have probably said, but I think this is the second best track on the album.   <br /> <br />Another of these areas is the sci/fi fantasy narrative motif in several of the songs, as well as Gabriel's penchant for assuming the roles of different characters within those lyrics. The best example of this is \\"Get 'Em Out By Friday,\\" a science fiction tragicomedy taking place in the semi-distant future, where the genes of unborn humans can be manipulated to control their height. The story involves the inhabitants of a flat being evicted to make way for shorter, more perfect human residents (perfect because Styx Enterprises, the company behind the evictions, can fit twice as many people in a flat due to their reduced height). In this song, Gabriel seems more comfortable moving between the character dialogue (you have to read the CD Booklet to see who exactly is saying what), and he also uses his impressive vocal range to give each character a unique voice. Sadly, this song loses points because, like most of Nursery Cryme, this album suffers from bad production. Gabriel's vocals on \\"Get 'Em Out By Friday\\" are so low-key (especially towards the middle of the song) that one can really only enjoy it if they listen to the song through headphones. However, Mike Rutherford's bass work is very good. This song is one of the rare moments when they brought Rutherford's instrument towards the foreground. <br /> <br />And now we come to the album's centerpiece, \\"Supper's Ready.\\" There's not too much I can say about this that won't be repeating what others have already said, but I'll do my best to make my thoughts sound like my own. This song is, simply put, amazing. It's based on a supernatural experience that Peter Gabriel's wife supposedly had, and somehow concludes with the ultimate battle between Heaven and Hell being fought and won. Each member of the group is at their peak, exploding with an energy and a passion not seen at any other point on this album (though some of the songs are good, they don't come close to this one). The transitions between chapters are surprisingly crisp, and the way the band manages to merge the overall theme of their music with what's happening in Gabriel's vocals is stunning. Especially noteworthy are the \\"charge\\" feel of Collins's drums in Part III (coupled with an amazing guitar solo from Hackett), the organ solo by Banks in Part VI, and the epic grandeur with which the song wraps up (the band reprising musical and lyrical themes from earlier in the song, but giving them a hell of a lot more thunder). One can almost see their souls igniting. The song seems to lose direction during Part V, but it gets back on track in a BIG way. \\"Supper's Ready\\" is where three of this album's four stars come from. An epic masterpiece. <br /> <br />Unfortunately, as I said earlier, there are still some production issues. The band still had difficulty finding a happy medium in the final mixing. Also, the shorter songs in between the longer ones seemed to go off in directions different from the musical direction that Tracks 1, 3, and 6 were going in. I do enjoy \\"Horizon's,\\" though. It reminds me of Yes's \\"Mood For A Day,\\" and in a way, almost serves as an intro to \\"Supper's Ready\\" (at least in my mind). I have to be in just the right mood to listen to the middle of the album. But overall, the album is outstanding. The band had proven they were both amazing musicians and avid storytellers (the staples of any prog rock band), but there was still something lacking. Something that would finally be found on their next album.
B0006L16N8|5.0|While X&Y seems to be headed in a somewhat different direction compared to their two previous albums, it definitely doesn't disappoint. Here's my song-breakdown on what Coldplay's newest album has to offer: <br /> <br />Square One - 8.4/10 - An ambitious start to what could be called an ambitious album in many ways. Maintains an up-tempo beat and rhythm throughout most of the song until it closes itself off with a final, meaningful and mellowed-down verse. Opening the album with a song like this sets up a clear distinction between this album and Parachutes/ARoBttH immediately. <br /> <br />What If - 8/10 - A slower, more sentimental song that seems to focus on the possibilities of what would or could happen if a loved one left you or someday decided he/she didn't need you anymore. It seems perfect for a situation where a couple might be going through an argument, but one person might be thinking ahead of what could happen if the problems at hand weren't resolved in the present. Sounds a bit 'too' moody at times, but does a decent job at not crossing that line into desperation. <br /> <br />White Shadows - 9.2/10 - A song that stood out from others immediately to me, thanks to its haunting and up-tempo nature. The lyrics and meanings behind the song seem to be a bit vague to decipher, but the music is what propels this song in the right direction. Despite the somewhat-confusing lyrics, the way the song closes itself off with the final verse is probably my favorite part of the track. <br /> <br />Fix You - 9/10 - Quite possibly the most beautiful song on the album, although its slow pace might not appeal to everyone at first. The message it delivers is full of hope and dedication for someone who's going through a rough time. The latter part of the track reminds me of a gospel reciting the lyrics, which in itself seems to into inject a feeling of hope and ambition into the whole theme of this song. Definitely one of Coldplay's best that will stick around and be loved for a while to come. <br /> <br />Talk - 7.9/10 - I didn't enjoy this as much as the other songs (partially because the lyrics aren't really strong, in my opinion) - but that's not to say it's bad at all. While it breaks away from the slower or more meaningful lyrics to set a style of its' own, it covers ground with some awesome guitar riffs to accompany the great beat.  <br /> <br />X & Y - 9.6/10 - Best song on the album for me. I got lost in the haunting lyrics and rhythm of the song the first time I heard it. When, \\"I know something is broken, and i'm trying to fix it... etc,\\" kicks in near the beginning, it reminds me of guitar being played in the Trans-Siberian Orchestra's rendition of 'Carol of the Bells'. This, when combined with the mesmerizing beat of the drums and the moody lyrics, sets up that perfect melancholy effect to drift away to. Simply magnificent. <br /> <br />Speed Of Sound - 9.1/10 - I found myself loving this song when the single came out... but having heard all the other songs from the album, the initial appeal wore off a little bit. Regardless - the song still sounds fantastic, and has fitting lyrics to back up the pacing of the song. Another keeper. <br /> <br />A Message - 7.5/10 - Started out as a song I didn't like/listen to too much, but has somewhat started to grow on me after listening to it more often. A simple song, but meaningful and to-the-point. Might take some time to develop a taste for and start liking, but still isn't one of the stronger tracks on the album for me. <br /> <br />Low - 9/10 - Another song that I ignored at first, but again, became a favorite of mine after giving it a chance. The first time this song played while I was driving was when I realized that this song is just amazing. It feels as if the spoon/glass effects near the middle/end of the song bring out the rest of the track and help enhance it. Overall, a great song that helps add balance to the album. <br /> <br />The Hardest Part - 9.2/10 - A song I fellin love with immediately, because it describes and reminds me of a time in the past which I can recall very vividly. That in itself is the main factor in why it's become a personal favorite of mine. Regardless of the song's meaning, it sounds beautiful - but could take a little while to start growing on you.  <br /> <br />Swallowed In The Sea - 9.4/10 - I'd be lying if I said that the lyrics to any other song from this album even come close to touching the beauty of the lyrics that make up this song. It's pure poetic bliss, accompanied by music that starts off calmly, but gets more intense as the song goes on. Aside from X&Y, this is probably my second favorite song on the album. <br /> <br />Twisted Logic - 8.7/10 - Chalk this song up as yet another one that I didn't like to start off with, but one that quickly grew on me. I have to give this song props - the lyrics are the most unique out of the entire album. \\"You'll go backwards, but then... you'll go forwards again\\" - I've had those lyrics stuck in my head since the first time I heard this song. A distinguished track that makes for a great way to cap the album off (aside from the next bonus track). <br /> <br />Til Kingdom Come - 8.9/10 - This will either be a love-or-hate track, in my opinion. I personally didn't like it too much at first, but as the growing trend throughout this album continues, I wound up loving this song after listening to it more and more. If it wasn't for the beautiful lyrics, this song would be nothing. Once you gain appreciation for the lyrics, this song is unforgettable. <br /> <br />*How You See The World (Japanese Album Release) - 9.8/10 - Dare I put an unreleased bonus track on the top of my favorites? It's truly a shame that this song wasn't released with the album everywhere besides Japan, because I was surprised at how much I eventually found myself listening to this song over most of the others after some time. It's easy to listen to, and is sung beautifully, accompanied by lyrics that don't disappoint. If you get a opportunity to listen to this, chances are good it won't let you down. <br /> <br /> <br />How would I rank X&Y compared to Coldplay's last two albums? If I had to choose between Parachutes and ARoBttH, i'd give the edge to Parachutes... but I just love the songs from both. My top 6 songs from the previous albums:  <br /> <br />Parachutes - Shiver, Spies, Sparks, Yellow, Trouble, Everything's Not Lost  <br /> <br />ARoBttH - In My Place, The Scientist, Warning Sign, A Rush of Blood to the Head, Amsterdam, Clocks <br /> <br />If I had to pick my favorites from X&Y? As of now, it'd probably be White Shadows, How You See The World, Swallowed In The Sea, X&Y, The Hardest Part and Fix You... but being forced to pick my favorite 6 seems like such a cruel thing to do, since each song has a different and unique feeling to it. <br /> <br />To conclude, i'll say this much. If you haven't heard any of Coldplay's older songs and have any curiosity to what all the `hype' is all about, listen some of the songs I mentioned above from either of the albums. Then, buy X&Y. It's just one of those albums that brings so many different things to the table, that it's hard not to enjoy and appreciate everything it has to offer. <br /> <br /> <br />Overall: 9.3/10 (not an average) <br /> <br />-KB
