0790729652|2.0|This is easily the worst DVD interface I've ever seen. Besides being packaged in Warner's \\"really cheap\\" half-cardboard DVD case, it jumps right into the feature without giving you the menu screen (a pet peeve of mine), and the menu screen itself doesn't even feature a \\"play movie\\" option. In lieu of the most basic scene selection screen is a \\"jump to a scene\\" menu that gives you direct access to a little over half of the movie's chapters. If there were a \\"zero stars\\" available just for the DVD interface and packaging, this would be a shoe-in.<br /><br />The feature itself is not the fantastic film that many would want you to remember, and certainly isn't the finest superhero movie of its age (folks who say that sort of thing apparently haven't seen \\"Superman II.\\" Or the first one for that matter). The titular character barely appears in the first half-hour, and most of the film's focus is instead turned to Jack Nicholson's admittedly good Joker. That'd be fine if Bruce Wayne and Batman got anything near the same treatment, but they don't. Wayne is given little characterization, but comes across as a bumbling geek rather than a dashing playboy (something that Keaton's hammy acting and Billy Joel haircut don't help in the least bit). The choreography is laughable, and far too reminiscent of the \\"BAM! POW!\\"-style fights of the '60s live-action series that Burton so obviously tried to get away from. The plot is forced, especially the late reveal that the Joker killed Wayne's parents. Add to that a Batman (with none of the comic version's hatred of guns or killing, mind you) who, in part due to a cowl that won't let him turn his head, comes across as more buffoonish than menacing, and you have the recipe for a two hour long film that can't decide on whether it wants to be a '60s campfest or a grim, weird Burton film.<br /><br />If you want to see good Batman, check out the Animated series that debuted following the sequel to this film, \\"Batman Returns.\\" The successful Batman movies were a great deal of the reason for the cartoon's existence, and the series outshines the movie in every way. You can pick it up in season box-sets, or you can start with one of the two Batman theatrical releases worth watching (not counting the not-yet-released \\"Batman Begins\\"), \\"Mask of the Phantasm.\\" Incidentally, the other of those two films, the '60s Batman movie, is also on DVD.ful Batman movies were a great deal of the reason for the cartoon's existence, and the series outshines the movie in every way. B000002JPA|5.0|Nuff said- this is the best- THE BEST Dream Theater ever- This is the best Prog Album ever!!!! YYYEEEAAAHHH!!!!!
B00097DX3U|2.0|It took me a week to write this review because I kept hoping further listening would make something click and this album would turn out to be great.  After their monstrous eponymous debut, I approached Audioslave's sophomore album with great expectations.  Formed from the ashes of Soundgarden and Rage Against the Machine, \\"Audioslave\\" put the lie to the snide \\"supergroup\\" remarks with scorching vocals from Chris Cornell and jaw dropping guitar work from Tom Morello.  Unfortunately, \\"Out of Exile\\" is a pretty dull album that hardly features Cornell at his best, and largely wastes Morello.  Not every song is bad, far from it, but by and large the album fails to live up to potential, and is genuinely dull after the first five tracks. <br /> <br />It begins strongly enough with \\"Your Time Has Come\\", a scathing anti-war (pro-soldier) number that should have been the first single.  Whether or not you agree with Cornell's politics, you have to admire the sincerity and genuine angst with which he infuses thus one.  Likewise, some of the best guitar riffs can be found on this track, and Brad Wilk's drumming really stands out.  Next is \\"Out of Exile\\" which represents the best of the Soundgarden/Rage Against the Machine fusion that worked so well on \\"Audioslave\\".  The lyrics and vocals are classic Soundgarden (\\"When you come down to take me home/send my soul away..\\") but the syncopated pacing and driving bass line are pure Rage; another strong track. <br /> <br />The third track is the first single \\"Be Yourself\\" which in spite of a catchy beat and some nifty guitar work is hopelessly bogged down by insipid lyrics.  \\"To be yourself is all that you can do\\"?  This Sesame Street psychology has been brought to you be the letter \\"A\\" and the number 4.  However, this pop nonsense could be forgiven if the rest of the album lived up to the next track \\"Doesn't Remind Me\\".  A beautiful mix of blues, country and rock this ode to the wisdom that comes with letting go of past mistakes workslyrically and musically and along with \\"Your Time Has Come\\" is one of the two best tracks on the album.  Once again, the drum work really drives this song. <br /> <br />\\"Drown Me Slowly\\" is another solid track which I predict will probably get some decent radio rotation.  Featuring a scorching pace and Cornell's patented wail it's reminiscent of the tracks which didn't make it big on \\"Audioslave\\" but which nonetheless held it together.  It also includes Morello's longest and best solo which flips from an almost hip-hop sound to an Eddie Van Halen-esque conclusion in a way only Morello could pull off. <br /> <br />So five tracks in we have one (albeit catchy) dud, one meat and potatoes song and three really good tunes: so far so good, right?  Unfortunately, things head south pretty quickly from this point on.  \\"Heaven's Dead\\" is a slow song, which is not bad in and of itself, but it has no energy and the lyrics aren't particularly interesting.  It is also way too repetitive, with the ostensible chorus (the shockingly inane \\"Heaven's dead when you get sad...\\") making up three quarters of the song.  Next is \\"The Worm\\" which totally wastes Morello with a guitar line a college house band could come up with; even his solo, which might have felt fresh ten years ago just seems mailed in now.  It also suffers from the same problem of repetitive lyrics featured in \\"Heaven's Dead\\". <br /> <br />\\"Man Or Animal\\" turns things around a little with a bruising tempo and some more great work from Wilk (who is really the silver lining of this album).  Morello throws in some pretty sick guitar work, and even though it feels a little tacked on you have to admire the man's ability.  It's a solid entry, but not enough to turn the album around.  \\"Yesterday to Tomorrow\\" isn't so much bad as dull, with all the finesse of a Metallica ballad.  The same holds true for \\"Dandelion\\" which likewise isn't bad but rather forgettable.  You might not change the radio station when it comes on, but you're not going to seek it out either.   <br /> <br />\\"#1 Zero\\" is another forgettable song that has the distinction of being the most boring song on an album with more than its fair share.  Clocking in at five minutes it feels more like ten and features such lyrical gems as \\"If I need to/I will keep you in the corner of my eye/Corner of my eye\\".  It has the added shame of featuring a riff that sounds like it was lifted from Journey; this could be the worst song Audioslave has ever recorded.  Wrapping things up is \\"The Curse\\" another number that slogs through to a fitting conclusion to the album. <br /> <br />I have to be honest, if this had been an EP featuring only the first five tracks I'd be raving about it.  But you have to consider the entirety of the album, and the second half is pretty much a let down.  Plus, when measured against the first album and the star power of the group, \\"Out of Exile\\" suffers even more by comparison.  If this album had been put out by any number of the pathetic heirs to the Seattle sound I might have been impressed, but when you bring this kind of ammunition to the table, maybe the most distinctive vocalist around and a virtuoso guitar player, and add a bass man and drummer that are nothing to sniff at, you have to expect more.  \\"Out of Exile\\" isn't universally bad, but the good songs suffer from the surrounding tracks, and the result is an album that could have been much, much more. <br /> <br />Jake Mohlman <br />
B0000CDLA7|2.0|I love DT- but this is insulting- I cant go 1 star- but this is close-
0805076476|5.0|I don't really know why I picked up the book Fight Club a few weeks ago.  I pretty much knew the major shocker of the story through word of mouth (it's been out since 1996, after all).  I guess I just wanted to see what all the talk was about.  Gratuitous violence doesn't do a whole lot for me anymore.  Most people would have thought a book called Fight Club would be the last on my list of books to read.  I'm going to be brutally honest, I figured that if Edward Norton and Brad Pitt were willing to do a film based off the book, the book must be decent.  I was not disappointed.<br /><br />The book's style was utterly devoid of any unnecessary components, which, of course, sticks to the majority of the book's theme.  Very direct narrative, very short and simple dialogue.  The story is told to us through the first person perspective of the main character, but his name is never revealed.  This gives the book a sense of \\"everyman\\" that I believe forces, especially, male readers to identify.<br /><br />Our main character is tired of life, tired of his job, tired of wanting to own things only to have those things own him.  It's only after he meets Tyler Durden that he experiences life the way he's always wanted to.  It begins with \\"Hit me as hard as you can,\\" and it ends with mayhem and destruction.  We have men drawn to Tyler and his Fight Clubs because they have no sense of worth without their fights.  It is only when they fight that they feel alive, and it is only through Tyler that they feel loved.  Indeed, Tyler gains quite a cult following waiting on his every command, and our narrator is no different.  Of course, the climax is when men start dying and our narrator decides enough is enough.  He steps in to stop the very thing he'd created with Tyler, and that's when things go downhill.<br /><br />Although the story seems rather unsophisticated, it is anything but.  It is the underlying message within this book that is fascinating.  We do have an entire generation of men out there (perhaps several) who don't know how to be men because they've had no father figure in their lives.  They think to be a man means to fight and to destroy; they've never had someone show them a man doesn't have to do these things to be \\"manly.\\"  We have a whole generation of people who don't know why they do what they do.  Why do they work?  Why do they buy?  Why do they live?<br /><br />This story is tragic, funny, and captivating.  I was instantly engrossed with the characters and the plot.  I highly recommend this book if, for no other reason, than to see an author write in an unconventional manner and prove highly successful.<br /><br />~Scott William Foley, author of [[ASIN:0595360823 Souls Triumphant]]everal) who don't know how to be men because they've had no father figure in their lives.  They think to be a man means to fight and to destroy; they've never had someone show them a man doesn't have to do these things to be \\"manly.\\"  We have a whole generation of people who don't know why they do what they do.  Why do they work?  Why do they buy?  Why do they live?    This story is tragic, funny, and captivating.  I was instantly engrossed with the characters and the plot.  I highly recommend this book if, for no other reason, than to see an author write in an unconventional manner and prove highly successful.      ~Scott William Foley, author of [[ASIN:0595360823 Souls Triumphant]]
B000021XS0|5.0|This may be the BEST DT album- if your new to the band- START HERE!!!! This kicks butt!!! WHat an amazing album!!!!
1400032717|4.0|They say never to judge a book by its cover, but with The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time, that is exactly what I did.  Sorry, folks, but I simply could not resist the orange cover with the cut out image of an upside-down dog.  I thought to myself, \\"If that novel is anywhere near as interesting as the cover, I'll have spent my money well.\\"  Guess what?  I did.<br /><br />Simply reading the back cover of this book, I had a fairly good idea of what to expect, or so I thought.  Well, my friends, I was wrong.  Our protagonist, Christopher, according to the back of the book, decides to investigate the murder of a neighborhood dog.  Oh, and he knows every country's capital in the world and all the prime numbers up to 7, 057.  Oh, and he hates anything involving the color yellow.  Oh, and he can't tolerate being physically touched.  You would think I would have been smart enough to figure it out.  I wasn't.  Christopher is autistic.<br /><br />Suddenly, the book took on a whole new dimension.  I don't know anything about autism beyond what I learned in Rain Man, and no matter how much I love that movie, I know that Hoffman's character was only a glimmer into the world of autism.  I was very excited when I found out that the author, Mark Haddon, had worked with autistics quite a bit as a younger man.  I really trusted him to give me an accurate depiction of this world I knew nothing about.<br /><br />Well, I still don't know how accurate his depiction was, but I do have to admit that it made for fascinating reading.  While the murder of the neighborhood dog is an interesting concept, it was made even more so by using the unique perspective of Christopher.  You must understand that Christopher doesn't think the way that we think.  Christopher doesn't experience emotion the way we experience emotion.  Having said this, however, this book proves that Christopher is not so different from us at all.<br /><br />Christopher takes us for a very interesting journey as he deals with real life issues in a manner that we, surprisingly, can relate to quite easily.  Granted, the specifics of how he deals with them are unusual; for instance, I don't believe that most of us will run through all of the prime numbers we possibly can in order to calm ourselves, nor do I believe that most of us determine what sort of day we will have by the number of red cars we see in the morning.  We all experience fear, loss, and disappointment, however, and those are some of the unifying experiences of being a human being.  I'm really afraid I can't tell you much more about the book without spoiling virtually everything, but you'll have to take my word when I say there are some really interesting, and unexpected, developments.<br /><br />Okay, so let's talk about style.  When you're writing from the perspective of a character that is not likely to express emotion in a forthcoming manner, there tends to be a lack of emotional punch.  Instead, the author presents his character in such a fashion that it is quite easy to empathize with his situation, if not with the character himself.  Meaning, we may not understand his thought processes, but we certainly do understand how WE would feel if put in his situation.  We think about how we would react, and then we read how he reacts.<br /><br />There are many, many, many digressions as our protagonist stops to delve into all sorts of explanations on math problems, science lessons, as well as present many diagrams aiding in their depiction.  Happily, these are not speed bumps in the story, although it may sound otherwise.  Rather, as already stated, the whole book features the perspective of a boy who is autistic and the book must be true to that perspective at all times.  The fact is-that is the way he thinks!  To expect a tone other than what it being presented in the novel is quite unreasonable.<br /><br />So, I would recommend that you read this novel.  It is a captivating study in character and style, and also quite informative.  It is atypical in almost every manner, and for me, that's a great experience.  And seriously, don't you want to know who murdered the dog?  It's not who you would expect.<br /><br />~Scott William Foley, author of [[ASIN:0595360823 Souls Triumphant]]manner, and for me, that's a great experience.  And seriously, don't you want to know who murdered the dog?  It's not who you would expect.    ~Scott William Foley, author of [[ASIN:0595360823 Souls Triumphant]]

Everything but Leper Messiah is awesome (not to say Leper is bad!). This is THE ideal metal CD. The only reason I have CDs I like more is because I've listened to this soooo many times. Get it now! 0060934719|2.0|I like Neil Gaiman. I really do. I liked Neverwhere, and I loved American Gods, both Gaiman novels.<br /><br />Stardust, however, is a completely different story. No pun intended.<br /><br />I can't believe this book is by the same author that I've read in the past. It seems so inadequate compared to his other works. It's supposed to be in the spirit of fairy tales, but it came up woefully short.<br /><br />Major issues I have with Stardust include the facts that it wasn't consistent. I was a fourth of the way through the novel before I even had the main characters figured out. The plot was convoluted and didn't become apparent until over halfway through. There was no sense of urgency, I didn't care about anyone in the novel, and furthermore, it took every ounce of strength I had just to finish the dang thing. There are few novels that I had to work at finishing.<br /><br />So, again, I like Neil Gaiman. I think he's a brilliant writer, and the other novels I've read by him are fantastic. Stardust, in my opinion, simply did not deliver.<br /><br />On a positive note, however, I will say that the last forty pages were much better than the previous ones.<br /><br />~Scott William Foley, author of [[ASIN:0595360823 Souls Triumphant]]

B00097A5I6|5.0|...That what is original about rock to-day isn't good, and what's good about rock to-day isn't original. B0006L16N8|3.0|If Coldplay constantly want to compare themselves to U2, then they should at least produce an album worthy of those comparisons.  Don't get me wrong, this is a decent record, but it's not as memorable as \\"A Rush Of Blood To The Head\\" (which I suspect will rank as their peak of creativity).  There's nothing really new here, nice as it is, and anyone with at least 1 ear can tell that \\"Speed Of Sound\\" is too inspired by \\"Clocks\\" to be considered an exciting and new piece of work.  I like Coldplay, but they'll never catch U2, let alone top them.  Let there be no doubt, this album will be HUGE, but only because of the hype, not due to the artistic merit.  The White Stripes' GET BEHIND ME SATAN..... now THAT's a fantastic CD.  Get that and compare it with this.  No contest.
B0006L16N8|5.0|It's hard not to be swept away by the frenzy that is Coldplay at the moment. If you're here to obtain information about this CD or any other Coldplay CD (there are only the other 2 of them), then the 'talk-up' of this CD has affected you in some way (you can't be a fan - otherwise, like myself, you would have gone out to buy this CD the day it was released). Despite being a major fan of this band's music, I hereby offer a genuine review of this album; and will try to speak of it in terms of its merit rather than promote the CD blindly.    One thing for starters - don't listen to the 30-second snippets. It will only do the tracks on the CD injustice. Buy the CD, listen to it in its entirety and if you don't like it, return it (I'm pretty sure in most countries we consumers are allowed to do so - if done in good faith). Nonetheless, here's getting straight into a review of the album. If you liked PARACHUTES and A RUSH OF BLOOD TO THE HEAD, chances are you're already a fan and have this CD. Otherwise, this CD is packed full with good stuff you'd learn to appreciate.    I must admit, Coldplay is an acquired taste. When I first experienced Parachutes, I found the music too raw and 'minor-key sounding' for my liking. Turns out, it is this sombre and gloomy mood that appeals to me most today. The world may have been introduced to this 3rd CD by Coldplay via \\"Speed of Sound\\"; an all too familiar sound reminiscent of the Grammy winning \\"Clocks\\" what with the repetitive piano playing and consistent yet catchy drum beats. X&Y is, actually, quite far from that.    On my first listen, the album did not impress me. The songs sit rather strangely, with not much of a tune one could associate to. There was no \\"In My Place\\" or \\"Yellow\\" to have yourself tapping and nodding to. There was no discernible, joy-evoking melody found on the CD, except for \\"Speed of Sound\\". I listened to the CD again. On my second listen, I found myself liking \\"The Hardest Part\\" and \\"Swallowed in the Sea\\". These two songs had a catchy tune to it, and my ears picked up a melody and I liked them. On these two tracks, especially \\"Swallowed\\", one is reminded of some nursery rhyme where Chris Martin starts off singing what seems like a folkish-journey song (if you know what I mean) to an almost silent background. But when the full band plays, there is a burst of musical bliss and one is overwhelmed by the uplifting feeling that Coldplay is master at evoking.    On 3rd listen, the album started to make sense. Each track found its position on the album - and I must say, great track listing. The songs seem to fit in with each other, complementing and contrasting. I discovered \\"White Shadows\\" on this latest listen, with its manic, distorted drum beats and the trade mark repetitive guitar riffs that attach Coldplay its addictiveness. What treasure! In fact, turn the volume up on this one. \\"Fix You\\" is a typical Coldplay song, and is sure to associate with fans - providing an amazing bridge where the music blows you away. Also, there is a hidden track \\"Kingdom Come\\" that is so similar to a stripped down, accoustic guitar, Bruce Springsteen song that you just can't help but marvel at the songwriting talents these 4 chaps of Coldplay have. Perfect closing to the album.    Chris Martin's singing is just as good as before, if not better. If forced to compare with previous albums, X&Y is closer to PARACHUTES than RUSH. X&Y, however, exhibits richer arrangements (perhaps more 'produced'), but portrays the similar 'minor-key', gloomy tunes that PARACHUTES introduced to the world. The CD is generally louder, has more instruments, and shows the style of RUSH on the music of PARACHUTES. Consequently, this CD is not a giant leap forward, but progression by Coldplay is obvious. There are 1 or 2 songs to satisfy those who like RUSH and prefer to stick with those songs, while Coldplay prepares fans for a transition to the next level with the band.    The album cover, of course, is some code meaning \\"X&Y\\". The CD booklet identifies the code for alphabets and if you're interested, pick up a \\"Speed of Sound\\" single to decipher the code. Great album cover.    I cannot recommend Coldplay enough. You know what? I foresee more Grammys - perhaps even a nod for Album of the Year this time.    The instruments and Martin's voice sweep and soar, the songs mesmerize and enchant, and the melancholy this CD exudes simply overwhelms. Well done, Coldplay, on this epic effort. Get this CD, if you still haven't done so.
B0009A1AS2|5.0|8th studio album finds the band stepping back a bit from the heavier tone of Train Of Thought. I might even go so far as to say that this is the band's lightest album although their prog roots are all over the place here ie. the 24 minute title track. So think of this as a better, more progressive version of Falling Into Infinity.

B0009A1AS2|1.0|I liked tot- it was heavy and in your face- this is balony!!!! what sound are you going to choose? STICK WITH IT!!!! buy hillary duff instead
B0006L16N8|5.0|It's 2005 and Coldplay have now reached an astronomical level of global popularity. They are easily the biggest rock band in the world, lead singer Chris Martin is one of the most respected musicians of the past decade and I myself truly feel proud to be British. With all the aforementioned, how much hype do you think a new album from Coldplay would receive? Well, I for one certainly was not prepared for the anticipation. I knew \\"X&Y\\" was going to be big, but not this big. It's been out for one day in the UK already, and sold hundreds of thousands of copies. This album will break records in this country and become one of the fastest selling albums of all time. This is all fair and well, but it is the follow-up to the Grammy-winning, multi-platinum \\"A Rush Of Blood To The Head.\\" Coldplay have a LOT to live up to, people, and this album will split people right down the middle from the minute they press the play button.<br /><br />What does this new album sound like then? Many have said that Coldplay haven't evolved their style and 'played it safe' but I disagree. There is a very noticeable maturity in the sound of this album. Martin is obsessed with the way things work, dismantling objects and rebuilding them, and the beauty of life. This is evident on the whole album, which is much larger and epic than their previous albums. The sound of this album is vast and large, almost reflecting the size and popularity of the band. If anything, they challenge U2 with the soaring choruses, racing guitar solos and massive drum sections. Is the album good then? Of course it is, I think it's bloody incredible. I expected nothing less. However, I know a lot of people won't agree, but give it time because this album will grow on you, I promise.<br /><br />The album opens with the amazing \\"Square One.\\" This is a brilliant rock opener and starts quietly with soft vocals from Martin. The drum beat then kicks in and when the chorus explodes after the first minute, you can visualise this as an epic stadium-filler. The guitars add the space in which they can bounce off the walls and echo down into your ears, and Martin's trademark cracked vocals that pierce your soul are comfortingly present when he wails, \\"It doesn't matter who you are!\\" The next song is the amazing \\"What If.\\" It begins slowly with a lone piano and Martin's questionable lyrics. A gentle pulsating hum begins arranging itself in the background in a song that seems to ask questions about Gwyneth, but that would be too obvious; it's the kind of thing you'd expect, so it's a surprise to realise this song is about Martin's connection to the fans, and sees him paranoid over whether Coldplay have dwelled in the spotlight too much. Hearing his beautiful, soothing voice wail \\"Oooo, that's right\\" is beautiful and sombre. From this, Martin can be reassured that the army of Coldplay fans very much want them in the spotlight for a long time yet. \\"White Shadows\\" is an incredible and very powerful piece of energised music. This is quite similar to \\"Clocks,\\" yet the piano is hidden. The drum beat is catchy and fast-paced, and the guitars surge through you. The chorus is amazing and races along like a stallion, as Chris Martin's vocals ascend higher and higher into the night sky. \\"Fix You\\" is the album's main ballad, and it is one filled with such intense passion and sadness. This is not quite \\"The Scientist\\" or \\"Trouble,\\" and may take a while to grow on you, but once it does the advantages are overwhelming. It begins with a soft piano solo which is very understated. It's one of those old-fashioned songs that will make the hair on the back of your neck stand on end, before climaxing in a proto-prog four-part harmony. The build up to this is achieved within a degree of perfection, because it doesn't become too loud as to spoil the first few minutes. It is a seamless pop production that will dominate stadiums and become an anthem for a generation.<br /><br />\\"Talk\\" is one of the highlights of the albumin my opinion, and samples Krafwerk's 'Computer Love.' The song begins off sparse and distant with an amazing guitar solo that echoes as though it were travelling around the perimeters of the universe, as a cold wind blows through your ears. The drums in this song are amazing, but the guitar solo is the real star here. The way it is arranged each time for you to anticipate it is incredible, it has me hanging on the edge and waiting for that pleasure rush every single time. Best line? \\"You could climb a ladder up to the sun. \\"The guitars become deeper and darker at the end of the song, providing the perfect outro. The album's title track, \\"X&Y,\\" is another stadium-filler that features an amazing catchphrase that will become a sing-along at Glastonbury this year. This song is steady and pounds heavily like \\"Politik,\\" swirling around and around, the guitars pushing Martin's vocals higher and higher as he sings, \\"You and me are floating on a tidal wave - together! You and me are drifting into outer-space.\\" The epic outro closes the song down to a point of obscurity, before \\"Speed Of Sound\\" begins. This is the album's lead single and entered the US charts at No.8, which is an astonishing feat for a British band! This is typical Coldplay with atmospheric guitars that buzz like static electricity with the driving drum beat. The trademark piano is ever-present, the verses are built well, and the chorus is powerful enough to keep the song going for almost five minutes. An amazing, soon-to-be classic! \\"A Message\\" begins with just a simple guitar and Chris Martin's soft vocals. It's rather intimate and close-up after the previous seven songs of open-air, stadium-filled rock. However, it soon ascends into a powerful rock piece. The real beauty, though, lies in the sheer emotion of the lyrics \\"You don't have to be on your own,\\" and the vocal harmonies in the chorus.<br /><br />\\"Low\\" is a great piece of rock music that reminds of Radiohead circa- \\"OK Computer.\\" The guitars are very strong as usual and the chorus is deep and mysterious. This is probably the 'worst' song on the album, and I use that term very loosely. \\"The Hardest Part\\" is an album highlight for me, with the beautiful lyrics and simple melody. Martin cries, \\"And the hardest part was letting go, not taking part.\\" This is a ridiculously-catchy song that undulates endlessly in the mind of the listener, as the celestial guitars flow like waves of molten gold and the keyboards shimmer like aurora in the night sky. A beautiful song that is begging to be released to radio. \\"Swallowed In The Sea\\" is a simpler song and a bit different to the complex and difficult vocal arrangements of previous tracks. This song reminds me of \\"Amsterdam,\\" but it opens up much earlier. The way Martin arranges the melody is very catchy and memorable. I love the imagery of this song, such as a thousand houses, one hundred miles, and trees being cut down and swallowed in a sea. It's a very natural, earthy and organic song. \\"Twisted Logic\\" closes the album and is yet another brilliant song where Martin wails, \\"You'll go backwards but then, you'll go forwards again!\\" Twisted logic, indeed! It works incredibly well with twisted guitars screeching and crying all over the melody, and serves as possibly the best outro to a Coldplay album we have witness to this point; unlike the final rock-out minute of \\"Amsterdam\\" from AROBTTH, this song is five minute of all-out pure rock!<br /><br />OVERALL GRADE: 10/10<br /><br />There is also a hidden track at the end of this album in the form of \\"Til Kingdom Come,\\" which was written for Johnny Cash, but unfortunately could not be recorded by him because of his untimely death. If you're looking for songs that are immediate and satisfying as \\"The Scientist,\\" \\"Clocks,\\" \\"In My Place,\\" or \\"Yellow,\\" then I think you may be initially disappointed with this album. Coldplay became popular in America with the release of their second album, where the melodies were strong and memorable, and I think a lot of American fans will feel disappointed because of this. Your loss if you feel this way, because this album is an incredible work of art. The melodies are there, you just have to be patient and look for them over repeated listens. And the true test of whether or not you can hear this will come in your appreciation of the album. I expect by Sunday, this album will have sold around 500,000 copies in the UK alone and will break all records. Coldplay have set the bar incredibly high with this album, which has simply made expectations for their fourth album ludicrous. I wouldn't be surprised if they packed it in for good after a world tour with this album, because this is truly the album of the decade and will top many Best Of lists for years to come.rs are very strong as usual and the chorus is deep and mysterious. This is probably the 'worst' song on the album, and I use that term very loosely. \\"The Hardest Part\\" is an album highlight for me, with the beautiful lyrics and simple melody. Martin cries, \\"And the hardest part was letting go, not taking part.\\" This is a ridiculously-catchy song that undulates endlessly in the mind of the listener, as the celestial guitars flow like waves of molten gold and the keyboards shimmer like aurora in the night sky. A beautiful song that is begging to be released to radio. \\"Swallowed In The Sea\\" is a simpler song and a bit different to the complex and difficult vocal arrangements of previous tracks. It works incredibly well with twisted guitars screeching and crying all over the melody, and serves as possibly the best outro to a Coldplay album we have witness to this point; unlike the final rock-out minute of \\"Amsterdam\\" from AROBTTH, this song is five minute of all-out pure rock! <br /> <br />OVERALL GRADE: 10/10 <br /> <br />There is also a hidden track at the end of this album in the form of \\"Til Kingdom Come,\\" which was written for Johnny Cash, but unfortunately could not be recorded by him because of his untimely death. If you're looking for songs that are immediate and satisfying as \\"The Scientist,\\" \\"Clocks,\\" \\"In My Place,\\" or \\"Yellow,\\" then I think you may be initially disappointed with this album. Coldplay became popular in America with the release of their second album, where the melodies were strongand memorable, and I think a lot of American fans will feel disappointed because of this. Your loss if you feel this way, because this album is an incredible work of art. The melodies are there, you just have to be patient and look for them over repeated listens. And the true test of whether or not you can hear this will come in your appreciation of the album. I expect by Sunday, this album will have sold around 500,000 copies in the UK alone and will break all records. Coldplay have set the bar incredibly high with this album, which has simply made expectations for their fourth album ludicrous. I wouldn't be surprised if they packed it in for good after a world tour with this album, because this is truly the album of the decade and will top many Best Of lists for years to come.

B0009I7NNA|5.0|<br /> <br /> At first listen some not-so-well-informed listeners will assume that since they're on a major label now, the corporate fat cats that be have ordered them to ixnay on the screaming vocals......BZZZZZT! Wrong. <br /> <br /> While playing in Leeds last year, vocalist M.Shadows suffered a broken blood vessel in his vocal chords. After several surgeries and months of training with a vocal coach (whom has worked with the likes of Axl Rose), his singing voice (which was incredible to begin with) is back and better than ever. And at risk of losing his voice for good; he's been medically advised to let the screaming vocals go the way of the dinosaur. <br /> <br /> It's more than evident that 2003's Waking The Fallen barely scratched the surface of the musical ability and range that this band posesses. The songs have become even more diverse and epic. Also, Zacky Vengeance and Synister Gates have given in to their urge to shred their asses off. Admittedly, their guitar work is worlds above their ability to choose stage names (sorry guys, couldn't help it). <br /> <br /> You almost feel naughty banging your head to their lead work...just because it almost doesn't seem right to hear this kind of fast fretting indulgence. But if it's wrong; I don't want to be right. <br /> <br /> The Rev (drums), and Johnny Christ (bass) are much higher in the mix this time, and don't think for a second that it's a bad thing. Mr. Rev's drumming is a suspected result of a genetic engineered splice between Dave Lombardo and Vinnie Paul. And to call Johnny's work on the low end 'solid' would be a gross understatement. <br /> <br /> Though not a bit shy about wearing their influences on their sleeve, none of this sounds derivative in the slightest. After all, if the rock media can call Jet a great new band (with their recycled AC/DC leftovers).... this is groundbreaking. <br /> <br /> Once again produced by Mudrock, the sound is much less prone to clipping as the last album was. Thisis largely due to a major label budget I assume. <br /> <br />  With some songs bordering on sensory overload due to breakneck tempo and dynamic shifts, this is a dark/light dynamic that would give a photographer an anuerysm (I hope I spelled that right).  <br /> <br /> To close in short; this album is 11 tracks and clocking in at just under 73 minutes. If you're tired of hearing cheesy synths, whining, bird calls, and stupidly simple arrangements being passed off as metal (not going to name names, but it rhymes with Disturbed), do yourself a favor and pick this album up. <br /> <br /> This just may be a sign that we're at the beginning of an era where it is once again okay to know your ass from a hole in the ground concerning the instrument you play. <br /> <br /> Five stars, and two sets of horns....way up. <br />

B0009I7NNA|2.0|I feel like a tough critic.  But after looking at everyone's review, I guess that I'm not alone on how bad this CD is.  Wow, how disappointing. B0000AQS0F|5.0|I'm a traditionalist when it comes to a movie.  I look first of all for a strong story and characters I can care about.  Firefly has both, plus humor and action, again, traditional marks of solid entertainment.  A recent book on Firefly pointed out that the show is masterfully constructed, with, for example, sightlines and camerawork used to build a relationship between the human characters and the ship they are in.  I had, for example, noticed subliminally that the character of Inara, the geisha/ambassador, had a particular aura, but had not realized that her character was deepened by set design, including especially the use of the color red.  Nor had I given a great deak of thought to the music, which, I realized only on reflection, not only set the mood but moved the story along as well.  This is a potential classic, defined as a work you can watch time and time again, learning or appreciating something new each time.  I'm on my third viewing, looking forward to the movie, and hoping that this wonderful story continues through many sequels.  There are memorable characters here: the beautiful, dignified and vulnerable Inara, the thuggish clown Jayne, who may have an ounce of decency somewhere, and the inscrutable Shepherd Book, to name only a few.  This is one of the triumphs of television history.

B0006L16N8|4.0|Well, here it was. I was sitting at this very place yesterday, staring at a brand new copy of the most anticipated release of this year, sober save for the coloured coded message, light reflecting off it's glossy surface. <br /> <br />Well, my heart wasn't exactly beating in my throat. Still, I was excited yet nervous in the face of the new album, nervous because I was afraid that Coldplay's third release would be the pin that would puncture and deflate my hopes for the record. <br /> <br />I won't say it was. After all, I have only listened to it twice. Still, the single Speed of Sound didn't really get my blood pumping. Certainly not when compared to the first singles of Coldplay's previous two albums, In My Place(from AROBTTH) and Yellow(from Parachutes). So I popped the disc into the computer(which, by the way, although it has copy protection, comes with a neat little player of it's own). On the first listen I was admittedly a bit disappointed. This was one long, vast expanse of sound. There didn't seem to be much variation either. So I was left at the end wondering how I would rate it and how it compares to their previous albums. <br /> <br />Then I listened to it this morning. Slowly, things began to click. I realised more than ever now that this record was definitely a grower. Which also seemed to be a matter of supreme irony, since although Coldplay has built further upon their trademark sound on X&Y, the record on the whole is actually less catchy and appealing to the general public! That should do away with the accusations of X&Y being some sort of corporate scheme to bring money in the drawers of the ailing music industry! Not that it is easy to imagine Coldplay as such a band. Now some people(actually, a LOT of people) claim that the band are stuck where they already were. That they haven't made any musical progression whatsoever. I beg to differ. It is virtually impossible for a band NOT to make any musical progression. Because, a band invariably changes inbetween recordings. The stadium-filling, paparazzi-punching, celebrity-dating Coldplay of now isn't the virtually unknown Coldplay of 2002. True, they might not have started churning out slick R&B tracks in the style of Justin Timberlake, but that does not mean that they have become musically stagnant. And there has certainly been a shift in mood. The band and Chris in particular almost buckled in the face of enormous pressure, both from the rest of the world and from themselves. Musically, the Beatles influence from A Rush of Blood...has diminshed. Instead, I can hear traces of Pink Floyd. This also becomes apparent in the whole setup of the album, which contains few catchy melodies and rather needs to be listened to as a whole. On the first listen, the album sounded uninteresting to me because the curious melodic shifts from AROBTTH(like in the title track and God Put A Smile On Your Face) have all but disappeared. Also, Chris's voice soars to greater heights, which on the surface makes him sound more cold and impersonal. Coldplay's latest definitely requires more than a few listens. Which is actually true of all Coldplay albums - when I got A Rush of Blood to the Head, I frequently skipped God Put A Smile On Your Face. A month later it was one of my favourite tracks. There are two stand-out tracks though. One is Low, the other is Twisted Logic. Both contain those strange Beatlesesque major-minor chord shifts that we have come to expect after AROBTTH. They both play with the head while firmly lodging themselves there. Twisted Logic is in the same league of spectacular closes as Everything's Not Lost and Amsterdam. A class track.  <br /> <br />A minor complaint that I have though is that there seems to be little variety in the songs. Lyrics were also never Coldplay's strongest point, but sometimes I do raise my eyebrows. The much-publicized electronic influences are almost absent, really, which may or may not be a good thing. <br /> <br />What bothers me thoughis that Coldplay's credibility will most likely plummet with this release. Sweeping and slow-burning, it is not a record which will be likely to appeal to the masses. Which might be a good thing after all, since it might give Coldplay the time and space to finally create a record to astonish us all.

B00079FUI6|3.0|Nobody - and I mean nobody - was higher on Desperate Housewives than I after seeing the pilot episode, which may have been one of the best hours of television I have ever seen. Better still, it holds up to repeated viewings. <br /> <br />So imagine my disappointment as the show became one of the most uneven in recent memory. Yes, there were unforgettable moments such as Bree's comically tragic dinner party and the ultimate fate of her philandering husband, Rex. But more often than not, storylines took far too long to unfold and, even worse, twists were easily figured out far in advance. Anyone who didn't see the big \\"revelations\\" regarding Mary Alice and her past coming at least three or four episodes before the finale has probably never seen any of the daytime soaps being lovingly mocked by their primetime sibling.  <br /> <br />The final episode of the season does deliver several standout moments, but, again, falls far short of what many were expecting. Billed in advertisements as ending with a major, shocking cliffhanger, viewers were no doubt left wondering if they'd missed something when what they got was... well, not to give anything away, but basically a spin on the old \\"three people and a gun\\" scenario.  <br /> <br />Is Desperate Housewives worth viewing? Yes and no. Suspend your disbelief, be prepared for several \\"now why the heck would anyone do something so stupid?\\" moments and, if all else fails, skip through the episodes and watch the sublime scenes featuring Felicity Huffman and Doug Savant as the most likeable - not to mention relatable - folks on Wisteria Lane, Tom and Lynette Scavo.
B0009I7NNA|5.0|Avenged Sevenfold is a very unique band. Their first two releases, Sounding the Seventh Trumpet and Waking the Fallen have shown that they have the talent of a legendary metalband, with the powerful emotion of today's metalcore. With thrashy drums and a perfect blend of screaming and singing, these two magnificent albums represent the beginning of Avenged Sevenfold--using the metal influences they love most to create a unique blend of \\"kid-friendly\\" metalcore. With their latest release City of Evil, A7X has run away with the metal side of their music and left the screamo behind. This new music is remeniscent of a classic metal masterpiece--every song has its hard hitting moments and its poignancy. The guitar work is stunning, the double attack of Gates and Vengeance will grow in the world to a great status. The bass is definitely turned up on this cd, and the riffs get much more technical. The drums are different, but for the better--they branch out from the very common \\"thrashier\\" style of WTF and STST, and into a different, more complicated unique style. And then there were the vocals--the biggest change on City of Evil. This is where Shadows gets to shine, as he is easily the best vocalist to come out of rock in the past couple of decades. He throws aside the screaming so he can showcase his unbelievable singing talents. Often his voice is remeniscent of Axl Rose and just as often he won't be as raspy but still perfectly on pitch like a solo artist. It is hard to fit City of evil into a genre--whether it is Metal, just plain Rock, still Metalcore, or even at times it is classical. The band also likes to describe some parts as \\"death-western.\\" Don't let this range of styles turn you off from the cd though...it all fits together perfectly. City of Evil is an epic for our generation...and one of the greatest cd's the world will have seen in a long time. <br /> <br />Beast and the Harlot - a grungey opener with a killer solo and vocals remeniscent of zakk wylde. 7/10<br /> <br />Burn it Down - With very catchy riffs, lots of tempo changes, and a great variety of vocals, this is a good sample of alot of things to come on the cd. 8/10 <br /> <br />Blinded in Chains - a really cool opening to this song, with lots of good riffs scattered here and there, and a unique sounding verse. 8/10 <br /> <br />Bat Country - inspired by \\"Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas,\\" this will be the first video for City of Evil. one of the greatest bridges i have heard in my lifetime. 10/10 <br /> <br />Trashed and Scattered - The beginning, with all the layers of sound almost sounds like a really fast heavy rock classical piece, if you can draw that from it. This is a really good song. 8/10 <br /> <br />Seize the Day - A ballad very remeniscent of A7x's Warmness on the Soul, or a poppy GnR, with some good solos. 9/10 <br /> <br />Sidewinder - Latin inspired rock song for the first 4 minutes which is alright, then the last 2.5 minutes are a stunning latin acoustic piece with great vocals, backing, and an awesome solo. 10/10 <br /> <br />The Wicked End - My favorite song on the CD. Starting off almost like a song from WTF, this goes from mid-tempo, to blatantly fast, and heavy, with a cool solo, and about half way through there is an orchestral interlude supported by a choir, and then the band comes in and plays over it. Spectacular piece of music. 20/10 <br /> <br />Strength of the World - A 9 minute \\"death-western\\" epic only Avenged Sevenfold could create. Brilliant song from start to finish. 10/10 <br /> <br />Betrayed - A rock song about the assassination of Pantera's Dimebag Darrel. Probably my least favorite on the cd, but that does not turn me away one bit. 7/10 <br /> <br />M.I.A. - A song that sounds like ...And All things will end, the WTF closer. My second favorite on the cd, starts really slow and then bursts into all out metal with a cool solo and \\"choir-y\\" sounding finish, with shadows turning things down a bit, and then a solo fading out thecd. another great piece. 20/10 <br /> <br />be sure to listen to this cd. i'ts brilliant.

B000002JS6|5.0|Screeching lyrics of sex and rock, metal thrashes and overwhelmingly loud riffs, and catchy drum beats in many ways defined AC/DC's signature metal sound, plastered all over Back In Black with perfection. Although musically is often criticised, the band offer great chemistry within their riffs and screams, coming together nicely after a tragic passing of former band member Bon Scott.<br /><br />Although maybe not completely original in sound, AC/DC revolutionized rock in many ways with this album. A powerful opener Hells Bells begins this 39 minute metal extravaganza. An instant classic, with a superb guitar riff that becomes imbedded in our heads. This powerful opener sets the tone for what's to come, an album filled with rising riffs, catchy choruses, and a great deal of melodic sense within the metal. Shoot To Thrill is another great example of AC/DC's talent. Givin The Dog A Bone is a ridiculous chorus, built around stunning riffs of joy. Let Me Put My Love Into You is almost the sensitive side AC/DC wished they could express with a lighter aspect. Instead they use a raunching guitar solo in between which makes for some classic metal. The self titled track features a very catchy, immediately recognizable guitar riff. Another classic follows with You Shook Me All Night Long, featuring almost a metal balladic side, with the beautiful, high pitched chorus ringing through your ears. A n almost blues based introduction starts off Have A Drink On Me, and keeps with the consistency of the album, as the group stays very close to their metal roots in previous songs with a catchy metal riff. Maybe the least memorable follows with Shake A Leg, simply lacking in any compelling guitar riff. Rock And Roll Ain't Noise Pollution however closes the album exceptionally well, featuring a slow paced intro into heavy bounces of metal sensation featuring a chorus suggesting \\"rock n' roll ain't gonna die\\". Unfortunately, although it stayed alive through to the mid 90s from the likes of Guns n' Roses and Nirvana, I consider it to be no more.<br /><br />Easily a landmark album in the metal genre, AC/DC in certain ways replaced KISS with this album, with a slightly different sound, and a screechier outlook on metal, and using the metal noise to create sensational music. Absolutely a must for all metal fans, and any AC/DC fan should own this, casual or diehard. Also, if you listen to groups like Linkin Park and Good Charlotte, don't purchase this album, and remember that that isn't the same kind of metal<br />Highly recommended.' Roses and Nirvana, I consider it to be no more.    Easily a landmark album in the metal genre, AC/DC in certain ways replaced KISS with this album, with a slightly different sound, and a screechier outlook on metal, and using the metal noise to create sensational music. Absolutely a must for all metal fans, and any AC/DC fan should own this, casual or diehard. Also, if you listen to groups like Linkin Park and Good Charlotte, don't purchase this album, and remember that that isn't the same kind of metal   Highly recommended.

0385510454|3.0|The novel started out nice, but mid-way got a little predictable. The characters seemed quite boring at times. Some of the important characters seemed unreliastic, which included President Morgan, Teddy Maynard and Critz. Even Backman/Marco seemed almost superhuman at times, in the way he adapted to his new environment and situation.  I had a problem with the ending as well. The last few chapters promised a lot and delivered very little. Particularly unbelievable was Marco's use of Giovanni's passport without anyone suspecting anything, both in Europe and  US. On the upside, some of the descriptions of Bologna and its landmarks are quite good, although I cannot vouch for their accuracy since I have not been there. On the whole, I would say this is a readable novel if you have nothing better to read or are stuck on an airplane/train, but I wouldn't spend half the night trying to finish this novel. The only other John Grisham novel I read was 'The King of Torts', which was much better in terms of its characters, subject as well as the development of the story.
B000003S0P|5.0|It was 1974, and the ever-rotating line-up that called itself King Crimson was collapsing...again. The band had already fallen apart and reformed two or three times before this album was recorded, and on Red, King Crimson was reduced to a trio. Guitarist Robert Fripp, drummer Bill Bruford, and bassist/vocalist John Wetton created most of this music, along with a few guest musicians.    \\"Red\\" is the first song on the album, and is constructed wonderfully. Heavy, menacing, dramatic; it was King Crimson at its finest. The six-minute instrumental finally gives way to \\"Fallen Angel,\\" a vocal piece that manages to sound just as epic as \\"Red,\\" complete with startling contrasts between light and darker, heavier moments. The beginning is rather subdued, but the chorus introduces some droning guitars and saxophones, and \\"Fallen Angel\\" is one of the strongest moments on the album. \\"One More Red Nightmare\\" feels like a weird, distorted, but upbeat take on the title track, utilizing a dented cymbal to mimic handclaps. It features some of Fripp's best arrangement tricks, as well as some truly interesting lyrics, that, indeed, chronicle one distressing nightmare. \\"Providence\\" is the second instrumental, but it is very different than \\"Red.\\" Comprised mainly of improvisation, \\"Providence\\" is interesting, but it just isn't a song I can listen to often. \\"Starless,\\" the epic closer, is a rewrite of the title track to this album's predecessor - Starless and Bible Black. In my opinion, it is superior to that song, containing one of the most haunting openings to any King Crimson song, ever. It is notable for having perhaps the finest John Wetton vocal performance for the band - maybe for his entire career. Following the vocal section, the band moves into a more experimental portion - droning guitars that keep reaching ever upward - that eventually resolves into one of the best King Crimson album closings ever.      Being a King Crimson fan, I can say that this is one of their finest albums. Perhaps newcomers should listen to this album. My personal introduction to the band was their debut, and I still recommend listening to that first, but Red isn't a bad choice. The truth is, it's stunning that this album exists at all. As it was being recorded, the band was imploding, yet the album can be considered one of their finest efforts. Red turned out to be bandleader Robert Fripp's final ideas for the dying band, and ultimately, it's heavier and noisier than some expected from King Crimson. Although their next phase (beginning with Discipline, continuing through Beat, and ending with Three of a Perfect Pair) was equally brilliant, this remains the closing work from Crimson Mark II (or is it III? Who can keep track?), and it's incredible stuff.
0316172324|2.0|If you consider yourself an intellectual (you know who you are...Matrix is your favorite movie) you will appreciate reading this book. Thereafter, you will commit the anecdotal experiments to memory and will shamelessly flaunt them at wine tastings.  <br /> <br />The author introduces the concept of thin-slicing beyond the delicatessen. He also informs the reader that snap judgments are not merely relegated to NFL quarterbacks.

The themes developed in the first section (really the first quarter or so of the book), notably the protagonist's religious interests, never get played out in the second.  Still, it's certainly an enjoyable read.

B0006GAI6Y|3.0|This big Hollywood remake of a small Japanese sleeper is going to get knocked around the dance floor by those who have seen the 1995 original which, to be fair, is better. But this one isn't half bad. In the original, a bored Japanese accountant courting a midlife crisis takes ballroom dancing lessons and enters a competition. In the remake, so does a Chicago attorney (Richard Gere). His wife (Susan Sarandon) hires a private detective because she suspects he's having an affair.    So why doesn't he simply tell her? Dancing is not yet criminal or shameful in Bush's America. The secretiveness worked in the original because the Japanese are wary of public physical contact. At the end, Gere tells Sarandon that, although he loves her and is happy, he didn't want to hurt her by admitting that dancing makes him happier. Uh-huh. Once you accept this tortured logic you might be able to enjoy all the stereotying, glamorizing and self-aware acting on abundant display.    Gere has played so many movie lawyers (he played another dancing one in \\"Chicago\\") he could play them in his sleep, but he seems awake to the character here; surely this good actor has passed the bar by now. Jennifer Lopez, as his teacher, dances gracefully and mercifully is not called upon to act, which allows her character a certain mysterious distance called for in the script. Stanley Tucci is a frenzied delight as an office drone with Gene Kelly genes.     If you were among the few thousand who saw the original, superior in every way, don't watch this DVD (with its entertaining extras) or spoil the story (with its small surprises) for the millions who haven't.

1591396190|5.0|This breakthrough book provides an organized framework for identifying and implementing out-of-the-box \\"blue ocean strategies\\" in all industries. The blue ocean strategy explains how to sail your business into new markets with less competition and greater profitability. Disarmingly written by W. Chan Kim and Ren&eacute;e Mauborgne, the book is energized with fresh research about the impact of innovative ideas on old industries. The compelling business examples alone are worth taking this cruise. Even the appendices make interesting reading and contain more detailed examples about products ranging from the Model T to movie theaters (the authors explain how innovators reinvented theaters and created their own blue ocean phenomena). While the book provides its share of rules and principles for intrepid strategists to follow, complete with its own jargon, managers easily can navigate right to the authors' key strategic advice. We consider this book essential for any strategist or entrepreneur who wants to move out of intensively competitive shark-infested waters and into the relative tranquility of the open blue ocean. Getting there isn't risk-free, but great adventure awaits the intrepid executive who makes the voyage.

Remember: the best lead guitar solos are the ones one can sing along with. I mean, how can anybody come up with those thunderous and imaginative double bass beats, is beyond me. The fast tempos are often offset by beautifully crafted slower patterns. Bruinenberg's drum lick repertoire and odd timing bag of tricks is endless. Nevertheless, his best stuff can be heard with Elegy, not here. Elegy to me is (was?) a much better band.  <br /> <br />Most reviews here highlight Forte's guitar performance. However --for a change-- it is very important to acknowledge the astonishing level of drumming accomplished by Bruinenberg. This album is a must for any drummer or musician willing to learn how to push the envelope into un-chartered territory. 0440180295|2.0|The horrors of war have unhinged many a man, Vonegut's Billy Pilgrim being one of the more famous of them.  It takes no great insight to grasp that war is awful almost beyond human understanding and that participating in it, or merely witnessing it, can crack someone's sanity.  Billy Pilgrim can't stop reliving his trauma. His time-tripping is an unconcious attempt to escape that trauma.  Goofy looking aliens tell him to think of the positve things in his life. It never works.  He goes tripping back to Dresden at random times in his life, and trips back to his life at random times while he's in Dresden. I don't understand why this novel ever rose to the status of a classic.  There are much better anti-war books ( Johnny Got His Gun ); there are much better science fiction books ( too numerous to mention ); there are much better anti-war science fiction books ( The Forever War, The Stars My Destination ).  The only pluses I can give this book are Vonnegut's style ( crisp, succinct and in plain English ) and its relative brevity. Get it from the library ( don't waste your cash ) and read it just so you can argue intelligently when someone tells you how great a book it is.
B00004YX0R|4.0|No doubt quite good interpretations. They are non the less also some of the most peculiar. That is perhaps partly due to the engineering, the ambience of the sound, but also to the playing style. This quartet sounds different from all other quartets I have ever heard. The bow on the strings often sounds very ugly, like somebody filing some metal. It is something feverish about it, at the same time something frail. It makes me think of sunshine stinging in the eyes. Suffice it to say that it is nothing fleshy about the sound of this quartet. Tempos are mostly brisk, the touch is light - in spite of the filing sound, which also can be described as a thin, withered, squeaky sound. Summa summarum: This quartet gives a so peculiar atmosphere to the Beethoven quartets that it is no point in comparing to other quartets, just as summer cannot feel like winter. This is summer. Summer heat, sultry, close, smoky, of barbeque or rubbish fire of withered leaves... I feel that these recordings are quite aristocratic, of very good taste, delicate, intimate. This has nothing to do with \\"old world\\", as both the Alban Berg quartet and Quartetto Italiano are (were?) \\"old world\\" and yet a far cry from Talich. I love to have this one in my collection, because it gives something not any other quartet gives.   Not my first choice, however, I would rather go for Takacs (op. 18), Takacs or Tokyo (middle quartets). To me, Tokyo rules when it comes to the late quartets, but that's me. I guess most people will prefer the Takacs quartet all the way, with the exception of the Quartetto Italiano congregation. Talich is something special, but very good as such.
B0002KQNZO|5.0|Bursting at the seams with originality, passion, and fury, Art Blakey's \\"Free for All\\" is a textbook example of how hard bop jazz is done. The title track of this 1964 masterpiece is an 11 minute wonder: Wayne Shorter's blazing sax, Freddie Hubbard on trumpet, and Blakey himself doing the most amazing drum solo that will leave you speechless. The fun only begins here. The band also tears it up on \\"Pensativa\\" and the upbeat \\"The Core,\\" whose interplay between Shorter, bass player Reggie Workman, and leader Blakey makes the track work so well. Throughout the album, you can feel and hear the harmony between all players, each of whom holds his own respectably. If you've never heard of Blakey, this CD will instantly turn you into a convert. One of the greatest recordings--jazz or otherwise--ever made. It gets my highest recommendation.

B0009A1AS2|3.0|Let me first start this review out by saying that I am a huge Dream Theater fan, seeing them 5 times in concert. I enjoyed 6 degrees of inner turbulance, I learned to love Train of Thought, but this album is a let down. It seems like all of these songs were just bland. Nothing really stands out on this cd. I'm giving it three stars because it is Dream Theater, and even on their worst effort, it's still better than all of the crap on the radio these days. The reason I don't like this album is because Dream Theater is trying to sound like too many other bands and not enough of themselves through the whole thing. I'll go track by track to explain myself: <br /> <br />1) The Root of All Evil: This is Dream Theater trying to be themselves, but it falls short. The Glass Prison and This Dying Soul were the first two of Mike Portnoy's 9 step song program, and it seems that with each song, they get worse. The main problem with this song is that it is too repetitive. <br /> <br />2) The Answers Are Within: Dream Theater trying to be _insert hair metal band here_ with their power ballad. This song sucks flat out. No emotion, forced feeling, and James LaBrie's voice is the thing that really bothers me about this song. This is Anna Lee bad from Falling Into Infinity. <br /> <br />3) These Walls: Dream Theater trying to be Pain of Salvation. The band pulls it off, but again, the singing is terrible. No matter how hard he tries, James LaBrie will never sound as good as Daniel Gildenlow. This is an alright song, but the influence is blatent. <br /> <br />4) I Walk Beside You: Dream Theater trying to be U2. I don't like U2, but this song is ok. I like the singing on here, but the rest of the band sounds cheesy. No real feeling in this either.  <br /> <br />5) Panic Attack: Dream Theater trying to be Opeth without death vocals and more lead guitar. Opeth is one of my favorite bands so this isnt too bad either. This also sounds very similar to Pain of Salvation again. This is the bestsong on the CD. This song is why this review has 3 stars.  <br /> <br />6) Never Enough: Dream Theater trying to be Muse and the Mars Volta influence is strong on this one. This is the filler track on the album. I have heard the whole album through half a dozen times and I could not remember this track while I was writing this. 2nd worst song on the album behind The Answer Lies Within. <br /> <br />7) Sacrifced Sons: Dream Theater trying to be themselves again. This is The Great Debate all over again. The Great Debate was a pretty big rip-off of tool, but it had enough Dream Theater in it to save the song. This song has what has become of Dream Theater, lack of interseting lyrics, and unfortunitly, lack of musical diversity to satisfy my tastes. The solos and drum fills have all been done before. The first time I heard them, they were awe-inspiring, but now it is just rehashed material done over a remake of one of my favorite tracks.  <br /> <br />8) Octavarium: Dream Theater trying to be Porcupine Tree/Symphony X. After seeing that there was going to be a 24 minute epic on this cd, I was expecting a lot. This is no Change of Seasons. This is a dull, boring track that misses all of the elements that make the bands they are stealing from great. The Porcupine Tree influence is in the begining when the sound texture rolls over the listener, but what it is missing is the feeling and the point of it. The Symphony X influence at the end of the song is strong in the orchestral arrangements and the double bass, but it is missing the songwriting and classical guitar lines that are in the forefront of Symphony X. This song is also missing Russell Allen's vocals. This track was the biggest let down of the entire album. <br /> <br />I do like this album despite the negative things I have said about it. The problem I have with it is that it is not up to the high standards I keep Dream Theater at. I like most of the \\"influences\\" they have included throughout the album so it wasinteresting to hear Dream Theater playing that style, but it didn't always work and that's where the album suffers.  <br /> <br />If you want to get a true progressive gem that came out this year, get Porcupine Tree's latest \\"Dead Wing\\" or the new Opeth cd when it comes out. Get this is you are a collector, but stick with Images and Words and Awake for the real enjoyable records.  <br /> <br />Those are my thoughts and remember I am entitled to my opinion so think for yourself, but this is how I feel about this record. A Three Star performance from a Five Star band. <br /> <br />-Andrew
B0006L16N8|4.0|It has been a couple of years since Coldplay's second album \\"A Rush Of Blood To The Head\\" hit the stores, and boy did it go down a treat, selling over 10 million copies world wide. Their recent release entitled: \\"X and Y\\" sees the band losing their distinctly raw sound featured in some of their previous hits such as \\"Yellow\\" and \\"In My Place\\". This is not neccsarily a bad think however as they still manage to encapsulate their trademark emotion into this album while also blending in a more complex, modern sound (and even techno in some parts).     Now, On to the actual songs...(I'll opt for the easy way and just do the review on a song by song basis)     Square One: Square One: An eerie, spacey type sound opens this song (and the album) up. Chris Martin's vocals drift in...     \\"You're in control, is their anywhere you wanna go?     This slow start soon gives way too a pounding, techno flavored beat that immediately lets you know this is no \\"Parachutes\\". It is a catchy, effective opening song,     What If: a great vocal performance by Martin is present here, although the lyrics are somewhat \\"Dr Seuss like\\" in terms of the rhyming scheme (not the content!) which degrades an otherwise beautiful, touching song.     White Shadows: A confident, thudding, techno beat greets us on this track. It reminds me of the b-side \\"Things I Don't Understand\\". Not one of my favourites, but by no means a bad inclusion.       Fix You: This song features one of the most memorable endings in the Coldplay's song repitua. Every time I hear the line towards the end:\\" Tears stream down your face, When you lose something you know you can't replace\\", I shiver with emotion, it really is something.     Talk: The guitar playing just does not work on this song; it sounds out of place as well as annoying. The lyrics are pretty corny as well. This song is filler.     X And Y: The previous blunder is quickly redeemed by this classic. The chorus is just stunning. And the lyrics are equally beautiful:\\"You and me are floating on a tidal wave....Togeeeeetheeeerrrr\\"   \\"You and me are drifting into outta space\\"     This song is trademark Coldplay, and should make for an excellent second single.     Next we have Speed Of Sound: The bands single release. It is very reminicient of \\"Clocks\\" (which is a good thing) as it features primal drumming and a memorable piano melody. All in all, a great song, And made an excellent first single.     A Message: A gentle acoustic opening helps us recover from the \\"larger than life\\" sound of the previous two tracks. The lyrics and vocals are very honest and sincere. It's a really sweet song. That's all I can say.     Low: R.E.M fans will love this won. It just doesn't sound like Coldplay....ughhh.     Hardest Part: A lot of the songs featured in \\"X and Y\\" describe the complexities that can exist in relationships between man and woman, and the emotional experience that can be associated with finding that one person of whom you want to spend the rest of you life with. This song is no exception. Musically it's quite uplifting, but sticks within the albums conceptual parameters.     Swallowed In The Sea: Nice little ballad, compliments the album for sure. But nothing, really to write home about.     Twisted Logic: This song is definitely a grower. The lyrics are really melancholy and it features a chorus that is hard not to sing along too.     Till Kingdom Come: The \\"hidden track\\" of the album. It features some really lush acoustic guitar playing, and touching vocals. It's just lovely. An excellent closer to the album.     Overall, Coldplay have done a remarkably good job here..I for one doubted whether they would be able to pull off even a decent third album considering how much presure they would of been under to replicate the success of their first and second records. Well done fellas.

B00078XGRO|3.0|Star Trek: Fist Contact is actually Star Trek VIII, and the first feature film containing solely the Next Generation cast.  With Jonathan Frakes (Riker) at the helm as director, veteran TNG screenplay writers Braga and Moore, production designer Zimmerman, and composer Jerry Goldsmith, this film truly contains the best family of TNG artists ever assembled.  The quality of the film reflects this collaboration.  It is far and away superior to either Nemesis or Insurrection, and objectively much better than Generations (although I have a soft spot in my heart for that film). <br /> <br />The story - another Borg cube has decided to challenge the Federation, and the fleet assembles for battle.  This time, the fleet fares better than at the Battle of Wolf 359 (as shown in the TNG episodes \\"Best of Both Worlds\\" I and II).  The Cube is destroyed, but a small escape ship emerges and vanishes through a temporal (time-travel) rift.  The Enterprise is quick to pursue, knowing that the Borg must intend travelling back in time to change history and/or assimilate Earth in the past.  Our heroes arrive in the year 2063 (just after WWIII in Trek lore) to find the small Borg ship bombarding Earth.  Their target - Earth's first warp-capable ship which allows humans to make First Contact with an alien species and ultimately pave the way for the creation of the Federation and of Starfleet.  The TNG crew must fight off the Borg (who take over the Engineering decks on the Enterprise), set the timeline right (without themselves disrupting it), and save the First Contact event. <br /> <br />This must be the most action-oriented film of all the Treks.  There is a big space battle, hand-to-hand combat with the Borg, etc.  However, the soul of the film is still in the interactions between the characters: Worf and Picard disagree about how to best fight the Borg, Picard must rescue Data, Troi and Riker must work together to ensure First Contact, etc.  Even fan-favourite Reg Barkley makes an appearance!  Seamlessly inserted into the cast are Alfrie Woodard as a 21st-century engineer and James Cromwell as Zefram Cochrane, legendary pilot and inventor of Earth's first warp-capable ship.  A word about the soundtrack is appropriate here as well - veteran Jerry Goldsmith delivers a supurb score, weaving in elements of his other Trek scores.  Worf's action scenes are punctuated by the Klingon theme from ST:TMP, the space-walk music is reminiscent of the V'ger theme, etc. <br /> <br />So why only the 3-star rating?  Unfortunately, there are a lot of little issues that detract from the enjoyment of the film upon repeated viewings, which is why you buy the DVD, after all.  For example, the first 45 minutes are fantastic - action, suspense, pacing, etc. are perfect.  After that, though, the editors and/or director allow the picture to slow down and it seems to run out of steam.  More alarming are more fundamental story problems.  For example:  the away team loses contact with the Enterprise (when the Borg take over part of it) but never seems concerned.  In addition, we get an extended Moby Dick reference, which is basically a rehash of Star Trek II - there's lots of literature out there to quote, it's sheer laziness to repeat the Moby Dick theme. <br /> <br />But the most serious problem is the change wrought upon the Borg, relative to their civilisation in the TV show.  They are given a queen who, apparently, controls the collective consciousness.  Suddenly there is a leader who, when killed, fatally disrupts the collective so it can no longer function.  The original point of the Borg was that they were not hierarchical - the only way to kill the Borg was to wipe out every single one of them.  Now, suddenly, there is a simple magic bullet solution that all you have to do is find and kill the leader?  This completely negates the strength and fearsomeness of the Borg, making them another mundane enemy race. <br /> <br />Naturally, I have no complaints about this special edition.  There are lots of goodies here, including three commentaries by (in order of decreasing interest) writers Braga and Moore, Trek guru Okuda, and director Frakes.  There are lots of little featurettes to keep the techies happy, talking about effects, design, etc.  And the price is very reasonable for a DVD of this quality!

1932100385|5.0|I have read many of the popular diet and nutrition books out there, and none of them have been able to stand up to this one. Although I knew that fruits and vegetables were very healthy, I used to vigorously defend moderation. I liked a hamburger or other beef dish two or three times a week and I tried to eat low-fat meats most other days. Chips and soda were only occasional treats, so I thought I was eating pretty good. But I was overweight, and I started doing the diet book merry go round. At the insistence of a good friend I bought this book and started reading it and had a hard time refuting any of the arguments made by the author. There is such a wide variety of evidence, from so many professional journals, regarding so many different studies, that it was difficult to come up with counter-arguments to defend my old beliefs. It's forced me to change the way I think about food and health.  <br /> <br />This is not a compilation of information from secondary sources like newspapers, magazines, and other popular books; this is a compilation of peer-reviewed research findings from the top biomedical journals, complete with hundreds of references. These are research findings not just from the author, but also from researchers at Harvard, Oxford, and dozens of other reputable institutions. This is the most credibility I've ever seen in a health book. <br /> <br />All of this information is strengthened by the last part of the book, the inside look at how food and medicine are being bungled in the US. <br /> <br />I also am impressed by the endorsements for this book. I don't know of any other diet and health book that has the credibility of having endorsements from a former Ivy League President, a Nobel Prize winning scientist, the former top food policy maker in Washington, the president of one of the premier cancer organizations, and a former senior World Bank official. Amazing! <br /> <br />Most importantly in the past 2 months since beginning to change my diet, Ihave lowered my cholesterol by 45 points, lost over 15 pounds, and can now walk up the stairs in my office building without having to pause halfway up. I get fewer headaches and my back and knee pain has gotten better(from losing weight, probably.) I feel great. I can't recommend this book enough.
