B0006L16N8|4.0|One of the best bands of the new millennium is Coldplay. With their first two albums, they were posed to battle U2 for the \\"Greatest Band in the World\\" title, a title that U2 has held for most of the last 25 years. Parachutes was a good introduction with mellow grooves, just something to sit back and relax too. It also set up what has become the signature Coldplay sound. Then with A Rush of Blood to the Head, they perfected there sound of crushing guitars and piano strings. X&Y could be the make or break album. <br /> <br />We got of what the new album will sound like with Speed of Sound, the first single that has been out for a while (one critic said it sounds like Clocks but without the passion). Sadly, that is about the best we will get to hear on the album. X&Y is, in essence, a step backwards from A Rush of Blood to the Head almost as it was the missing link between Parachutes and A Rush of Blood to th Head. <br /> <br />So what we get on X&Y are songs about new love. One song sappier that the first. The best of these songs is Fix You. A song about trying to fix any problem your girlfriend has no matter how hard the problem is. Had they stopped there, it would have been good for the album but then we have to sit through others relationship issues like What If?, Talk, A Message, The Hardest Part, and Swallowed in the Sea. <br /> <br />The standout track is the hidden closer, Til Kingdom Comes. A song the band originally wrote for Johnny Cash's American Recordings V, but unfortunately Cash died before recording it. On a side note, I cannot recommend American Recordings I-IV enough. Coldplay ended up recording it for themselves, so what you get is an old-school county song with Martin bringing out a rare baritone voice. <br /> <br />In the end, if you liked their first two albums, most likely you will like this. Hopefully on the next album, they experiment a little more maybe even try a couple more songs like Til Kingdom Comes. <br /> <br />As an after word to this review, I caught a MTV special with Coldplay performing the songs off the album. I caught it about halfway through, but what I heard was more passionate than what was on the album. Maybe instead of comparing them to U2, Dave Matthews Band might be a better comparison as their studio albums never sound as good as their live shows.

1573223026|5.0|This is another excellent novel from Nick Hornby who has yet to write anything that I have not enjoyed. It is the story of four very different characters. <br /> <br />Maureen is a downtrodden single parent whose life is dedicated to caring for her severely disabled son. Martin is an obnoxious daytime TV presenter who has been the subject of a high profile sex scandal. JJ is a musician who always wanted to be a rock star but now deliver pizzas. Jess is an impulsive teenage tearaway. It is hard to imagine a group with less in common.  <br /> <br />What does bring them together is a tower block - Toppers House - in London on New Years Eve where each arrives intending to leap to their doom. They inevitably discuss what has brought them there. I must say that I feared that they would understand each others pain and then hug each other living happily ever after in a community. But they don't. In fact whenever I thought I knew where it was going it went off in a different direction. Never predictable and never dull.  <br /> <br />They are certainly not a likeable bunch. Why else would they be at Toppers House in the first place? But they are a fascinating group of oddballs and their mutual dependency is both touching and amusing. The subject matter is never trivialised even though there are several laugh out loud moments. The writing is always excellent. Watch out for Maureen's discovery of Nick Drake's music. That is a real `waterworks' moment.  <br /> <br />Don't be put off by the gloomy subject matter. This is his best to date and should not be missed.  <br />

630460288X|5.0|Initially, when I saw the preview for this movie back in 1993, I will be the first to admit that I thought this movie was going to be terrible.  However, I was convinced to watch this movie when it came out on video and I must say that this is one of the best sci-fi/action movies I have seen.<br /><br />Demolition Man takes place in the year 2032 in the city of San Angeles, which encompasses the current day cities of Los Angeles, Santa Barbara, and San Diego.  The society closely mimics the society described in the book \\"The Time Machine\\" by H.G. Wells.  Most of society resembles the \\"Eloi\\".  Society has turned into a utopia of political correctness.  Most everyday things have been made illegal including swearing, sex, spicy foods, and salt for example.  The city has no violence or firearms of any kind.  Rather than prison, criminals are frozen and rehabilitated during their \\"hibernation\\".  However, there is an underground \\"Morlock\\" type society known as \\"scaps\\" in the movie.  The \\"scraps\\" are the free thinkers, which I would compare to modern day Americans.<br /><br />The leader of San Angeles secretly releases a violent criminal, Simon Phoenix (played by Wesley Snipes) to kill the leader of the \\"scraps\\", Edgar Friendly (played by Dennis Leary).  The police release another \\"cryo-con\\", a maverick 20th century cop named John Spartan (played by Sylvester Stallone) who originally captured Phoenix in the 20th century and was framed during the arrest of Phoenix.  Spartan is partnered with a bored officer named Lenina Huxley (played by Sandra Bullock), who is a nave police officer obsessed with the 20th century.<br /><br />The result is an awesome action film with a shaky plot.  This movie reminds me a lot of \\"The Last Boyscout\\", a loud movie with a lot of shootouts.  However, this film is also filled with many laughs, as Huxley rattles off many 20th century clich&eacute;s but manages to screw most of them up.  Product placement in the movie is everywhere.  Despite the frequent referral to brand names that would become nauseous in most movies, the product placement works very well in this movie and adds to the comedy and charm.  The movie also makes references to a couple of 20th century actors such as Arnold Schwartzenegger and Jackie Chan.<br /><br />If you enjoy an occasional pointless, loud, violent action movie, this is definitely the movie for you.  While I would not rate this movie as a masterpiece, I do think this is one of the few movies that pull action and comedy together exceptionally well.  I thought the mix of actors worked exceptionally well in this movie and complimented each other beautifully.  I would definitely say this is a must see movie!  I think the movie is even better now as it brings up a lot of memories of the late 80's and early 90's.frequent referral to brand names that would become nauseous in most movies, the product placement works very well in this movie and adds to the comedy and charm. B0009A1AS2|4.0|I just got the CD and after having listened to it three times I already place it among my favourite DT's Albums. I'd encourage progressive rock fans to listen carefully to the title track (almost 24 minutes!), probably the best piece of music ever written so far by DT. Interestingly, you can hear echos and citations of all well known DT's influences. It starts with a PINK FLOYIDISH \\"Shine on you crazy Diamond\\" type of atmosmophere, it builds into a GENESIS Peter Gabriel's flute melody reminescent of Selling England by the Pound, it grows into RUSH's Geddy Lee bass riffs that seem taken from LA Villa Strangiato e Cygnus X-1 (the citation here is obvious since Lee and Myung normally have a very different sound). Later in the song you will clearly distinguish YES's keyboard solos, BRUCE DICKINSON's angry singing and even DAVE MUSTAINE's Donald Duck voice. To recap, blend Pink Floyd, Genesis, Rush, Yes, Iron Maiden, Megadeth and lots of Dream Theater original style and you will get this masterpiece. I have listened to the song only three times, I am sure there are more citations. Listen to it and find more!

B0006L16N8|5.0|I divide Coldplay songs into two categories:  Songs that I could never get tired of hearing and songs that I have to be in a \\"Coldplay\\" mood to listen to.  Both of their previous albums are filled with examples of both.  Luckily, this is one of the few bands whose singles are all in the first list, with the Scientist being the only exception.  X & Y, once again, offers plenty of both.  After a few days, Speed of Sound (though a bit of a Clocks retread), Talk, Square One and Low are my early favorites, and could easily end up as the type of song that I'll never tire of.  Others are definitely more Coldplayish...What If? is the best example...the chorus will stay with you for days after you've heard it a few times, but once you find yourself in a mood for an upbeat rocker, its the kind of song that you'll skip (as are many of Coldplay's best songs). <br /> <br />My personal grading scale aside, I have to say this is one of the best albums I've ever bought....and one of the few that has lived up to the hype that preceded its release.  Coldplay pulls off a nice trick that few bands have managed, and that's tinkering with things and changing their sound a bit without SOUNDING like they've changed their sound.  The best parallel I can think of is REM in its hey day following up Green with Out of Time.  Everything is instantly identifiable as a Coldplay song, yet repeated listens will reveal some nuances that show the band isn't just trying to remake the previous album. <br /> <br />All in all, I would recommend this to anyone that enjoyed the previous two albums.  There are those, such as my lovely wife, who think Coldplay are whiny, and that opinion will only be reinforced with X & Y....My one (very minor) complaint is that at times Chris Martin opts for the falsetto voice a few times too often.  But trying to find fault with an album this good is sort of like trying to name the worst Beatles album...no matter how you slice things, its still better than almost anything else out there. <br /> <br />Coldplay is a band that takes its music seriously, but its nice to have a young band out there that is still defining their legacy and showing that they have what it takes to belong in the company they aspire to.  And especially after such a long layoff and all the attention and hype that come with having a hit album, marrying a Hollywood actress and becoming a staple of People Magazine's photo pages, its nice to see that an artist can stay true to his overshadowed (and underappreciated) bandmates and turn out a terrific set of songs.

630027120X|5.0|The Mission continues to be one of my all time favorite films. The sceanography of the Amazon jungle is breathtaking not only because of its vast beauty, but because of the context; Watching De Niro clamoring up the precarious falls is just one of the many images that elicits a holding of one's breath.  <br /> <br />The other major reason that I am profoundly impressed each time I watch this film is its poignant fictional representation of how the Vatican and the Catholic European monarchs of the colonial period prioritized profiteering and political intrigue over winning souls. It betrayed the innocents and sanctioned their massacre and slavery by turning away and shrugging it off with a tear(reminiscent of WWII). <br /> <br />As any great movie elicits a strong emotional reaction from its audience, this one elicits a flood of grief and appropriately righteous indignation at the sickening atrocities and social injustices of the \\"civilized Christians\\" against a people who had no real defense against the subjugation of militarily more advanced colonizers.  <br /> <br />Here we see a fictitious yet historically accurate account of how, once again, the powers and principalities of the day will justify their own gain and security at the ex pence of others rather than doing what is right ethically and, ironically, that which is truly representative of Christianity.  <br /> <br />There are many other components of this story of which one can ponder and discuss, such as the quality of the acting of the children and the politics of the 16th and 17th century Jesuits, the early \\"Liberation Theologists\\", and martyrdom, social anthropology, ethnography and the affect on a primitive culture by exposure to another in the attempt to study it(or 'help' it), existentialism, mysticism, global politics and commerce, labor out-sourcing...just to name a few.  <br /> <br />Politics and religious ethics aside, The Mission is a gorgeous, visually rich film with what can be considered one of the best casts imaginable performing their utmost best...what more could anyone expect of a film...if it were re-released it would be among the few movies worth paying to see in theaters. Also, if it were released as a DVD it would be one of the handful of movies worth owning. <br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <br />

B000006IUQ|4.0|David Mamet's trademark dialogue is present in THE EDGE, a film that is buoyed by its stars performances and some truly disturbing scenes featuring Bart the Bear.  Anthony Hopkins is a billionaire who accompanies his model wife (Elle McPherson) on a photo shoot in the Canadian wilderness.  The cinematography brilliantly captures the immense wilderness beautifully.  Hopkins is invited by his wife's manager (an effective Alec Baldwin) to join him on a brief flight north to get an Indian for a model.  Harold Perrineau Jr. as Steve accompanies the two but the trip becomes a nightmare when a bizarre accident downs the plane and leaves the three survivors to find their way to rescue.  Of course, Hopkins suspects Baldwin of having an affair with his wife, and is sure Baldwin is going to kill him to get her and his vast fortune.  Bart the Bear begins stalking the survivors and in a particularly horrifying scene, devours Perrineau, leaving Hopkins and Baldwin on their own.<br /><br />Mamet's script tends to be a little too literary but it doesn't diminish the impact of the situation, and Hopkins is typically brilliant as the billionaire.<br /><br />THE EDGE is worthwhile entertainment and is to be commended on its viscerality and portrayal of the ordinary man up against the extraordinary.

B0007Y4TVU|5.0|System of a Down is possibly my favorite band.  I've been hooked right from album number one. <br /> <br />System of a Down do what any good band would wish themselves to do, & that is, maintain a certain genre & feel that is their own, but never to copy themselves over from past material. This puts a justification on my following statement; Mesmerize is just like all the other albums, in that it isn't the same.  <br /> <br />Let's run through the tracks. <br /> <br />1 - Soldier Side.  This is just a little introduction to the album. Basic, soft riff & some powerful words to kick off the new album. <br /> <br />2 - B.Y.O.B. (Bring Your Own Bombs). Power track. This is the first single from Mezmerize. Heavy, fast verse pacing for the  drums & guitar, & a slower, catchy, almost taunting chorus, this is a great kickoff to the album with System's anti-war message rumbling into your ears.  Good lyrical content that can only be expected of SOAD. This single's video is quite well-done as well.  I particularly like the helmets passing by that read things like \\"God\\".  Clever. <br /> <br />3 - Revenga. This is a hyped up song with very fast vocals from Serj, which I've come to love. It's got a real great flow to the lyrics / instruments. My sweet revenge / Will be yours / For the taking / It's in the making baby.  This track is practically impossible to skip, it jumpstarts your brain (if it's possible to skip any System song). <br /> <br />4 - Cigaro.  Not a favorite track, but catchy as all hell. This is one of those songs that pops up on every System album that has a weird flow to it, & doesn't make much obvious sense, but you wind up always listening to anyways.  Cool / In denial / We're the cruel regulators smoking cigaro, cigaro, cigar.  Makes you want to get up & bang your head a little bit. Or smack it off a wall.  Decent track just the same. <br /> <br />5 - Radio/Video.  Liking every System track I've heard thus far (ecluding that song with Wu-Tang), it's weird to say it, but this song rather annoys me.  I don't hate it, or even really dislike it, but it's not something I'd recommend to start with to a new System listener or something like that. Has some good points to it, I just dislike the chorus & the way it flows. <br /> <br />6 - This Cocaine Makes Me Feel Like I'm On This Song.  This is a ridiculous song, in a good way. Pumped up, catchy, & it makes your head spin. Gotta love that.  There's nothing wrong with me / There's something wrong with you / I hope your stepson doesn't eat the fish. ... weirdest part of this is, I think that underneath this craziness, lies a message. This song kind of makes you think. I wonder if that's a good thing or not. Don't ponder to deep. <br /> <br />7 - Violent Pornography. Catchy track that gets its point across quickly.  It's a lyrically very raw track, with a trippy little riff to it.  This is the one track I can't say much about, it kind of gets lost on me how to react. I don't know, but I like it.  <br /> <br />8 - Question!. Another great track. Original as it is, it puts you in mind of past System songs, which isn't a bad thing. It's intriquing, no more, no less.  Good, to-the-point lyrics, with a great flow that blends to them. I could see this as a future single.  It could make for a good video. <br /> <br />9 - Sad Statue. This has quickly become one of my favorite System songs. Says a lot about the way things are in the 21st century & how damaged society is at this point. Great lyrics, great mood. Good music, that doesn't outride the lyrics, which are the general focus for this track. Nothing is really outshined here, the whole song is brilliant. <br /> <br />10 - Old School Hollywood. A sort of heavy track, as far as the chorus goes at least. Lyrics are simple, & intended that way. It's a good song, very catchy in a weird kind of way.  It also sets up track 11 quite well. <br /> <br />11 - Lost In Hollywood. Daron takes over the lead vocals for this track, & does a superb job.The mood of this song is well-tuned to suit his singing voice.  Good lyrics, good imagery. Would make for a good single, a good video. Some people were disappointed with his extra vocal time, but I don't see the problem.  Daron is just as much a part of System as Serj, as is John, as is Shavo.  The guy can sing, they wanted to give him a chance, let him have it.  I think he holds up quite well. <br /> <br />Same old System, brand new album.  & it's awesome.

The rules of civil discourse must change such that we can intelligently address, as this book does, the important issues of our time. The modern equivalent of the flat earth society has been out there making some absurd decisions about our lives and our future. Unless we stop them soon humanity will be handicapped for quite a while. Sam Harris tells us the way to come out of the closet and argue effectively with the Christian Right who may mean well but who are doing a pretty good job of screwing things up badly. For instance, no rational approach to ethics would have us stop stem cell research. Our present official policy is shaped by beliefs that are divorced from every reasonable understanding of biology. As a neurologist I can assure you that we visit more suffering on a fly by killing it, then we visit on a blastocyst, to say nothing of a zygote. This book is a good place to start to arm yourself against the hooey and baloney that the Bush administration is throwing our way everyday.

B0006L16N8|3.0|I'm not a huge fan of Coldplay to begin with. They're a nice, simple alternative rock band with nice simple love songs and pleasing progressions and melodies, but Coldplay are not reinventing the wheel here. All the doting reviews on amazon for this album bring to mind Radiohead's Thom Yorke and his dismissal of Coldplay as \\"Lifestyle Music.\\" This album, I feel, justifies the remark.<br /><br />Instead of joining in on the Chris Martin circle-jerk, I'm going to be honest and say that I'm just not that impressed by this album. It's nice and everything, but there just isn't much to grab my attention. Unlike Parachutes and A Rush of Blood to the Head (which is a guilty pleasure of mine,) There just isn't a whole lot here that jumps out at me. Coldplay has suddenly decided that they very badly want to be U2, and the most predictable and skip-able aspects of A Rush of Blood to the Head form the groundwork for the majority of this album.<br /><br />Again, it's still enjoyable and has it's moments. Even though the verse of \\"Speed of Sound\\" is like the dull bastard child of a bad U2 song and \\"Clocks,\\" the soaring, emotionally over-the-top chorus and pre-chorus are perfect examples of why I still listen to Coldplay. The Pink Floydian synth intro to \\"Square One\\" got my hopes up (far too soon) and indeed the rest of the song is pretty good. The progression is different and the subtle electronics are at least tasteful. The sort of Depeche Mode, new wave groove is something different from Coldplay. \\"White Shadows\\" starts out slightly out of character for Coldplay, and is actually pretty dark sounding. \\"Talk\\" sounds like a likely candidate for the next single and has a memorable guitar hook that, again, brings to mind U2. Another nod to dark 80's synth pop is \\"Low,\\" probably my favorite song on the album. \\"'Till Kingdom Come\\" is also a nice treat, bringing back some of the folksy charm that persists throughout Parachutes.<br /><br />This album stands out when Coldplay is trying something new, but unfortunately that doesn't happen much on these songs. Most of the other songs on this album fall into that vague, forgettable pop tune category. They bring to mind phrases like \\"well that's nice\\" and \\"what the hell did I just listen to?\\" A lot of this is a diluted rehashing of the worst parts of A Rush of Blood to the Head. It's sad, but I think Coldplay are now slaves to the reactive American rock radio industry. Producers and record execs have a leash on the band's creative potential, and Coldplay aren't even going to try and break free at this point - would you want to take risks if you were the most masturbated-to band in the world right now?<br /><br />I'll give the record multiple spins, in hopes the remaining songs will grow on me, but my initial reaction to it is to be very underwhelmed. If you like nice, easy to digest singsongs, go ahead and pick it up, but don't expect to have your mind blown.trying something new, but unfortunately that doesn't happen much on these songs. Most of the other songs on this album fall into that vague, forgettable pop tune category. They bring to mind phrases like \\"well that's nice\\" and \\"what the hell did I just listen to?\\" A lot of this is a diluted rehashing of the worst parts of A Rush of Blood to the Head. It's sad, but I think Coldplay are now slaves to the reactive American rock radio industry. Producers and record execs have a leash on the band's creative potential, and Coldplay aren't even going to try and break free at this point - would you want to take risks if you were the most masturbated-to band in the world right now? <br /> <br />I'll give the record multiple spins, in hopes the remaining songs will grow on me, but my initial reaction to it is to be very underwhelmed. If you like nice, easy to digest singsongs, go ahead and pick it up, but don't expect to have your mind blown.

B0008KLVG4|5.0|What a bunch of whiners! Yes, DVD's are released over and over as initial releases and then special edition(s). This is not \\"scandalous\\" as one reviewer put it - it's business. Of course the studios and distributors are going to add more stuff and get more of your money. Get over it. For the most part, DVD's are so inexpensive now (the new Special Edition 30th Anniversary of Jaws is only $16.99 at Amazon) that they're practically throw-aways after a couple of years (when the newer special edition comes out). For pricier compilations such as The Lord of the Rings trilogy, you should just sit on your hands and wait until the more expensive multi-gazillion disk set is released. If you buy them individually and then get mad because you have to buy them all over again it's your own fault for not waiting.
B00004UEDQ|4.0|A script so good that even Sandra Bullock's annoying presence can't mess it up. There are other cute features, like instructions on how to make a gum-wrapper chain like Sandra makes in the movie. <br /> <br />Basic storyline: <br />Gwen is a party girl who gets busted for a DUI. She is sentenced to rehab. At first she thinks rehab is whack and cheesy. She doesnt participate with the others, and has her party-boy boyfriend sneak her drugs. But then she starts to think she really may have a problem. Will Gwen straighten up, or continue with her partying ways? Will she accept the proposal of her drunk-druggie boyfriend? <br /> <br />This movie is above all a comedy. The addicts will make you laugh, Gwen's reaction to them will make you laugh. Steve Buschemi plays a rehab counselor, and while he isn't funny in this role, he is interesting. <br /> <br />There are a few sub-plots. Gwen's rehab roomie is a teenage heroin addict. Also, a major-league pitcher (sex addict, druggie) comes to rehab and bonds with Gwen. B00080ZG10|4.0|It's easy to understand the mixed reviews even if one doesn't readily side with all of them.<br /><br />First, one cannot fault this production for its visual audacity. It looks and feels like a fascinating personal adventure. You'll remember it for its thrilling flying scenes. There's even a nail-biting rendition of the [in]famous FX-11 reconnaissance plane crash on a row of Beverly Hills townhouses.<br /><br />And that's not half of its appeal. We get a glimpse of it all -- inventions, glamor, tough romances, quotable quotes, explosive action, madness. The screenplay is riveting. A taut script chugs things along at a rapid clip.<br /><br />Helped by confident cameos from everyone, especially Cate Blanchett after one comes to terms with that farcical Hepburn accent. DiCaprio was hardly the right physique for the role if you've seen a pic of Hughes but his intensity and flair quickly make up for that inadequacy. Alan Ada sports phenomenal presence in the little bit of screen time he is accorded.<br /><br />No, the film is truly well made. I'd recommend it in a blink. It must have made a very, very close second to Million Dollar Baby, which took the cake for its simple yet hard-hitting emotional heft.<br /><br />The problem lies with the somewhat vacuous aftertaste one recalls the picture with, due in no small measure to its drawn-out ending that seemed enamored with the idea of meticulous bottling of human discharges.<br /><br />One wonders if Hughes was the only one wallowing in OCD; Scorcese seems so drunk on Hughes the Inventor's fervor that Hughes the Man gets a short shrift. Historical glitches I'm not qualified to mull over, but the version we see of his feats as aviator/inventor are watered-down at best. Why his obsessive bravado? Why the promiscuity in adult life? Why the egging psychosis?<br /><br />Two and half hours of this magnum opus and we end up none the wiser. Which is really quite tragic as the film had everything going for it.<br /><br />A 2-disc DVD should have made for a perfect avenue to fill the gaps and include canned scenes or some such, but we are subjected to half-hearted documentaries instead.<br /><br />That's two strikes on wasted opportunity.VD should have made for a perfect avenue to fill the gaps and include canned scenes or some such, but we are subjected to half-hearted documentaries instead.<br /><br />That's two strikes on wasted opportunity.

6302787300|5.0|An interesting topic observed in the film 1492: Conquest of Paradise is the transcendental encounter among Europeans and the indigenous cultures of America.  Two completely different worlds meet on October 21, 1492.  According to the film, Colombus  feels that he and his men have found the Garden of Eden.  The natives do not seem to be a threat during Columbus's first voyage, for they even give artifacts to the Spaniards as a \\"sign of submission.\\"  I would say that the way in which the indigenous people are portrayed is by means of a realistic point of view.  The reason why I hold such idea is because the film does not seem to favor one group over the other.  There are scenes that show the cruelty in which some Spaniards treated the indigenous; similarly, the fact that the indigenous people also killed Europeans is brought up in the film. <br />The way in which Columbus is portrayed is both realistically and idealistically.  He is represented as a man with a \\"think outside the box\\" mentality.  His dreams are to reach for the stars and he challenges Spain's Catholic king and queen, as well as fights and wins a mental battle with himself and his crew when they believe they are doomed in the sea.  However, one of my uncertainties is whether or not Columbus truly felt that the indigenous people were equal to his men, as the film suggests.  Yes, Spaniards were forced to work and build cities as did the indigenous people, but was it to the same extent? <br />Religion plays a vital role in the film.  During Columbus's second voyage, a Catholic church and a bell are built.  Undoubtedly, religion serves as an instrument to \\"conquer.\\" <br />Other aspects of the encounter brought up in the video are the fact that the Europeans oppressed the indigenous people in every thinkable way and, indeed, mixed interracially with native women; the way in which Columbus searched for India; and the Europeans' lust for gold. <br />In conclusion, I would recommend the film, due to its historical value, as well as because of its awesome scenery, casting crew, and music. <br />

B0000C7PSW|5.0|Not many singer/songwriters these days, would choose to follow the career path of Rufus Wainwright.  Having come from the 'Wainwright' family, of whom his mother, father (& now Sister), are all accomplished performers, musicians.  Rufus specialises in a theatrical form of expressive Chamber Pop/ Singer-songwriter music that takes in: Cabaret, Theatrical Pop, Adult orientated Pop/Rock, Adult Alternative & even opera & literate pop.  Shamelessly overblown and Passionate, some would argue that this form of sophisticated, literate music, died a century ago, along with the music it references, but you see, Rufus isn't your average Pop star.    \\"Oh What a World\\" rams home the point admirably, with a huge lush orchestrated sound, largely operatic in approach over which Rufus muses \\"Why am I always on a plane or a fast train, Oh what a world my parents gave me, Always Travelin' but not in love....\\", and chimes wonderfully with his cabaret-infused theatre pop, and the addition of plucked strings, only serve to highlight that Rufus is aiming for the highest echelons of Adult-orientated pop.    \\"I Don't Know What It Is\\", follows with a gradual, slow building melody, that solidifies critics various mentions that Rufus is something of a Renaissance man musically, with an ear for emotional complexity.  With a song that places an emphasis on melody and production, over which Rufus sings: \\"Take a lookin around At friendly faces, All declaring a war on far off places, Is there anyone else who is through with complaining about what's Done unto us\\" shows his sentiments, in no wavering fashion, but the richly textured and layered songs, belie the incisive wordplay.        \\"Vicious World\\" opens with gloriously shimmering strings and backing vocal harmonies, and gentle slow piano chords, with Rufus' delicate vocal intone of: \\"Thought that maybe we'd fall in love over the phone, Thought that maybe I'd really love being alone, Everybody but Heaven knows how I was wrong!!\\", in the softest and sweetest of vocal deliveries, it's feels like a extremely low-key ballad of the subtlest kind, and is as poignant as it is restrained, and neatly highlights some of the very broad musical scopes with which Rufus pitches his lyrical tent on which to draw upon, his multitude of musical influences.  This may be a little too subtle for some, but the albums refusal to follow conventional musical methods is extremely impressive.    \\"Pretty Things\\" is far more sombre in tone & mood, with the barest sketches of instrumentation (Piano, organ), making the perfect musical backdrop for Rufus to sing over, (think, midnight mood Torch-bearing chamber-pop), with the lyrical theme largely about not feeling guilty for liking pretty or superficial things, as Rufus boldly declares:  \\"Pretty things, so what if I like pretty things??, Pretty lies, so what if I like pretty lies??\\", without a dash of irony, and cleverly twisting the listeners disbelief at his superficiality, by saying: \\"This time will pass and with it will me, And all these pretty things......Don't say you don't notice them??\\"    And so there you have it.....gloriously pretentious, shamelessly overblown, impossibly romantic, and probably a little too literate & cerebral for widespread mainstream acceptance, it's pitches its tent firmly in the Adult-orientated market, and asks listeners to meet it, on Rufus' terms.  And frankly....some listeners may not want to, as the album has layers that are gradually peeled away, to reveal hidden depths of lyrical intricacies that will be missed the first time, knowing little references that will begin to make sense on repeated listens, and phrases lifted or modified from literature.  And few would argue that what Rufus, has created here, isn't uniquely his own!!, and so seemingly out of step with what music is currently being made, that you have to wonder, how many audacious & left field albums, can he make such as this, before his record label pulls the plug??  But then again, anything this bold, brave, artistic, painstakingly detailed or not easily catergorisiable, deserves all the (limited) recognition it can get.  Finally!!!....an artist not afraid to take chances, and have to simplify his music, in an effort to bend to the almighty dollar, or have to make a bland commercially viable album....and you know what???, his music is all the better for it.  Buy Now!!!

0838577016|4.0|I am an undergraduate neuroscience major.  I chose Principles Of Neural Science on my own, because I wanted a higher-level text than the course required.  The textbook provides a good overview of the many different aspects of neuroscience, from synaptic transmission to perception to development.  It is easy-to-read, not dense like some textbooks.  I find it especially helpful to read a chapter of the text before attempting to dive into a research article. My only criticism is that it refers to material from other chapters as though it should already be learned, as though the  book is meant to be read in order and not used as a reference.  With 63 chapters, I am not sure this is appropriate.  Nevertheless, I highly recommend this text.
B0006L16N8|3.0|Many people predicted that with this album, Coldplay would become the biggest band in the world. While the album is still fairly musically strong,there are no particular songs with the exception of \\"Fix You\\" that seem especially striking like \\"The Scientist\\" and \\"God Put a Smile on Your Face\\" were. A majority of the album is comprised of synth, piano, drums, and electric guitar causing a good number of the songs to sound like mere continuations of each other rather than songs that can truly move listeners individually. The songs that seek to emotionally impact the listener sound like an above average ballad, but fall short when compared to the previous accomplishments of \\"Yellow\\" and \\"Green Eyes\\". <br />       While this new album does succeed in making many of these songs especially \\"Talk\\" into live-audience pleasers, it fails to recapture the essence of what made them so magical in the first place. The absolutely gorgeous songs of the previous two albums including \\"The Scientist\\", \\"Amsterdam\\", \\"Warning Sign\\", and \\"Yellow\\" are replaced by stadium designed songs. This new slate of songs sounds fairly appealing to the ear, but does not convey an intense feeling of emotion and thus, becomes forgettable. It is still a strong album especially to those who considered Coldplay to be too mellow and wanted them to toughen their sound . However, those who loved  Coldplay for their unbelievably melacholic and touching songs may want to look else where.  <br />Top Songs: Fix You, White Shadows, Swallowed in the Sea
0679720200|5.0|The Stranger is one of my absolute favorite books.  I read it the summer after my grandmother died.  I did not cry at her funeral, nor did I feel particularly sad--old people die.  My friends noticed a smiley face on my calendar.  I told them it was an unhappy face that marked the day my g-mom died, because I thought I'd forget otherwise.  Their reaction to this shocked me; it was as though I killed her myself. <br /> <br />Then I read The Stranger.  Brilliant.  The opening lines resonated:  \\"Maman died today.  Or yesterday maybe, I don't know.\\"  Everyone seems to mark it as a disturbing book, but I cannot imagine a truer, more honest book.  I strongly recommend it to anyone who has ever felt betrayed by society's judgments.

Now a days, if a band released a new album with only 8 songs on it, fans would be pissed. This 8 track effort however, at times sounds like a double-disc release. \\"Battery\\" thrashes you around like a tornado, \\"Master of Puppets\\" provides one of the best riffs in history, and \\"Disposable Heros\\" gives a fast and tear-up song about war. Then there's \\"Sanitarium,\\" a can't miss haunter with echoing verses and a thrashing finish. There are no mistakes on this album, absolutely none, and the fact that it hit #22 on the Billboard charts without any radio or TV play shows that. Metallica was, is, and always will be an authority in metal. Black Sabbath started metal, but Metallica saved it from that spandex, LA crap. This album marked the beginning of Metallica's takeover of the world.

0007144369|5.0|The Collins edition of Oscar Wilde's complete works is the only one I've ever found that actually is *complete*. It contains not only all of his plays, fairy tales, and short stories, but also most of his essays (some brilliant writing) and *all* his poems. Many books say they do, but there are a few tiny gems that oft go unnoticed (such as \\"Love Song\\" and a lovely little piece with no name). A truly wonderful edition of a truly wonderful writer, or, as Wilde himself might say, \\"Quite utterly lovely.\\" Also, if I am not mistaken, contains several pages of pictures of Wilde and his family.
B0006L16N8|5.0|Coldplay will no doubt in my mind be one of the few bands along with a few singer/songwriters from this era to be remembered 20-30 years from now. Coldplay writes these psychadelic melodies that leave the listenter in a emotional trance. Chris Martin writes beautiful/smart lyrics as well, giving the songs a very interlectual feel. As if the songs are more composed rather than just rocked out. Now don't get me wrong rocking out is deffennitely not a bad thing, I myself enjoy loud guitar riffs and solo's, but Coldplay are doing something different. B0006L16N8|3.0|For me the best song in this collection is the hidden track Kingdom Come.  It is a true surprise in it's honesty, simplicity, and sheer beauty.  Perfect lemonade after a 12-song diet of sugary syrup.  And too, it is a surprise as it is delivered in the manner of an after thought given it's position.  The rest of the collection is clearly a worried-over effort that tries to best its predecessor.  Sadly it doesn't.   <br /> <br />Here's how to fix the problem. <br /> <br />Dummer.  Simple highhat, kickdrum and snare.  No more complex tom rythyms or chugga-chugga 16th notes.  Play with your heart not your head. <br /> <br />Guitarist. We like your style but you need to expand.  Lead us down a path that seems obvious but then surprise us with things that touch the soul. <br /> <br />Singer.  Remember Politik, and A Rush of Blood to the Head?  Don't sing to mortals, sing to gods.  Less broken spirit stuff, we're not all broken hearted or lost or sad. <br /> <br />Basist.  You're fine. <br /> <br />Please don't become the Styx of this century.
B0006L16N8|5.0|I'm so moved by the aural space inside my headphones that I've nearly forgotton how to type. X & Y is something else...something great that should not be overlooked by anybody with a real musical taste. Sonically different from anything they've done before, and in terms of composition, melody, harmony, emotion, it continues where Parachutes left off, though somewhere in the far future... B0007Y08QA|5.0|THE MACHINIST is a mesmerizing film, a journey through the interstices of a mind deprived of sleep, of nourishment, and a mind that struggles to untangle the chaos of a past of guilt and terror. And the journey is terrifying.<br /><br />When the film opens we meet Trevor Reznik (Christian Bale) or at least the emaciated, tortured remains of a man who hasn't slept for a year.  We don't know why this worker in a machine factory is in such condition: the story unwinds slowly so that by the end we accompany Reznik in his shock to his moment of discovery.  It is the getting there that is the tough beauty of this amazingly rich film as written by Scott Kosar and directed by Brad Anderson.<br /><br />The setting is always dark as though the state of mind is a nightmare.  Reznik's meager existence is challenged when he is involved in an industrial accident in which a fellow worker Miller (Michael Ironside) loses an arm.  Shocked by the accident (for which Reznik feels responsible) the various few people in his life seem supportive: a hooker named Stevie (Jennifer Jason Leigh), a waitress in an airport all night diner Marie (Aitana S&aacute;nchez-Gij&oacute;n), and an ambiguous bald man Ivan (John Sharian) who appears to Reznik in strange ways.<br /><br />Reznik's mind slowly disintegrates into paranoid delusions, the only way he can hold his life together is by post-its reminding him first of his documented progressive weight loss, then of his needs, then of his secret mystery.  To say more would be a great disservice to the extraordinary plot.<br /><br />Christian Bale delivers one of the most committed performances on film.  He not only physically inhabits Reznik with his skeletal appearance, he also mentally nurtures all the nuances of fear, pain, pleasure and madness that build as his character's reason for a year of insomnia is revealed at the very end.  We stand in suspense with him and his fall is as powerful as any Dante ever devised.  The entire cast is superb but special kudos go to Jennifer Jason Leigh who finally has a role that allows her to demonstrate the spectrum of skill she possesses as an actress.  Not an easy film, this, but a very important one.  Highly recommended - but not to see alone!  Grady Harp, June 05al kudos go to Jennifer Jason Leigh who finally has a role that allows her to demonstrate the spectrum of skill she possesses as an actress.  Not an easy film, this, but a very important one.  Highly recommended - but not to see alone!  Grady Harp, June 05
B0006L16N8|4.0|Capitol Records is right to use Coldplay as the reason their stock rises or falls.  With the release of X&Y, Coldplay has really taken their place as one of the more influential bands of our time.  The reviews here have been mixed, but those one-star reviews really should be ignored on the release date.  No one can give a fair review after one listen.  I've been listening to this album all day....start to finish and over again. <br /> <br />This is by far Coldplay's breakthrough album.  Yes, even more so than A Rush of Blood to the Head.  I really don't understand all the comparisons to U2.  Yes, Martin's voice sounds a bit like Bono's, but the musical style is completely different.  X&Y is unmistakably Coldplay.  The same vocal style, the same lullaby crooning, and the same ethereal crecendos.  Only this time, they've added a synth here and there.  The synths, however, don't overpower the live instrumentation.  It's used merely as a support element.  The result is that the music sounds more lush and has much more depth than in the first two records.   <br /> <br />The first half of the album is so sonically uplifting it gives me chills.  \\"Square One\\" and \\"Fix You\\" are almost reminiscent of Pink Floyd in their use of layered guitars (wow, the guitars on this album!) and layered vocals.  The song \\"What If\\" is almost reminiscent of Sigur Ros in its ending swell.  The very upbeat songs, \\"White Shadows\\" and \\"Talk\\" are also magical in their own right.  The second half of the album starts out strongly with \\"Speed of Sound\\".  This track is the only one that's of the same style as the first two albums.  It's almost a perfect blend of \\"Clocks\\" and \\"Moses\\" (from the Live 2003 set).  The album takes a less exciting turn after this song that begins to recover with \\"Swallowed in the Sea\\" and finishes strong with the amazing \\"Twisted Logic\\".  Then, after it seems to end perfectly with this track (and 30 seconds of silence), the hidden track \\"Til Kingdom Comes\\" arrives like an encore.  While not at all like the other tracks on this album (rumor has it that it was written for Johnny Cash), this is still a pretty cool little song.   <br /> <br />All the rumors about Chris Martin's marriage to Gwyneth and his new fatherhood status ruining this album are completely unfounded.  Yes, a song or two is probably about Gwyneth, but it's not gushy, rather it's done quite tastefully.  This is an incredible album by Coldplay.  Sadly, I think people's expectations were so high that no matter how good it is, it won't be as universally loved as A Rush of Blood to the Head.  Too bad, this is truly the defining Coldplay album.

B0009A1AS2|5.0|I gotta be honest, the first time I heard this album, I didn't like it. I'm 20 years old and I've been a fan of DT for about 5 years, and I've always gravitated towards their heavier tunes (i.e. Pull me Under, Glass Prison, Lie, and anything off of T.O.T). But I'm also a musician and therefore am very into the virtuosic side of DT. I recently purchased Jordan Rudess' latest album and got even more into his style of playing. Although he does tend to overshadow Petrucci some times, I think his playing has once again succeeded my expectations. I think this album takes a bit of getting used to. There's definitely some more \\"pop-style\\" songs on here, but it's also very progressive. I kept getting reminded of Yes, Kansas, and Genesis while listening to some of the non-metal tracks. It's probably a Dream Theater Fan crime to say this, but Train of Thought is still my favorite DT album. It's fast, it's heavy, and it shreds non stop (except for the cello-driven \\"Stream Of Consciousness\\"). But the nice thing about \\"Octavarium\\" is that this album is almost a direct contrast from T.O.T. But lets not forget the heaviness of Panic Attack; John Myung's bass chops are still among the best. Granted, Petrucci isn't as solo crazy as he was on the last album, but this just goes to show his versatility. He can be the monster lead guitarist everyone loves, but he can also be the support structure of the band that is so well needed. The more I listen to this album the more I like it, and I think that's going to be the case for a lot of listeners. Dream Theater albums have always been in heavy rotation in my CD player, and this latest album by the DT boys will contribute to my daily dose of virtuosity and general musical genius. Well done gentlemen..

It should be obvious why Flor would want to keep her cultural identity and why should would want to pass this on to her daughter.  But would she deny her the chance of a lifetime to receive a top education?  It's a hard path to follow.  It seems like Brooks had the right intention (honoring cultural independence), he just couldn't figure out a way to show it in a way that was appropriate.<br /><br />*spoiler alert*<br /><br />Unlike viewers who applaud the \\"family values\\" ending, I can't say I enjoyed the last five minutes. Deborah is, quite bluntly, not just a lousy wife but also a horrible parent.  All of the kids would be better off with Flor and John together.<br /><br />I applaud Brooks for his bravery in depicting (finally!) a father figure who is loving, supportive and, most importantly, non-traditional (egalitarian).  Funny how some liberal critics missed that point.  Flor and John are the ideal parents while Deborah, the clueless perfectionist, represents any bad parent, male or female.

B0006IIPIK|3.0|The 2004 movie, \\"Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow\\", directed and written by Kerry Conran, includes the stellar cast of Jude Law, Gwyneth Paltrow, Angelina Jolie, Michael Gambon and even the late Sir Laurence Olivier.  However, the movie, along with its exceptional cast and unique look, still falls victim to a questionable plot and mediocre acting.    It's the late 1930s and someone has been kidnapping some of the most brilliant scientists of the day.  While newspaper reporter Polly Perkins (Paltrow) is tracking down leads to the disappearances, New York is attacked by a group of giant robots bent on stealing power supplies.  Enter Joe Sullivan a.k.a. the Sky Captain (Law) who is the leader of a squadron of flying aces based in a secretive location and Polly's former love interest.    When the base is destroyed and Joe's friend and technical wiz, Dex Dearborn (Giovanni Ribisi), is kidnapped, it's up to the Sky Captain and Polly to find out how the disappearance of the scientists connects to the robot attack, who's behind the chaos and what their plans are.  Clues soon lead the pair to Dr. Totenkopf (Olivier).  With the help of Captain Franky Cook (Jolie) and her amphibious squadron, they are able to infiltrate Totenkopf's lair and discover his dastardly plans.  From there, it's up to the Sky Captain to not only save the scientists but keep the entire world from being annihilated.    There are several good things about \\"Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow\\".  With the increasing advances in technology, the movie is unique in the fact that the entire film was created by using strategically placed props with a green screen backdrop.  Except for the actors, most of the scenes in the movie were created by computers which gave the film a different look not seen in other features.    Gwyneth Paltrow and Jude Law are considered the two main characters of the film.  However, it's Giovanni Ribisi's performance as Dex Dearborn that really steals the movie and offers somecomedic relief.    Despite some good points, there are some negative aspects to the film.  Although their performances were fine, the fact that Paltrow's and Law's characters were formerly and potentially romantically involved didn't come across as such.  Unfortunately the use of Michael Gambon as Polly's editor and Angelina Jolie was to move the plot quickly from one place to another.  When using this talented actor and actress, it would seem that their characters could have been built up a little more.    The movie's ending was also anticlimactic.  It's easy to see how some people could walk away feeling completely confused.  At some parts towards the end, such as the battle inside the ship, it even seems a bit rushed.    Because of computer effects, the use of actors posthumously is on the rise.  Such is the case with Sir Laurence Olivier who was seen in a few scenes in \\"Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow\\".  The actor passed in 1989.  But because of CGI and old video footage of the actor, he was still credited as playing Totenkopf.  The popularity of this new trend will depend on the individual moviegoer's tastes.     \\"Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow\\" is not the best film but it isn't the worst film to come out of Hollywood.  It's just simple entertainment.  Although it is lacking in some parts, the movie provides a unique style of film making.

B0009A1AS2|4.0|I've only known Dream Theater's music for about three years or so, but I own all their albums.  Maybe it's because I'm a teenager, but I've noticed their music has changed for the better. Their early work is amazing, but after \\"Scenes from a Memory\\" (which is probably their best album to date), the level of creativity and intensity has improved a lot ever since Jordan Rudess joined the band.  Sometimes, its easy for fans to pigeon-hold a band to a specific type of sound they expect to get, but that shouldn't happen to Dream Theater, and I think both existing fans and new fans have to realize that it's better for a band to approach their music differently every time they make an album or a song.  Otherwise, the band becomes predictable and their music kind of loses originality and turns into dry and formulaic fan-pleasers.  That's not what Dream Theater is about.  DT is an incredibly talented group of musicians that can write amazing songs and are great performers live.  Octavarium seems like a reaction to Train of Thought (which was more on the dark/heavy side).  I think we should give time to their latest release to sink in and really absorb the music before bashing the work.

This is their strongest LP since Winds OF Change (which I would call a neglected masterpice, as strong as Pepper and Sunshine Superman). Love Is was a few years ahead it's time, looking forward to other progresive excesses of the early 70s, to the likes of Hawkwind, Yes, and, the worst, sorry ELP. You have to like anything Eric does to appreciate the CD, if not, it will totally go over your head. They did not take the easy route with this LP. It keeps you on your toes with unpredictable changes, and never for the sake of them. The tunes make no claims to be perfect pop songs,(although River Deep is) yet it somehow manages to avoid just about every cliche in pop music as they use those excesses and cliches to their own ends in their attempt to move music forward. The band didn't burn out. Once again Eric did his thing and moved on just at the right moment. He never sold out. One of my favorites right now.
B000068PNQ|5.0|This is one of the greatest albums of the 1960's, hands down. That said, this re-issue is an interesting idea, but it's definitely not going to please everyone. The mono mix of this album is superior and closer to what the band intended, but the differences are not dramatic and it's really the kind of thing that only a record-nerd like myself would care about. Buying this is certainly easier than trying to track down a mono copy of the record, that's for sure. It's only for a die-hard fan, and pointing out that it's easier for the casual fan to simply buy the single cd is beyond obvious. There are several albums from this era where the mono mix is noticably different and/or superior. The most striking instance is the first Pink Floyd album \\"Piper at the Gates of Dawn.\\" No one ever listens to me about this, but the difference between the stereo and mono mix of that album is like night and day, seriously. And the mono is so much better, I mean so much better, that the fact that only the stereo is commercially available is an autrocity. (Will someone please re-issue the mono mix of this album on cd like they did here with the Velvets). Any record-geek will tell you that Sgt. Pepper and The White Album are superior, or at least noticably different in mono. But the mono mix of this album is superior, but not dramatically so, and the original \\"closet\\" mix of the Velvets third album is more strikingly different than the mono mix of this album, and can be found as apart of the 5 CD Velvets box set. I think this was a noble effort that is easy to trash, because it's not worth it to most people to spend the extra money. I think it's probably the case that there aren't enough existing outtakes to make a 2cd set like the \\"Fully Loaded\\" version of the Velvets final album. The Nico solo stuff is not out of place either, as the Velvets were her band for these tracks so, in many respects, it's comparable to Femme Fetale, etc. Bottomline, the mono mix of this album was in demand. I'm happy to finally get a copy, especially on CD. I think this re-issue was a welcome one, but again, it's geared toward a completist. Personally, I bought my copy used on amazon for roughly the same amount of money that people are selling the single cd. If the difference is like 50 cents, please. Spend the extra money and get the two-disc set, why not. If it's twice the amount for the two-disc and you've never owned this album, obviously go for the single disc.

B00097A5I6|3.0|There is no question that the past two efforts by Oasis were, on the whole, fairly weak. They each had their bright tracks, but they failed to showcase the talents and the appeal that Oasis displayed on their first three albums. On 'Don't Believe the Truth' the Gallagher boys and company seem to have their feet set on the right path again. <br /> <br />On the whole this album still doesn't compare to the lofty music that Oasis made on their earlier efforts, but at the same time it certainly eclipses their two most recent efforts by a landslide. Tracks to note are \\"The Importance of Being Idle\\", \\"Part of the Queue\\", \\"Keep the Dream Alive\\", and perhaps the closest thing to an anthem circa \\"Champagne Supernova\\", the fantastically stirring \\"Let There Be Love\\". The latter track is the clearest glimpse of what Oasis could be if they stuck to making more huge, melodic, arena-rocking songs of old (\\"Wonderwall\\", \\"Don't Look Back in Anger\\", \\"Live Forever\\") instead of pumping out songs that simply don't catch on as quickly or nearly as deeply. Though \\"Let There Be Love\\" borders on being outright cheesy, it's immediate appeal and heartfelt connection is undeniable, and it would do Oasis much good if they tried making more songs like it. <br /> <br />Oasis has done a great job of rocking out in a refined and vintage way, almost on the verge of sounding like a different band altogether, but Liam's jeering singing and Noel's ever-improving voice anchor the album. In fact, the tracks Noel sings almost outshine his brother's tracks. <br /> <br />Their fans will be satisfied, and those new to Oasis will be intrigued but most likely not totally won over. On 'Don't Believe the Truth' Oasis finally gives us hope that all is not lost and that a couple more good albums may yet be on the way.

B000002UB3|5.0|Abbey Road, first off, is one of the greatest albums ever. It's not just because of the insanely magnificent songwriting or the delicious mood of the album that makes it so great, but also because of the overall \\"togetherness\\" of the album.  <br /> <br />The cohesiveness of this album (and it truly is an \\"album;\\" all the tracks support and enhance one another even though most would be great songs on their own) is nothing short of spectacular. The mechanical chords of \\"Come Together,\\" the title itself expressing the feeling throughout the album, progress into the splendid \\"Something.\\" The first five songs are the most individualistic, but nevertheless, they still have a wonderful shared purpose in the big picture.  <br /> <br />By the end of the sixth track, the album reaches its pinnacle, where it stays for the remainder. The gentle sparklings of \\"Here Comes the Sun\\" emerge softly from the deafening silence left by the muscular ending of \\"I Want You,\\" leaving the listener bewildered.  <br /> <br />The remainder of the album is nothing short of spectacular. Such magnificent creativity has not been felt since. The orchestral theme of \\"You Never Give Me Your Money\\" reappears at the end of \\"Carry that Weight,\\" while \\"Mean Mr. Mustard\\" alludes to \\"Polythene Pam.\\" Gaps between songs are eliminated, and the general impression of the album is that it is an almost constant flow of musical greatness.  <br /> <br />The true themes of the album are ends, both false and unexpected. From the abrupt ending of \\"I Want You\\" to the actual song \\"The End\\" which, in typical Beatles fashion is not the end of the CD, the Fab Four always keep you on the edge of your seat. But most of all, Abbey Road signified the end of the Beatles reign, something that everyone knew would have to come yet all dreaded it. Luckily, unlike so many other great bands, the Beatles left on a high note, leaving behind for us a wonderful piece of music.
B0006L16N8|5.0|I had my first listen to this album while exercising on an elliptical machine at the gym with headphones on.  I was expecting to hear more of the same as  from their two previous cd's, both of which I loved.  In fact, after listening to X&Y more than a few times, I felt inspired to listen to  Parachutes and A Rush of Blood To The Head.  X&Y is an impressive display of the versatility Coldplay possesses.  It is my opinion that X&Y has a more \\"sonic\\" sound, as opposed to the \\"rock\\" sound of the two previous cd's.  I especially like the use of strings, organ, more piano, and acoustic guitar on X&Y.  Chris Martin uses more of the upper register and falsetto of his voice here, more so than on the previous two cd's. And he uses it with great ease and naturalness.  One customer reviewer felt that Chris Martin was attempting to sound like Bono.  Bono does use a lot of falsetto in his singing, but his vocal quality is angst driven, with a sense of urgency.  But Chris Martin sings with a sensitive expression of pain, and matters of the heart.  Both of these singers are great, but they are very different - almost dramatically.  For those listeners who are critical of Coldplay for trying something different with X&Y, well, one must understand that great artists make creative efforts not to repeat themselves, but to experiment and to take risks.  I would not be surprised if Coldplay's next cd moves in a direction different from X&Y.  I respect their courage to stretch their talents - and enormous talents they surely are.  I applaud Coldplay.
B00097A5HW|5.0|We have to admit that with a title like Fijacion Oral one expects to listen nothing but a bunch of loud beats and uncalled nonsense. But what a great surprise when, past the contagious notes of lead single \\"La tortura\\", fears disolve in front of a bouquet of melodies and emotions not exactly a trademark of the colombian singer's previous releases. It is true that we won't hear her singing about looking for a lover in her purse or in Botero's paintings (circa Pies Descalzos), but there is still a candid approach to the lyrics that has made her songs both appealing and puzzling. In Fijacion oral we come face to face with a Shakira that shares her passion and the sense of emptiness a love she has already experienced may bring once it's gone, as opossed to the longing for an unknown feeling that we tasted in the other two albums. It shows a more mature approach to life, love and music in general. The definite highlight is \\"La pared\\" (track that appears in two versions), with its grasping chorus and a performance so beautifully delivered that it can only be compared to the classic \\"Antologia\\". It is precisely in this harmonious voice that Fijacion oral finds its anchor, among a collection of rhythms that go from the poppy \\"Las de la intuicion\\" (the only song in this album to remind us of earlier times), to bossa nova (\\"Obtener un si\\"), to the perfect composition of \\"Dia especial\\", which she co-wrote and performed with latin legend Gustavo Ceratti, that otherwise would be a complete chaos. <br />Toward the end we face the flaw that she might as well skipped: \\"Lo imprescindible\\" sounds indeed quite innovative with the rapid switch of tempo, but fails to close an album that could arguably be Shakira's masterpiece.  <br />Absolutely brethtaking moments and still a lot of fun, Fijacion oral is a delight not destines to please anyone but those who believed Shakira can go beyond mud crawling and hip shaking.
1883010039|4.0|The most important thing I learned from this book is that I'm not ready for this book!  I inherited my mother's table loom some time ago and have not had time to look into weaving until recently.  To get myself started, I purchased a number of books on weaving so that I could build up to tackling her loom.  I found both \\"Weaving Without a Loom\\" and \\"You Can Weave\\" very helpful for a beginner.  They taught simple terminology, basic weaves, the use of a variety of materials not only for weaving but for looms, and the use of patterns.  Chandler and Redding's book, \\"Learning to Weave,\\" looks to be an excellent resource for weaving on my table loom, but just perusing it's pages, I realized that I still need to work a little with the simpler looms before getting on to the main task.  In reading the book, I found the notion of samples a fine idea.  I started making them with some of the simpler looms, and have even found a use for some of the samples I've made.  The suggestion regarding practice color combinations was also helpful.  In looking forward to the daunting task of warping or dressing my table loom, I suspect that the authors' suggestions with respect to managing the warp threads and the alternative suggestions with respect to approaching the physical task itself will make my first experience much less frustrating.  But first we have to build up the courage!

'B.Y.O.B' is the best song on the album and it's track number two. Theres nothing wrong with that but it leaves the rest of the album comming up short, or at least in my openion it does. The guitar riff to B.Y.O.B. is one of the best guitar riffs I have heard in a long time, and I love the lyrics because they are so true. One thing System Of A Down can do is right a political song, and do it well. 'Sweet Revenga' is the next song and I like this song, it has a nice catchy chorus and once again some pretty cool guitar tricks by Daron. 'Cigaro' is next, it's a pretty funny song, but it also has a killer chorus. I love Cigaro. After Cigaro however, the album just feels empty. I still like the rest of the songs but I just don't feel that they are really worth mentioning. The guitar is great through out the rest of the album and the vocals and lyrics are good as well. However one of my complaints on this album is that the drummer is a really good drummer but it doesnt show on Mezmerize and the same can be said for the bass player, they are truly talented musicians but they are not doint what they are capable of. The biggest highlight of this album is that Daron wrote most of everything, and he sings more on this album then he has one all the past Sytem Of A Down albums combined. It adds a really  nice touch to the album and the sound of the vocals and music, they should really layer Serj's and Daron's vocals more often.<br /><br />All I can say is this is not an album for our everyday hard rock fan or you casual System Of A Down fan but more for a hardcore fanatic. While this is a good album I really belieave it could have been a great album!f the vocals and music, they should really layer Serj's and Daron's vocals more often. <br /> <br />All I can say is this is not an album for our everyday hard rock fan or you casual System Of A Down fan but more for a hardcore fanatic. While this is a good album I really belieave it could have been a great album!

Music didn't have too much of an effect on me then, but I just thought the songs were just amazing then and still do. Years later, and I discovered the band for real and borrowed \\"Hybrid Theory\\" from a friend. It has yet to be returned. Linkin Park have a sound that combines rap elements with rock in a truly unique original way that's only theirs. Too describe the band I'll start with the band's two vocalists. Chester Bennington's vocals include of mostly screaming hooks, but unlike popular belief the guy can do things other than scream as heard in hits like \\"In The End\\" and \\"Crawling\\" The other vocalist Mike Shinoda is the rapper of the group and his rapping flows clearly and goes perfect with Chester's to add to the unique sound of the band. The DJ of the band plays a big role in the sound and uses his scratching and sampling for a very cool unique effect. The album itself is truly an enjoyable thing to listen too. Every song on the album is a hit from begining to end, even the instrumental \\"Cure For The Itch\\" which really shows the DJ's talent. From heavier, angrier, faster  tracks like the hits \\"One Step Closer\\" and \\"Points of Authority\\" to the lesser knowns \\"Forgotten\\" and \\"By Myself\\" Too the softer more balanced tracks where the band really shines in radio hits \\"In The End\\" and \\"Crawling\\" I highly reccomend this album to any music listeners, even the more \\"hardcore\\" listener of music should give this album a try, I doubt you'll be disapointed.

B000069AUI|5.0|Coldplay is certainly back in the limelight with their new release \\"X&Y\\", but 2002's \\"A Rush of Blood to the Head\\" represents their finest work so far.  This album truly belongs in 5-star modern rock company along with \\"OK Computer\\", \\"Disintegration\\" and \\"The Joshua Tree\\".   <br /> <br />Many will already be familiar with mega-hit singles \\"In My Place\\", \\"Clocks\\" and \\"The Scientist\\", but the best material lies in the other album tracks.  \\"God Put a Smile Upon Your Face\\" combines a slinky acoustic stomp with an uplifting chorus that's impossible not to sing along with.  The title track may be the band's most straightforward rock song, combining bluesy and dreamy elements into a sound reminiscent of classic Pink Floyd.  \\"Amsterdam\\" is a heart-breakingly beautiful ballad that closes the album with its emotional crescendo.   <br /> <br />\\"A Rush of Blood to the Head\\" is one of those rare, once-in-an-artist's-career moments when all elements come together perfectly.  Songwriting, performance, and emotional depth and variety make this album a must-have for any modern rock fan.

B000002H33|5.0|I would give anything to go back in time to 1986. Reign in Blood was kicking the world's ass, Megadeth was Selling Peace, and prog shred just started to hit the air waves.
