B000002UAX|5.0|I'm not going to lie about it, I love this album. I think it's The Beatles best work, although Abbey Road is amazing as well, and a fine example of excellent musicianship. Pretty much all the songs on this album are absolute masterpieces and  it lets all four of The Beatles have their share of the limelight. <br /> <br />Everything starts off with Paul's Back In The USSR which takes inspiration from both Chcuk Berry and The Beach Boys, and wraps it all in The Beatles style. It's a great number which is very easy to listen to, and it also has some very nice guitar work, courtesy, as usual, of George. Next up is John's Dear Prudence, which his second son Sean did an excellent cover of in 1990 or round about, and it's a great song. It's much more quiet than Back In The USSR, but things get a little louder again with Glass Onion with is basically John's sequel to both Strawberry Fields Forever and I Am The Walrus. He mentions some of the mysteries surrounding the other songs, and adds even more clues to the whole \\"Paul is dead\\" theory as well. It's a good song, if not as enjoyable as Strawberry Fields Forever or I Am The Walrus. The next song is Ob-La-Di, Ob-La-Da which was recently voted one of the worst songs of all time. I can see why some people don't like it but I don't think it lessens the impact of the album in any way. Included in the rest of the first album of this double album is The Continuing Story of Bungalow Bill, a great John song, followed by what is possibly George's best song... While My Guitar Gently Weeps. It's wonderfully structured and, of course, it includes an amazing guitar solo by guest musician Eric Clapton, as George wasn't confident enough to try the complicated solo himself. George's other song on album number one is Piggies, which is basically about the police. It's a great song, with some nice semi-sarcastic comments. Ringo also has his songwriting debut with Don't Pass Me By, a country style number later on in the album. It's good, but Iprefer Ringo's other songwriting attempt on Abbey Road, Octopus' Garden. Then we have John's Happiness Is A Warm Gun which, like A Day In The Life, consists of a few songs strung together, and it's very well done. We also have his Julia, a touching tribute to both his mother and his new love Yoko, and I;m So Tired, which has an interesting bit of mumble jumble at the end of the song where he's muttering and, when played backwards, it very clearly says \\"Paul is a dead man... miss him... miss him... miss him\\". Don't believe me? Go and play it backwards and see. <br /> <br />Album number two maybe isn't as good as the first but it includes some pretty famous numbers and one of the most notorious moments in The Beatles' history. First, we have Paul's song Birthday which is good but is followed up by John's amazing Yer Blues, which he later played live on his Live Peace In Toronto album. It's a stark song and a million miles away from the days of Love Me Do, She Loves You and I Wanna Hold Your Hand. Speaking of dark, we also have one of Paul's best Helter Skelter which, as you probably know, was the song that inspired Charles Manson to kill Sharon Tate. George's Piggies is also supposed to have contributed to this murderous rampage. John has two other shining moments on the album with Revolution 1 which had prmeiered in a faster, more rocking, version as the B-side to the Hey Jude single shortly before The White Album was released. Revolution 1 is a slower version but still retains it's edge. John's other great moment is Cry Baby Cry which is one of those songs that is very easy to listen to again, and again. <br /> <br />Of course, you have to talk about Revolution 9 when you review The White Album. Originally intended as the end of Revolution 1, it's basically a series of strange noises and sounds effects with the sound sof marching, talking, shouting, cars, fires... just about everything. I understand why people don't like it but as a fan of John and Yoko's later avant garde work, I think it's a wonderful piece of work. Like John says, he probably spent more time on that song than any other he ever did when he was working as a Beatle. The album finally finishes off with Good Night, a lullaby John wrote to his son Julian, which is sung by Ringo. It's of a much lesser quality than the rest of the album, but it's still a good number. <br /> <br />And that's it... The Beatles... The White Album. It doesn't get much better than this. I suggest getting this and Abbey Road so you can finally see why everyone calls The Beatles the best band in the history of music.
B000002H2H|5.0|Never has there been a more well-rounded thrash/speed metal album revolving around death. From the unbelievably fast riffing in Fight Fire with Fire to the classic irresistable guitarness of Ride the Lightning to the powerhouse metal coiled with For Whom the Bell Tolls, Metallica kicks the ass of the music that you've been listening to in just the first 3 tracks. Trapped Under Ice and Creeping Death are quite thrashy, while Escape provides likable melodies in a change of pace and Call of the Ktulu ends the album in an epic, creepy instrumental. Fade to Black; however, dominates as the best song on the album, as well as one of the band's best work. Mixing acoustic clean mastery with haunting vocals/lyrics and piercing solos, it's enough to make one forget about the latest homogenous numetal 'album' they picked up because of that catchy radio hit they like. Own this or be owned.
B000002UAR|5.0|With their previous album, Rubber Soul, The Beatles had shown that they weren't going to stick to the pop norms of the time, and they tried many different things. Revolver goes further with this, and includes some amazing numbers. It's a great transition between Rubber Soul and Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band, and is definitely worth your time. <br /> <br />The album starts off with what is probably George's first \\"great\\" song, called Taxman. It was unusual for an album to start off with a song not penned by John or Paul but it proves that George was just as capable as those two. The next number is Eleanor Rigby by Paul and is also a little mini-masterpiece. It's actually quite a dark number, and I always liked the \\"lonely people\\" intro. Then we move on to John's I'm Only Sleeping which is possibly my favorite song on this album. A great number, with a backwards guitar solo, which was one of the first instances of this (their single Paperback Writer/Rain had been released just before this and the song Rain contained a backwards section). These first three songs by George, Paul and John, respectively, are a great little trilogy and an excellent start to the album, showing the talents of these three members of the band. <br /> <br />Ringo would also get a little chance to shine with his lead vocals on Yellow Submarine. A wonderful, catchy tune, about LSD disguised as a nursery rhyme, it's become a favorite of both adults and children and, of course, was the basis for the animated Beatles film. <br /> <br />Of course, For No One, Here, There and Everywhere, Tomorrow Never Knows, to choose but a few, are all great songs as well, with Tomorrow Never Knows providing a great segue-way into the trippiness of Sgt. Pepper.
1400034779|5.0|Oh, how I love these stories. I read Tears of the Giraffe first (see Amazon review of 5/24/05), and loved it. I would recommend, as with all series, that you begin here with The No. 1 Ladies' Detective Agency. This is where you get the full background about how the agency got started, about its proprietress, Precious Ramotswe; Mma Ramotswe's beloved Daddy, Obed; and her friend J.L.B. Matekoni, and others. You'll fall in love with Mma Ramotswe's Africa as well.<br /><br />The story takes place in Botswana, a country just north of South Africa. Botswana is a democracy and has done very well for itself since the mid-sixties when it gained its independence. Precious Ramotswe, who is always called Mma Ramotswe, opens the first and only detective agency in Africa run by a woman, after the death of her father. She is a very clever woman, quite plump, too, which is a good thing...she refers to her build as the \\"traditional\\" build of the Botswana female. She is very proud of her size and her brain, which she puts to good use in helping people solve the \\"problems in their lives.\\"<br /><br />The book is a series of events of a social, personal, and business nature and moves easily along and keeps the reader interested. The best way I can describe McCall Smith's writing is that it has class, from his vocabulary to his style. The story flows smoothly from one page to another; one chapter to another; and even horrible events in people's life are served up with a kind of dignity as presented from the viewpoint of Mma Ramotswe. While Mma is a very gracious and polite lady, she can be ruthless when dealing with vile, evil, and unscrupulous individuals. In the end, she is not afraid of anybody or anything! I'd love to meet her...if she were only real!!<br /><br />Carolyn Rowe Hill
B000002UDB|4.0|Originally released as an EP in the UK to accompany the TV film of the same name and expanded to a full album, using several singles, in the US, the \\"album\\" version was the one released on CD, and is the one widely available now. <br /> <br />Personally, I don't think that the singles mix well with the rest of the songs but, hey, any Beatles is good Beatles, that's my opinion. I also like his Your Mother Should Know. Sure, it's cheesy, but it's catchy and I always liked the way it is used in the Magical Mystery Tour film. George's song Blue Jay Way isn't his best but it's enjoyable none the less. <br /> <br />The real masterpiece on this album, in my opinion, is John's song I Am The Walrus which started the whole \\"who is the walrus?\\" mystery. Of course, in the end, it all ties up to the whole \\"Paul is dead\\" thing. There's plenty of websites that deal with this subject so I won't go any further, as there are much better places where you can read up on it. <br /> <br />Sandwhiched between Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club and The White Album, two of The Beatles' finest works, the Magical Mystery Tour EP/Album is often forgotten but it contains a couple of gems and is well worth picking up.
B0000024SI|5.0|With apologies to Dan Berg, this was the new American language, the most compelling, surging songwriting in English, during the mid century. I'd been content, pretty much with radio fare. And if my favourites weren't getting played sufficiently, or had gone off the boil, I purchased a 45 of Pitney's, Mecca, or Manfred Mann's,'Do Wah Diddy Diddy'. One summer Saturday morning, I indulged in hitherto unprecedented behaviour. First, at the newsagent, I bought a copy of the new national daily, The Australian. Hoping to nurture my budding curiosity, I honed in on the 'arts' section where a generous and probing review of an unknown (to me) Bob Dylan impelled me to a second purchase that morning at the local record bar.Have you got,'Another Side of Bob Dylan'? I tended. 'No. But we've got his latest\\". I swooped in on'Highway 61', my first LP. So much of my remaing teenage years were literally galvanised to Bob. As fanatical as I was about my weekend sports, I sat transfixed over the old portable player, returning its arm into the groove that gave over those 11.20 minutes of,'Desolation Row.' In two and a half hours I had them burned into my mind. For the first and only time in my life I missed the beginning of my sport's event and was incapable of explaining my waywardness.That night, in the town's only stairwell where sufficient chamber had allowed me to unconvincingly croon,'Unchained Melody' I had no difficulty in mimicking the raspy weariness of Bob. Mr Jones, Dr.Filth, Ezra Pound, the Graveyard Woman, Queen Jane and the Junkyard Angel, a trunkload of freaks and lost souls driven mad by surging rock rythyms, would lead me into temptation and console me through my romantic bittersweet youth. It was a hard if not impossible act to follow. Only Bob did so with the sprawlingly fecund,'Blonde On Blonde'. He was the measuring stick for the Bobby Linds' (Butterfly of Love) the Phil Ochs'(Pleasures of the Harbour), the Eric Andersons'(Blue River). I waited breathlessly for whathe might offer. There'd been nothing like his fullness in my life. The profundity of ,'John Wesley Harding' was yet to come with his cast pruned to less flamboyant if more archetypal beings, the Wicked Messenger, the Drifter,the Immigrant,the Joker and the Thief. But it was 61 I travelled first and most formidably; a Saturday morning riven in my life, propelling me into the power of contemporary language and its complexities of inwardness; out of the sticks, where I lived, to wander some mythic nightscape.
B000002UAO|5.0|Although The Beatles were very successful before, this album is where they really took off as a band that were willing to do something completely different from anything that had came before them. <br /> <br />The album starts off with the fairly ordinary number Drive My Car, before the siatr kicks in on Norwegian Wood (This Bird Has Flown). This is where it starts getting very unusual. Norwegian Wood is a great song and the use of the sitar was something that no one had ever heard before. It works great, and the song sets the path for the rest of the album. John is probably the main man on this album with Nowhere Man, Girl, In My Life, and Run For Your Life all being incredible highlights. Nowhere Man is a great song with some nice guitar work, and In My Life always brings a tear to my eye whenever I hear it. <br /> <br />Of course, it's not just John's show as Paul contributes some great numbers as well. You Won't See Me and I'm Looking Through You, both about his relationship and breakup with Jane Asher, are great numbers and definitely get your foot tapping away when you hear them. Paul also contributes the sweet song Michelle, which pretty much cemented his status as the cute, loving Beatle.  <br /> <br />George has two songs on this album, If I Needed Someone being one of them, and I think it's a really good one. He was really starting to improve his writing and he would add a couple of excellent songs to The Beatles' next album, Revolver. <br /> <br />Rubber Soul was really the first album where the public saw that The Beatles were a band who were ready to try different things. This album has quite a few masterpieces, and is really worth picking up, along with The White Album and Abbey Road, if you want to see what all the fuss about The Beatles is.

B000002UAU|5.0|Perhaps one of the most discussed albums of all time, and priviledged with almost 1000 reviews here on Amazon, you wonder what more can be said about this album. I'm not going try to add anything new, except that I love this album. The Beatles were the best band of all time, no doubt about it, and when this album came out, it was something that no one had ever heard before. Everything was different from it's faus live structure, to the sitars on Within You, Without You (although The Beatles had previously used sitars on Norwegian Wood, and The Rolling Stones had used one on Paint It Black), to the amazing five minutes that end the album... the song known as Day In The Life. This is a song that I could talk about for hours. It's a wonderfully structured, starting with John's haunting voice, then moving into a large orchestra, then Paul's slightly more upbeat section, and then end with THAT piano chord. It's a song of a quality that had not been acheived to that point, and is rarely acheived anymore. <br /> <br />Of course, that's not the only song on this album, as there is many more. I've always enjoyed With A Little Help From My Friends, mainly because I've always enjoyed Ringo's vocals, and it's a catchy tune. Of course, Lucy In The Sky With Diamonds is one of John's greatest Beatles songs, as is Being For The Benefit Of Mr. Kite. The rest of the songs can be hit or miss. Getting Better is listenable but hardly a classic, same for Fixing A Hole. I do enjoy She's Leaving Home and the catchiness of Lovely Rita, and I think Good Morning, Good Morning is a nice number. <br /> <br />I could talk about this album for a while but there's not much more to say. Is it The Beatles' best album? No, personally, I think it would be either The White Album or Abbey Road, but Sgt. Pepper is much better than the majority of albums that were coming out at that time. I highly recommend it.

B000002UAI|4.0|Beatles For Sale is an album that seems to be rarely talked about amongst the Beatles community. A lot of people think it was rushed out, and that the boys were very tired from touring, both of which may be true, but it has several rewarding aspects. <br /> <br />Perhaps most interesting are the first two numbers, No Reply and I'm A Loser, both of which are John's songs. They have a very Dylan-esque feel to them that John would later perfect with You've Got To Hide Your Love Away on the Help album. They're both very memorable songs that people rarely talk about anymore.  <br /> <br />Also of interest is Paul's number I'll Follow The Sun which is a very catchy, bright little number. It has the same feel of Yesterday, which would debut in the next album. This album has several cover versions, which is a slight disappointment since The Beatles' previous album A Hard Day's Night had been their first full album of all original songs. Still, Paul's cover of Kansas City is a nice piece of old fashioned rock and roll, as is the song titled, suitably enough, Rock & Roll Music. Another good song is Eight Days A Week which was also a single.  <br /> <br />Overall, it's a good album but maybe not essential if you're not a hardcore Beatles fan. Still, it offers several good songs, so borrow a copy first and then decide if you want to buy.

On the way he meets women that share the same pain that he has. B0006L16N8|5.0|Believe it or not at one point in time I actually hated this band...no joke! Coldplay can now proudly say that they have officially conquered the music world. With tickets being sold for almost a grand to see their shows...I would agree. Coldplay returns after an almost 4 year hiatus from their grammy winning sophomore release only to return with something even better. `X&Y' is the same old Coldplay from a mood standpoint. Meloncholly tunes that are fun to relax to, but this time Coldplay really tried to experiment with new sounds. Coldplay uses the neo-new wave sound through the uses of keyboard effects on songs like `Square One and the self titled track, probably to throw in the science theme. There are also familiar  sounds featured in the hit single `Speed of Sound' and `Fix You' Then what makes this album really special is new song themes and tunes that make people listen and say...\\"Wait...that was Coldplay?\\" Songs such as those are. `A Message' and my favorite from the album `Swallowed In The Sea.' `X&Y' is all there was to be expected from this now super group and I am hoping that they will keep finding new ways to continue pleasing their fans. Being compared to bands like U2...I am sure they are hoping the same.

0316172324|3.0|This book is nothing more (or less) than an intriguing and entertaining collection of anecdotes.  Gladwell presents these as examples of how a finely tuned unconscious can make near-instantaneous decisions that are superior to the results of extensive information-gathering and analysis.  Unfortunately, nothing of any substance is offered in the way of how to train your mind to \\"thin-slice\\" or how and when to trust it (Gladwell points out that the unconscious can also be disastrously wrong).  Perhaps the author has left that for his next best-seller?
B00008S2VG|4.0|I have revisited Madge's much-maligned 2003 album \\"American Life\\" and I actually think it's pretty good...not at all as bad as people made it out to be when it was originally released. A couple of things may have factored in this: obviously, the title track, which I love, was a risky song to release as a first single, but heck, she was really the only artist at that point in time making her opinion heard of the Iraq war and the situation in the U.S. loud and clear...the American public took offense (surprise) and the song and album did not fare very well. The best version of the song, however, is the Oakenfold remix, which should have been the single (and they should have taken out that awful rap)...speaking of rap, Madonna's rapping on this album is dismal and also influenced the negative reviews, but she only does it a few times. The album's poorly chosen second single \\"Hollywood\\" holds the dubious distinction of being Madge's first single to fail to crack the U.S. Hot 100, and truly is one of Madonna's most tepid, uninspired and unoriginal songs, and probably aided in the album's tanking. Whoever thought of releasing that song as a second single should be fired. Same with the double sided \\"Nothing Fails\\"/\\"Nobody Knows Me,\\" which also failed to chart. The fourth single released from this album, \\"Love Profusion,\\" should have been the second, and it might have kept the album afloat in the U.S. Either way, \\"Love Profusion\\" had a great video and was a major hit internationally, especially in Spain, where it went to number one. Another lovely song that could have been a single was \\"Intervention.\\" Had they selected better songs as singles, this album may have fared differently. All in all, it makes for a good listen.
